headline: An Israeli Rights Group Fights for Palestinians
abstract: LEAD: Dedi Zucker did not expect that founding the only Israeli organization that monitors human rights abuses in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip would help bring threats to his life by angry Jewish mobs.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Babcock Industries, Fairfield, Conn., a diversified manufacturer that is a subsidiary of FKI P.L.C., Halifax, England, promoted Robert M. Miller to vice president of legal and to secretary.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   U.S. WARNS ALLIES ON AID TO SOVIETS
abstract: LEAD: The United States threatened today not to join a new financial institution designed to funnel the bulk of economic assistance to Eastern Europe if the Soviet Union were to become a major borrower from the organization.

headline: Romanians Take Stock Of Damage
abstract: LEAD: At the Foreign Trade Ministry, the leaders of Romania entrusted with reviving the country's export industry recently made an alarming discovery: no specialists in foreign trade were being trained in the country.

headline: Gillette Reacts To U.S. Move
abstract: LEAD: The Gillette Company said today that it was surprised and disappointed by a Federal Government decision to bring an antitrust suit to block its acquisition of the United States operations of Wilkinson Sword Inc.      Gillette had agreed to buy

headline: For I.B.M. Users, Programs Abound for IBM
abstract: LEAD: An irony surrounds the bevy of tax-preparation computer programs on the market these days: Despite countless hours spent by program writers to distinguish their products from the competition, the programs for I.B.M. and compatible personal computers remain essentially alike. As a result, a consumer would be wise to pick a program based on how easy it is to use, whether it offers adequate on-screen help and whether it can generate a finished tax return on the printer the consumer owns.

headline: Japan Store Shuns Bloomingdale's Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Tokyu Department Store of Japan said it had decided not to join in a proposed management buyout of the Bloomingdale's department store chain. The decision came late last year after a series of studies and contacts with Bloomingdale's, a Tokyu official said.

headline: Control Data Shift at Top
abstract: LEAD: The Control Data Corporation said today that its chairman, Robert M. Price, retired on Thursday but remains chairman of the company's board.

headline: Kroger Reduces 4th-Quarter Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Kroger Company said today that it had lost $45.9 million in the fourth quarter because of an extraordinary loss of $51.3 million from writing off debt.

headline: Talks on Bank to Aid the East Bloc End in Dispute
abstract: LEAD: An East-West meeting on establishing a development bank to help Eastern Europe's troubled economies ended today with some dispute over whether the bank's lending should be limited to only the private sector.

headline: Syrian Leader Assails Change In East Bloc as Boon to Israel
abstract: LEAD: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria today denounced political changes in Eastern Europe as beneficial to Israel and offered no promises of major liberalization by his own Government.

headline: Company News;   I.B.M. Researchers Increase Speed of Silicon Transistors
abstract: LEAD: In a development likely to extend the life of silicon as the leading material for manufacturing high-speed semiconductors, I.B.M. researchers have almost doubled the world's record for the speed of silicon-based transistors.

headline: S.E.C. Cites Lawyer Over Grand Met
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a Minneapolis lawyer with trading on inside information about Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s takeover of the Pillsbury Company in 1988.

headline: Chancay Journal;   Where Ancient Infants Lie, Grave Robbers Thrive
abstract: LEAD: Dressed in safari shorts and a bikini top, the young Italian tourist could barely conceal her disappointment as she stood on a sand dune.

headline: Anti-U.S. Threat in Panama
abstract: LEAD: A terrorist group has claimed responsibility for the fatal crash of two United States helicopters and the bombing of a discotheque, and it threatened more attacks on Americans and United States property. The group calls itself the December 20 Movement after the date of the American invasion of Panama.

headline: Steady Rates Expected If Dollar Stays Strong
abstract: LEAD: Fuzzy signals about the domestic economy and rising foreign interest rates are likely to create a standoff and keep interest rates in the United States in a narrow trading range - as long as the dollar remains strong, many analysts say.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       A lower capital gains tax rate will almost certainly be enacted this year, Administration officials and Congressional leaders say. Democrats who fought the capital gains proposals in the fall pretty much concede that they do not have enough votes to block them again. A lower capital gains tax rate has been one of President Bush's top legislative priorities.

headline: U.S. Vehicle Sales Up 8.2% in 10-Day Period
abstract: LEAD: Sales of American-made cars and light trucks were stronger than expected in early February, leading some automotive analysts to suggest that the industry may be emerging from a four-month sales slump.

headline: Anheuser-Busch
abstract: LEAD: Anheuser-Busch Inc. said it plans to begin selling its new non-alcoholic brew, O'Doul's, around the country starting on Monday. The brewery said it has had strong initial sales in selected cities where the beer has been on shelves since March. Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewery, said O'Doul's would meet the desires of a growing segment of consumers who like the taste of beer but do not want the alcohol.

headline: U.S. Pressed to Pay for Boat People in Hong Kong
abstract: LEAD: Britain is pressing the Bush Administration to pay most of the cost of caring for the tens of thousands of Vietnamese boat people now being housed in its colony of Hong Kong, as well as for building a new refugee camp, possibly on Guam, diplomats and United Nations officials here say.

headline: Hallmark Cards In Stock Buyback
abstract: LEAD: The greeting card giant Hallmark Cards Inc. said it had bought back $289 million of its own stock from the Hall family and from the company's employee stock ownership plan. The stock was bought Dec. 28 with ''available corporate cash reserves,'' a Hallmark spokesman, Steve Doyal, said. The shares were repurchased so the employee plan would have enough cash to pay for future retirements, he said.

headline: Gillette Is Planning to Open A Plant in the Soviet Union
abstract: LEAD: In a bid to become the Soviet Union's major Western supplier of razor blades, the Gillette Company said yesterday that it had tentatively agreed to build a $50 million factory capable of making 800 million blades a year, or 80 percent of the total exported annually to the Soviet Union.

headline: British Curb On Rate Swaps
abstract: LEAD: Britain's Court of Appeal ruled yesterday that interest rate swaps are legal for local government authorities if they are used to limit interest rate risks but not if they are used for speculative trading for profit.      The decision involved the

headline: Chamorro Said to Drop Anti-Army Plan
abstract: LEAD: Despite campaign promises to ''send all the weapons to the bottom of the sea,'' President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will only gradually reduce Nicaragua's military, and she has backed away from plans to abolish the army entirely, her advisers say.

headline: Saatchi & Saatchi Arranges Big Credit Line From Banks
abstract: LEAD: In a move that analysts say should calm jittery shareholders, the Saatchi & Saatchi Company, the troubled advertising and communications giant, confirmed today that it had arranged enough bank financing to see it through its current difficulties.

headline: Treasury Prices Move Downward
abstract: LEAD: A news service report about comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sent shudders through the credit markets yesterday and pushed down prices of Treasury notes and bonds.

headline: Shell From Israeli Zone Kills 2 in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Two Nepalese soldiers serving with the United Nations peacekeeping force in southern Lebanon have been killed and six wounded by an artillery shell just north of the Israeli-designated security zone in southern Lebanon, officials of the force said today.

headline: Angry at U.S. Rebuff, Jerusalem Tries to Show How Well It Treats Arabs
abstract: LEAD: As he set out on a drive through East Jerusalem Friday afternoon, trying to demonstrate despite Washington's suggestion to the contrary that the Arab half of the city is an inseparable part of the Israeli capital, Mayor Teddy Kollek could hardly restrain his anger.

headline: Scowcroft Asserts 195,000 Is Minimum for U.S. Troops
abstract: LEAD: Brent Scowcroft, President Bush's national security adviser, said today that 195,000 is the minimum number of troops that the United States needs to keep in central Europe if a new East-West agreement is reached on cutting conventional forces in Europe.

headline: American Express in Reversal
abstract: LEAD: In an abrupt about-face, the American Express Company said yesterday that it would buy all the publicly held shares of its brokerage firm, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

headline: Japan Surplus Off in Month
abstract: LEAD: Increased imports helped Japan slash its current account surplus by 32.4 percent in February, the Finance Ministry reported today.

headline: Earle Palmer Brown
abstract: LEAD: Earle Palmer Brown said its Atlanta office had added several of the staff members and clients set loose by the reduction of Tracy-Locke's Atlanta office. Donald S. Morgan, the president of Tracy-Locke Atlanta, will take a still undetermined management position at Earle Palmer Brown, which said other staff moves were under negotiation.

headline: Gambro of Sweden To Buy Cobe Labs
abstract: LEAD: The Swedish medical supplies company Gambro A.B. agreed to acquire Cobe Laboratories Inc. of Lakewood, Colo. for $37 a share, or a total of $253 million. Gambro, which is based in Lund, Sweden, said Cobe would become a fully owned subsidiary. Cobe's board recommended that its shareholders accept the bid.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Tale of Panic at Execution of Ceausescus
abstract: LEAD: In a chilling new account of the last hour of Nicolae Ceausescu, the deposed Rumanian dictator, and his wife, Elena, a prosecutor was quoted as saying that they ran wildly around the courtyard where they were to be shot until troops hunted them down.

headline: Bush Faces Decision on Arms Talks
abstract: LEAD: With conflicting advice from the national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, President Bush faces a decision on whether to wrap up a strategic arms agreement with the Soviet Union or introduce major new proposals that could delay its completion, Administration officials say.

headline: Commerce Secretary Issues Warning on Japan's Surplus
abstract: LEAD: After two days of meetings with Japanese Government officials, trading companies and political leaders, the United States Secretary of Commerce, Robert A. Mosbacher, warned today that Japan's trade surpluses had ''achieved a semipermanent status.''

headline: Shaoshan Journal;   Mao's Halo Is Back and His Hometown Is Happy
abstract: LEAD: Pilgrims are streaming once more to this little farming village, the Bethlehem of Maoism, and after a long period of neglect the town seems to be celebrating a resurrection.

headline: Reports Indicate Mounting Efforts To Free U.S. Hostages in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: There are growing indications from Washington and the Middle East of a flurry of diplomatic activity to free the American hostages in Lebanon.

headline: ISRAELI COALITION DISSOLVES IN FIGHT OVER PEACE PLAN
abstract: LEAD: Israel's coalition Government collapsed today when Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir dismissed Finance Minister Shimon Peres, the leader of the Labor Party, prompting the rest of Labor's Cabinet ministers to resign.

headline: EXECUTIVE LIFE;  Business Stars Wary Of Paparrazzi, Too
abstract: LEAD: Time was when the paparazzi were satisfied with movie stars, socialites and rock musicians. But with the tireless celebration of business during the Reagan years, chief executives have become as shutter-conscious as any Hollywood starlet. And today, many of them are managing their public images with the kind of fervor previously reserved for social climbing or corporate gamesmanship.

headline: Pope Warns on Rekindling of Rivalries in East
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II today hailed the ''irrepressible thirst for freedom'' that has ''broken down walls and opened doors'' in Eastern Europe, but he warned that the rapid political changes could unleash nationalist feelings and ethnic conflicts.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LEAD:    MONDAY: The Senate Finance Committee holds hearings on Senator Moynihan's proposed Social Security tax cut.       TUESDAY: The Fed's Open Market Committee meets.    Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady and O.M.B. director Richard G. Darman are scheduled to testify before the House Ways and Means Committee on the nation's economy and the President's budget.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: LEAD:

headline: In West Germany, Anxiety Over Unity
abstract: LEAD: In the turbulent debate about German unification, West Germany's intellectuals reflect a national mood of confusion - a profoundly troubled mix of anticipation, anxiety and resentment.

headline: Hungary Confident on Debt Payment
abstract: LEAD: Although Hungary has the highest per capita debt burden in Eastern Europe, the president of the nation's central bank proudly says the Government is against rescheduling its $20.7 billion foreign debt.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   New Polish Vanguard: Unemployed Workers
abstract: LEAD: As Poland and other Eastern European nations begin transforming their economies from Communism to capitalism, a new workers' vanguard is being formed, and Roman Anucinski is not at all happy to be part of it.

headline: Republic by Republic, Soviet Vote Points to a Murky Political Future
abstract: LEAD: Like many of the thousands of candidates campaigning for local office across the maddening new landscape of Soviet politics, Vladimir M. Rylyakov is a practicing Communist who is wondering what happened to Communism.

headline: A Radical New Style for Stodgy Old Gillette
abstract: LEAD: Now that the Gillette Company has introduced Sensor, a lot more than a tough beard is riding on the razor's edge. Management's neck is, too.

headline: Campeau Divisions Will Miss Deadline
abstract: LEAD: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation will not meet a bankruptcy court's mid-May deadline for filing a reorganization plan and will ask for more time, the lead lawyer for the department store chains said. ''We will be seeking an extension of the exclusive period,'' said David Heiman of Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue at a court hearing.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       COMMITTEE ON THE ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   Gorbachev Sees Havel and Agrees To Speed Withdrawal of Troops
abstract: LEAD: The Czechoslovak President, Vaclav Havel, and the Soviet President, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, agreed today on a faster timetable for the Soviet troop withdrawal from Czechoslovakia as well as on an end to cold war intelligence cooperation directed against Western nations.

headline: Market Place;   Aerospace Plays Develop in Japan
abstract: LEAD: MITSUBISHI HEAVY INDUSTRIES, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries, which are among the biggest foreign suppliers of aircraft components to the Boeing Company, ''are going to be the core of the Japanese aerospace industry,'' Dr. Edward Yardeni, economics director for Prudential-Bache

headline: Dow Falls 12.16 Points in Light Trading
abstract: LEAD: Stocks slumped in light trading yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 12.16 points, to 2,674.55, in the wake of a rise in bond yields.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Intel Target: Customers' Customers
abstract: LEAD: In an unusual advertising campaign, the Intel Corporation is bypassing its customers, the computer makers that use its microprocessors, to try to persuade computer users that they would be better off with its more powerful 386SX chip than its older 286 chip.

headline: Second Thoughts on Open Borders
abstract: LEAD: In West Germany as in East Germany, the euphoria of last year's grand German reunion has given way in the new year to some hard reassessments, tough politicking and even anxiety.

headline: Shandwick Ranked as Largest Firm
abstract: LEAD: Shandwick P.L.C. has become the largest public relations firm in the annual listing compiled by O'Dwyer's Directory of Public Relations Firms. Net fees collected by the London-based firm rose by 48 percent in 1989, to $180 million, enabling it to leap over Hill & Knowlton, whose fees totaled $164 million in 1989, and Burson-Marsteller, which collected $159.9 million.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Alsy Corp., Hicksville, L.I., a maker of portable lamps, named John M. Eikenberg chairman, president and chief executive. He succeeds Sy Stewart as chairman and Al Gindel as president. Mr. Stewart and Mr. Gindel retired.

headline: Revolt in Rumania: Days of Death and Hope - A special report:   How the Ceausescus Fell: Harnessing Popular Rage
abstract: LEAD: On Sunday, Dec. 17, President Nicolae Ceausescu summoned top party officials across the country and, on closed-circuit television, issued orders to kill.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Doubts and Fears of Rumania's Lingering Germans
abstract: LEAD: Jurgen Breitenstein, a 30-year-old mathematics teacher, decided a year ago to join the thousands of ethnic Germans who had left Rumania for West Germany in search of freedom and opportunity. Now, after the toppling of Nicolae Ceausescu, Mr. Breitenstein is not sure whether to follow through on his decision or stay and support the dwindling

headline: Noriega Was Close to Suicide, Aide Says
abstract: LEAD: Realizing that he had been cornered by the United States troops, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega originally decided to commit suicide rather than surrender or risk being ''shot by some G.I. Joe from Missouri,'' a close associate asserted today.

headline: Jerusalem Journal;   Who Needs Hebrew? More and More Palestinians
abstract: LEAD: Like thousands of new immigrants, foreign diplomats and exchange students before them, Nabil Mushara, Mohammed Lafi and Issam Kassis spend four hours a week studying Hebrew for beginners.

headline: Drexel Offers Explanation For Bonuses
abstract: LEAD: As many creditors reacted with dismay to the news that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had paid perhaps as much as $350 million in bonuses to executives in the weeks before it collapsed, the firm's chief executive, Frederick H. Joseph, made a telephone conference call yesterday to assure some creditors that the firm had done nothing untoward.

headline: Nova Scotia Prices 9 1/4% Debentures
abstract: LEAD: The Province of Nova Scotia yesterday priced $300 million in 9 1/4 percent debentures due in 2020 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: Another Challenge of the 90's: Managing Information Technology
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Kohl Arrives in U.S. for Talks on Europe's Future
abstract: LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany arrived here today for intensive talks with President Bush on the future of Europe and the accelerating pace of German unification.

headline: NEW TV CONTRACTS FOR N.F.L.'S GAMES TOTAL $3.6 BILLION
abstract: LEAD: The National Football League yesterday concluded a four-year television package for more than $3.6 billion, the most lucrative deal in television history.

headline: Drexel Is Said to Owe Millions to Foreign Governments
abstract: LEAD: Many foreign governments and Puerto Rico are owed hundreds of millions of dollars as a result of the collapse of the parent of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., people at the firm and lawyers said yesterday.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Unity Talks Begin Today
abstract: LEAD: The four World War II Allies and the two Germanys are to begin initial talks on Wednesday on returning the full sovereignty that the Germanys lost with the defeat of the Third Reich in 1945.

headline: 25 Are Hurt as Storm Floods Welsh Village
abstract: LEAD: Raging seas, whipped up by a storm that has killed 51 people in Europe, surged through a shattered sea wall and swamped homes in this coastal village today.

headline: Broker Case Is Settled
abstract: LEAD: Howard A. Rubin, a former head mortgage bond securities trader at Merrill Lynch Goverment Securities Inc., settled Federal disciplinary charges today that he had failed to keep accurate books and records about certain sales of mortgage-backed securities in April 1987.

headline: Hearst Picks New Chief For Trade Book Group
abstract: LEAD: The Hearst Trade Book Group, whose imprints include William Morrow & Company and Avon Books, named Howard Kaminsky its chief executive yesterday, effective April 1.

headline: Pulling Levers, No Strings Attached
abstract: LEAD: For Christoph Schoppe, a 40-year-old cattle rancher, two words summed up the feeling that he had today as he cast his ballot in East Germany's first free elections.

headline: An Apartment Hotel Opens on West 48th Street
abstract: LEAD: A 479-unit rental apartment house, which just opened in the theater district of Manhattan, offers prospective tenants the option of leasing an apartment fully furnished - with bed linens, dining and kitchen equipment in place - for an added monthly fee. The concept is an echo from the 1940's and 1950's, when dozens of rental buildings on the Upper West

headline: GORBACHEV ACCEPTS DEEP CUTS IN EUROPE IF FORCES ARE EQUAL; BAKER HINTS SHIFT ON GERMANY
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is prepared to accept President Bush's proposal for deeper troop cuts in Europe, but only if the plan leaves both countries with equal levels, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said this morning.

headline: Boeing in Move To Double Shares
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company is seeking shareholder approval to more than double the number of common shares outstanding to 600 million, but the company said in its proxy statement that it had no immediate plan to issue more stock. Boeing has 230.6 million common shares outstanding. Shareholders will vote on the proposal at the company's annual meeting on

headline: Business and Health;   Time to Confront Health-Care Issue
abstract: LEAD: ADMINISTRATION officials, members of Congress and executives who buy or provide health care are girding for a broad debate on the future of the troubled medical system.

headline: While Land Prices in Japan Soar, Officials Fight Back With Words
abstract: LEAD: Each of the last four years, the Government of Japan has declared a well-publicized war on this country's astronomical and still-rising land prices, the world's highest. But despite the strong oratory, the soldiers in the war never seem to leave their barracks.

headline: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   Small East Berlin Parties Seek to Postpone Unity
abstract: LEAD: In what many members view as a rear-guard campaign unlikely to halt rapid reunification of the Germanys, three political movements presented an election program today to preserve the independence of East Germany until it can negotiate unity on more equal terms.

headline: 6 in South Africa Die in Clash Of Black Transport Workers
abstract: LEAD: Six people were killed today as black transport workers fought each other with clubs, sticks and knives at a railway station here. The clash was one of the most violent incidents of recent South African labor unrest.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Centaur Partners L.P., an investment group, will not bid for National Intergroup Inc., Pittsburgh, an insurer, of which it owns 16.5 percent.

headline: 'Smart' Tires That Read the Road
abstract: LEAD: One way to boost a car's mileage is to increase tire pressure, which reduces rolling resistance. But increased tire pressure means a harsher ride on uneven surfaces. Cornering ability suffers as well.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Lithuanian Parliament Calls Soviet Annexation Unlawful
abstract: LEAD: The Lithuanian parliament has approved a resolution declaring Lithuania's 1940 annexation by the Soviet Union ''unlawful and invalid'' and seeking talks with Moscow on independence.

headline: Trump Group To Raze Hotel
abstract: LEAD: Donald J. Trump said Saturday that he and his partners will raze the Ambassador Hotel, where Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated in 1968, to build a large commercial and residential complex.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Air Products and Chemicals Inc., Allentown, Pa., a supplier of industrial gases, specialty chemicals and environmental and energy systems, announced the retirement of Leon C. Holt Jr., its vice chairman and chief administrative officer. The company named Donald T. Shire senior vice president for human resources and administration.

headline: For Macy, a Bitter Pill to Swallow
abstract: LEAD: Afflicted by continuing high debt and costly competitive pressures, R. H. Macy & Company has been carefully preparing its investors, lenders, employees and suppliers for another bitter pill to swallow on quarterly losses.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Pro Bono
abstract: LEAD: * Gearon Hoffman Conlon & Nye Advertising will handle advertising and public relations for the David M. Winfield Foundation.

headline: Market Place;   Little Interest In Stock Baskets
abstract: LEAD: FRIDAY was another typical day of trading in the New York Stock Exchange's so-called basket product: nobody bought one, and nobody sold one.

headline: CABINET IS OUSTED IN ISRAELI DISPUTE OVER PEACE TALKS
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Parliament dissolved the Government today over Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's refusal to accept terms for starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks that were suggested by the United States.

headline: A New Star For Studios Is Mexico
abstract: LEAD: Hollywood's big names and big studios are increasingly being drawn to Mexico to make feature films and television movies.

headline: Trade Deficit Shrank in '89
abstract: LEAD: The United States trade deficit increased slightly in the fourth quarter of 1989 but narrowed to $113.2 billion for all of last year, its lowest level since 1984, the Government reported today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Air Wis Services Inc., Appleton, Wis., said it would buy Aspen Airlines. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Manville Venture
abstract: LEAD: Manville International B.V. and the Belgian-based Recticel have formed a partnership to make and market foam insulation products in Europe. Manville International is a subsidiary of the Denver-based Manville Corporation. Recticel is a subsidiary of the Societe Generale de Belgique, which is based in Brussels.

headline: China Maker Promotes Grandson of Founder
abstract: LEAD: Rosenthal A.G., the noted West German maker of fine china, is seeking to expand its presence in the United States and it has put a grandson of the company's founder in charge of its American operations.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Funeral;   Simple 'Last Homage' to One Who Stood Against Ceausescu
abstract: LEAD: Rumania's new leaders paid last respects today to Secretary of State Corneliu Bogdan, the first of their number to die since they took power two weeks ago.

headline: Madrid Offers Leniency for a Basque Truce
abstract: LEAD: The shooting of a retired navy officer in the northern city of San Sebastian was the latest act of violence in a week that began with an offer from Justice Minister Jose Luis Corcuera to the Basque separatist group E.T.A. to exchange generous treatment for a six-month truce.

headline: FREE-TRADE TALKS WITH U.S. SET OFF DEBATE IN MEXICO
abstract: LEAD: In a break with the policy of economic nationalism that has prevailed here since the Mexican Revolution of 1910, President Carlos Salinas de Gortari has agreed to consider negotiations for a free-trade agreement with the United States.

headline: Fed Changes Foreign-Margin Rule
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board said last week that it would allow large brokerages to establish margin accounts on foreign securities. Margin accounts allow customers to purchase securities on credit and borrow against securities.

headline: Johannesburg Journal;   Glossy Magazine with a Difference: It's for Blacks
abstract: LEAD: Between the glossy advertisements for Japanese cars, Scotch whisky, British knitwear, French-style lingerie, sparkling wines and designer kitchens, an editorial message of black pride is being pitched to a prospering minority among South Africa's impoverished black majority.

headline: World Trade Grew in 1989
abstract: LEAD: International trade volume could slow slightly this year, with inflation and rising interest rates in industrialized nations hampering expansion, the world's main trade forum reported today.

headline: British Jobless Rate Dips
abstract: LEAD: Britain's unemployment rate fell to 5.6 percent in February from 5.7 percent in the previous month, the Government reported this week. The jobless rate stood at 6.8 percent a year ago, the Department of Employment said. Without seasonal adjustment, the number of unemployed was 1.676 million in February, compared with a revised 1.687 million in January and 2.018 million in February 1989.

headline: In Canada, Two Vie to Lead the Liberal Party
abstract: LEAD: Hoping to reinvigorate Canada's main opposition group after six years in the political wilderness, one of the country's most seasoned politicians is squaring off against a former Montreal shipping executive for the leadership of the Liberal Party.

headline: Michigan Offers Tax-Free Bonds
abstract: LEAD: The Michigan Municipal Bond Authority is tentatively offering $74 million in tax-exempt local government loan program revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.25 percent for a long-term bond due in 2009.

headline: The U.S. and Panama: The Press;   Paper Noriega Crushed Is Reborn as a Watchdog
abstract: LEAD: Guillermo Sanchez Borbon had a bit of a fright when he returned this week to his newspaper office, which had been closed for 23 months. There were four heavily armed soldiers outside the front door.

headline: Treasury Prices Fall on Jobs Report
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities tumbled yesterday after the Government reported an unexpectedly large rise in civilian employment in February.

headline: VOICE OF MILITANTS RISING IN KASHMIR
abstract: LEAD: Young pro-independence militants are exercising increasing influence in the Vale of Kashmir, cutting the support for traditional pro-Indian groups and leaving mainstream politicians isolated and silent.

headline: Adweek Units to Shut
abstract: LEAD: The advertising trade magazine Adweek is ending publication of Ad Day, its daily news update, and Winners, its bi-monthly creative magazine. Ad Day, which is two years old, is closing immediately. The April-May issue of Winners will be its last. Adweek said it made the moves to devote its resources to its core weeklies, Adweek and Adweek's Marketing Week.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Marine Transport Lines Inc., Secaucus, N.J., a bulk shipping company, announced the resignation of Dirk Langeveld, its executive vice president and chief operating officer.

headline: 12 Die in Raid in Mozambique
abstract: LEAD: Rebels attacked a truck belonging to the Government's relief agency, killing the driver and 11 people riding in the back, a Government-run newspaper reported today.

headline: Some Lincoln Investors Escape Loss in Collapse
abstract: LEAD: The collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association produced an array of victims, from retired California investors who bought unsecured bonds to American taxpayers. But it also turns out that not all the investors in the failed institution were losers.

headline: Neiman Marcus
abstract: LEAD: The Neiman Marcus Group Inc. said it had long-term plans to open a 140,000-square-foot Neiman Marcus store at the Long Island Galleria, a shopping mall being developed in Westbury, L.I., by Westfield Inc. The store will be the Dallas-based retailer's second in the New York area and 24th location in the nation.

headline: I.M.F. Is Urged to Sell Gold as Hedge Against Bad Loans
abstract: LEAD: The United States has proposed that the International Monetary Fund sell about three million ounces of gold, which at current market prices could raise more than $1 billion, to buttress the global lending agency against the growing problem of delinquent payments by its members.

headline: Hungary Halts Emigre Flights After Muslim Threat
abstract: LEAD: The Hungarian airline has suspended flights carrying Soviet emigrants to Israel, the official press agency said today. The action came six days after a militant Muslim group in Lebanon threatened to attack airlines and airports that help transport the new wave of Jewish settlers.

headline: Georgia Gulf Revises Recapitalization Plan
abstract: LEAD: ATLANTA, March 16 (Reuters) -

headline: Upheaval in the East: Diplomacy;   Baker Meets in Moscow On Arms and Afghans
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d opened talks today with the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, by setting out a variety of arms control initiatives, as well as a new American proposal for solving the Afghan conflict.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Western Europe;   On Germany, Not All Is Joy
abstract: LEAD: With the reunification of Germany now accepted as inevitable in Western Europe, governments from Brussels to Rome are bracing for the emergence of a single German nation rich and powerful enough to dominate European affairs.

headline: President of Simplesse Enjoys Taste of Success
abstract: LEAD: David L. Morley's boss envies his job. The chairman of the Nutrasweet Company, Robert B. Shapiro, regularly tells Mr. Morley that he has one of the most exciting corporate jobs in the country.

headline: Gold Makes Quick Rebound From Wednesday's Plunge
abstract: LEAD: Gold prices roared back today after falling sharply on Wednesday when it was reported that the Treasury had asked the International Monetary Fund to sell at least a million ounces of gold to offset late payments by 11 countries.

abstract: LEAD: IN a blow to one British-owned American advertising agency and a boost to another, the Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday withdrew its $60 million account from Backer, Spielvogel, Bates and awarded it to Lowe Marschalk.

abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki of Poland said today that a ''peace treaty'' securing his country's postwar western border should precede German reunification and that Soviet troops should stay in Poland as insurance.

abstract: LEAD: As President Bush's Latin American drug summit meeting approaches, drug traffickers have released five kidnapping victims - including the son of President Virgilio Barco Vargas's chief of staff - stopped their nightly bombings and surrendered a bus packed with 2,000 pounds of dynamite as part of their offer to quit the cocaine business.

headline: Rights Protesters Attacked in Nepal
abstract: LEAD: A Nepalese democracy movement, modeling itself on the campaigns for change that have shaken or toppled governments from Beijing to Bucharest, was born here over the weekend in a hail of broken bricks and stones.

headline: Bush, Citing Security Law, Voids Sale of Aviation Concern to China
abstract: LEAD: President Bush today nullified the sale of an American company that manufactures airplane parts to a military-related agency of the Chinese Government. In doing so, he resorted for the first time to a law that allows him to bar some foreign investments on national-security grounds.

headline: Treasury Prices Ease in Slow Day
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds eased in very slow trading yesterday, as dealers took some profits after Wednesday's strong rally and awaited the release of new economic statistics.

headline: The Executive Life;  Humiliating Times For a Boss Who Smokes
abstract: LEAD: In business corridors, smoking has become the great new equalizer, at least in the minds of some chief executives who are unable to quit. Cigarettes are no longer a symbol of strength, machismo and style, and smoky rooms, no longer synonymous with serious business. Executives who smoke these days tend to feel weak, embarrassed and ashamed.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Alaska Air Group Inc., Seattle, an airline holding company, said that under its ''Dutch auction'' tender offer, it would buy three million shares of common stock at $22.875 a share.

headline: Demand for Oil Off 6.7% in U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Demand for oil dropped 6.7 percent in February, compared with the month a year earlier, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday. But production fell even faster, so imports rose, according to the report.

headline: Banque Indosuez Adds Risk-Management Post
abstract: LEAD: Richard Sandor, a self-styled financial ''tinkerer'' who has created some of the futures market's most familiar interest-rate products, has been hired to organize a new risk-management unit for Banque Indosuez, the French merchant bank.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Delay Appears Likely In Rumanian Election
abstract: LEAD: Pressure mounted today from new and revived political parties, including the Liberals and the National Peasants Party, to postpone elections beyond the April date set by the provisional Government. Count Otto von Lambsdorff, head of West Germany's Free Democratic Party, said at a news conference here that in talks held with leaders of the new

headline: Treasury Prices Down Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply in light trading yesterday as dealers, facing losses from a weakening market, chose to liquidate positions.

headline: U.S. Economy Stayed In Slump in December
abstract: LEAD: The economy remained in a slump in December, although production levels rose and exports expanded, the nation's purchasing managers said in a monthly report.

headline: British Gas Sets Big Canadian Bid
abstract: LEAD: In an attempt to build its Canadian gas business, British Gas P.L.C. bid $1.1 billion (Canadian) today for the Consumers Gas Company of Canada.

headline: Peasant Militia in Peru Kills 8 Leftist Rebels
abstract: LEAD: Peasants used machetes, sticks and slingshots to kill eight leftist guerrillas in the latest of a series of clashes betwen ragtag rural militias and rebels in which at least 20 people have died this week, the police said today.

headline: Peronist Workers Rebel in Argentina
abstract: LEAD: The growing conflict between President Carlos Saul Menem and those who elected him - the rank and file of the Peronist Party - broke out today into a one-day strike by state workers and a large march on the Congress.

headline: Your Money;   Errors That Lead To an I.R.S. Audit
abstract: LEAD: Taxpayers can minimize the likelihood of an audit by the Internal Revenue Service if they avoid certain common errors and are alert to areas the I.R.S. considers prone to abuse.

headline: Chronicling Politics as An Industry
abstract: LEAD: HOLLYWOOD has Daily Variety to report on the business and politics of entertainment. Now, several Washington publishing professionals want the nation's capital to have a daily newspaper to chronicle the business and entertainment side of politics.

headline: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   Berlin Communists Lose a Leading Reformer
abstract: LEAD: A leading East German reformer was quoted today as saying he would abandon the embattled Communist Party, and the President suggested that pro-democracy forces help run the Government until May elections.

headline: NICARAGUA IS CALM IN HEAVY TURNOUT FOR CRITICAL VOTE
abstract: LEAD: Under intense international scrutiny, this war-battered country voted today in the first free and broadly contested elections in its history. There were few reports of violence and strong signs of an overwhelming voter turnout.

abstract: LEAD: Bowing to demands of thousands of irate demonstrators, leaders of Rumania's governing Council of National Salvation agreed tonight to outlaw the Communist Party and to hold a national referendum on restoring the death penalty.

headline: Bush Seeks Japan Shift On Imports
abstract: LEAD: When leaders of the two biggest economic powers meet during the weekend in Palm Springs, Calif., the United States will offer a closer global economic partnership but insist that Japan slash import barriers, Administration officials said today.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Honecker, in Disgrace and in Poor Health, Is Arrested as He Leaves a Berlin Hospital
abstract: LEAD: East Germany's relentless pursuit of its former hard-line leaders finally reached Erich Honecker today. The ousted Communist Party chief was released from the hospital and immediately arrested.

headline: Bank in Northeast Sells Leasing Unit

The bank sold the United States portion of McCullagh Leasing to GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company.

headline: Northrop Sale Of Properties
abstract: LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell two office buildings, one of which houses its corporate headquarters, and another 53-acre site. The price of the sales is more than $250 million.

abstract: LEAD: The Hotel Investors Corporation and Hotel Investors Trust, a hotel management company and real estate investment trust whose shares are paired for trading, said they had retained Salomon Brothers Inc. to consider selling their two Las Vegas, Nev., casinos: the Bourbon Street Hotel and Casino and the King 8 Hotel and Gambling Hall.

headline: Nicaraguans Woo Youthful Voters
abstract: LEAD: In the middle of an intense campaign for national elections here, the Sandinista National Liberation Front paused recently to celebrate young love.

headline: LITHUANIANS VOTE STRONGLY FOR INDEPENDENCE BACKERS; SOVIET CROWDS ASK CHANGE
abstract: LEAD: The Communist establishment suffered a double blow today as protesters across the country thronged the streets in a defiant call for a share of power while one republic, Lithuania, voted to end Communist rule.

headline: Most of Xerox's Suit Against Apple Barred
abstract: SAN FRANCISCO, March 23 - A Federal judge today dismissed almost all the closely watched copyright lawsuit filed by the Xerox Corporation against Apple Computer Inc.   In what appears to be a sweeping victory for Apple, Judge Vaughn R. Walker of the Federal District Court in San Francisco threw out five of the six counts in Xerox's lawsuit, saying, in essence, that Xerox's complaints were inappropriate for a variety of legal reasons.   Xerox sued Apple in December, seeking more than $150 million in damages. It asserted that the screen display of Apple's Macintosh computer unlawfully used copyrighted technology that Xerox had developed and incorporated in a computer called the Star, which was introduced in 1981, three years before the Macintosh.   "We welcome the ruling in every way," said a jubilant Jack E. Brown of Brown & Bain, the law firm representing Apple, which had filed a motion to have the case dismissed. Even if Xerox prevails on the one count it can still pursue, it cannot win much because the judge threw out all the counts seeking damages, attorneys involved in the case said.   A Xerox spokesman said the company planned to appeal. "The ruling does not mean Apple hasn't taken substantial portions of the Star and claimed them as their own," a statement issued by Xerox said. "The court merely held, we believe erroneously, that Xerox does not have standing to present facts in support of our contention."   The Xerox lawsuit is one of many copyright suits that are splitting the computer software industry. A major issue is the right to the screen displays known as graphical user interfaces - a dashboard of sorts by which a user controls the computer.   A key appeal of the Macintosh is its ease of use, thanks in part to a display that allows users to perform tasks by pointing at symbols on the screen and to divide the screen into separate "windows," each containing a different document or program. Now, virtually all computer companies are adopting similar screen displays.   No one disputes that many of the ideas behind such interfaces were born at the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center in the 1970's, although the Star was not a marketing success. But the question of how similar one interface has to be to another to constitute copyright infringement remains unanswered.

headline: Treasury Bond Prices Fall Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Treasury bond prices tumbled and yields climbed yesterday, largely because of heavy overnight selling of domestic and United States securities by Japanese and European institutions.

headline: A Savings and Loan Is Seized in Florida; 2 Others Progressing
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Government seized Florida's largest savings and loan association yesterday and said the institution was the victim of a flamboyant and spendthrift chairman. But in Texas and California, two other big savings institutions made progress toward recovery, thanks to Federal subsidies.

abstract: LEAD: A secret South African military unit suspected of killing opponents of apartheid planned at one time to replace the heart pills of Nelson Mandela's lawyer with tablets designed to induce a heart attack, judicial investigators were told today.

abstract: LEAD: An attempt to assassinate Lebanon's chief of military police at a mountain resort near here was foiled today, but four soldiers and a civilian were killed.

abstract: LEAD: The Mentor Graphics Corporation of Beaverton, Ore., said today that it would acquire the Silicon Compiler Systems Corporation for about $110 million in newly issued Mentor shares.

headline: MCI's Net Off 11.5%
abstract: LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation, the long-distance telephone company, reported disappointing fourth-quarter earnings today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    COMPANIES       The F.C.C. proposed giving A.T.&T. a freer hand in cutting or raising rates and offering additional services for large business customers. The move was another step toward deregulating the long-distance market. [Page D1.]      Campeau defaulted on $5.2 million in interest payments to two lenders, risking the loss of another chunk of its empire.

headline: Muslim Separatists Are Said To Raid 6 Philippine Villages
abstract: LEAD: About 1,000 Muslim rebels attacked six predominantly Christian villages today, killing at least one person and causing thousands of residents to flee, the military said.

headline: Busch Adds Officers In Broad Realignment
abstract: LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies yesterday announced a management realignment that included an expansion of corporate personnel and a new president for its Anheuser-Busch Inc. beer subsidiary.

headline: Threats to Mandela Worry Pretoria
abstract: LEAD: The South African Government is concerned about the safety of Nelson Mandela after he is released from prison, its Law and Order Minister, Adriaan Vlok, said today.

headline: Police Fired on Crowd, Jesse Jackson Asserts
abstract: LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that the South African Police had fired on a crowd of blacks gathered to welcome him in a black shantytown outside Cape Town. But a police statement said that the shots had been had fired by a black civilian fighting a rival black group.

headline: EXILED OPPOSITION TO SEND A PANEL TO MEET DE KLERK
abstract: LEAD: The governing body of the African National Congress said today that it would send a delegation to South Africa ''as soon as possible'' to meet with President F. W. de Klerk in an attempt to remove obstacles to opening talks with Pretoria.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   11.00        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   6.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.25   8.18   9.31        3-MO. headline: Market Place;   Xtra to Sell Itself And Avoid Proxy
abstract: LEAD: RATHER than risk their removal in a bitter proxy vote, the top managers and directors of the Xtra Corporation said yesterday that they would put the company up for sale and would cancel the annual shareholders meeting originally scheduled for tomorrow. If the company is sold, the managers and board members are likely to reap a tidy profit themselves.

headline: A Eurotunnel Director Quits
abstract: LEAD: Eurotunnel P.L.C., the British-French consortium building a rail tunnel under the English Channel, said on Thursday that Tony Ridley had resigned as a director.

headline: Survey Finds 2 in 3 Poles Opposed to German Unity
abstract: LEAD: Roughly two out of three Poles are opposed to the reunification of Germany, but a majority of Russians and Hungarians feel positively about the idea, according to the results of a poll of political views in eight European countries published here today.

headline: U.S. Forgives Portion Of Kenya's Loan Debt
abstract: LEAD: The United States today formally agreed to forgive all economic-assistance loans to Kenya, as part of an effort to give economic relief to Africa, including some of the continent's poorest countries.

headline: Late Drop Sends Dow Down 28.37, to 2,766
abstract: LEAD: Stocks ended sharply lower yesterday as trading accelerated near the close of the session. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 28.37 points, to 2,766.

headline: Nearly 2 Years Later, Pennzoil Fills Position
abstract: LEAD: The Pennzoil Company yesterday named James L. Pate its chief operating officer, filling a vacant post in its top management.

headline: Harsco Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Harsco Corporation said it had received notice by telephone that the Carlyle Group expects to notify the Securities and Exchange Commission next week that it holds at least 5 percent of Harsco's stock. No further details were given. Harsco is a diversified industrial company with 13 divisions.

headline: Mutual Funds;   Digging Out After Drexel
abstract: LEAD: When the crisis at Drexel Burnham Lambert hit the news last Monday, Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund company, geared up for Tuesday's flood of telephone calls.

headline: Turnover in Nicaragua;   NICARAGUAN RIVALS FOCUS ON CONTRAS IN ELECTION'S WAKE
abstract: LEAD: Three days after his Government was routed in national elections, President Daniel Ortega Saavedra today declared an immediate cease-fire with the American-supported contras.

headline: Tricking a Molecule to Create a Coating
abstract: LEAD: Fooling Mother Nature is helping a New Jersey company develop coatings that prevent corrosion and adhere more tightly to solid surfaces than other forms of plastics.

headline: More Protests Of Pantheon Resignation
abstract: LEAD: The remaining senior editor at Pantheon Books resigned yesterday, following the departures of the four other senior editors in protest over the removal of Andre Schiffrin as managing director.

headline: Professor at Harvard To Head Benckiser Unit
abstract: LEAD: ''This is a good chance to practice what I preach,'' said Thomas V. Bonoma, a Harvard Business School profesor who has written 17 books on marketing. Mr. Bonoma has been named president of Benckiser Consumer Products Inc., the maker of Electrasol dishwasher detergent and other household brands.

headline: New Notions On Old Crisis In Argentina
abstract: LEAD: Like many of his countrymen, one of Argentina's leading industrialists was talking the other day about what is wrong with his country and what ought to be done about it.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   France Urges West Germany to Speed Unification
abstract: LEAD: Worried that West Germany is wavering in its commitment to the European Community, France urged it today to absorb East Germany as rapidly as possible and again focus attention on European integration.

headline: Ex-Boesky Partners Get $248 Million Settlement
abstract: LEAD: A group of limited partners of Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrager who pleaded guilty to securities fraud, received a $248 million payment yesterday, in the culmination of a complex settlement reached in recent months among Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the partners, Mr. Boesky and other parties.

headline: Two West Germans Drown As Rains Soak Black Forest
abstract: LEAD: At least two people drowned today and 50 were forced to leave their homes after heavy rain and snow caused flooding in the southwestern state of Baden-Wurttemburg, the police said.

headline: Real Estate;   Bridge-Vault Development Is Stalled
abstract: LEAD: THE concept seems efficient and appealing for crowded Manhattan: Use the gigantic empty vaults beneath the Brooklyn and Queensboro bridges as commercial, retail and even residential space to help ease the demand for development sites.

headline: In Slovenia, Link to Rest of Nation Weakens
abstract: LEAD: Less than a month ago, the Communists of Slovenia pulled out of a national party congress and became a loose thread that is now unraveling Communist cohesion across the country. A few days ago they shocked their comrades further by announcing they were no longer Communists.

headline: FORUM;  Unions Should Stick to the Basics
abstract: LEAD: The corporate landscape of the 1980's has presented union leaders with major challenges. Unions have responded variously. Some have stuck with essentially traditional positions as they struggle to secure their members' rights and interests. Other labor organizations have ventured into new areas, daring even to become ''players'' in the financial markets.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  West Coast Executive Promoted by Drexel
abstract: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that Allan Sher, who oversees the investment firm's West Coast operations, had been promoted to vice chairman.

headline: Mobil Ends Environmental Claim
abstract: LEAD: The Mobil Corporation said yesterday that it would remove the word ''degradable'' from boxes of its Hefty plastic trash bags. In doing so, it is apparently bowing to demands from environmental groups and the threat of legal action by the attorneys general of eight states.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.       Monday       None       Tuesday       None       Wednesday       Automobile Sales    Mid-Jan.       Thursday       None       Friday       Durable Goods    Dec.       G.N.P.    4th Qtr.

headline: Bass Group Makes an Offer For St. Petersburg Times
abstract: LEAD: A group that includes Robert M. Bass, the Texas financier, has offered $270 million to acquire control of The St. Petersburg Times in Florida.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: In Pretoria: Last Throes of Marxism?
abstract: LEAD: The winds of change battering Marxism around the world have hit the South African Communist Party, which has endured by making itself synonymous in many blacks' minds with the struggle of the majority to free itself of domination by the nation's white minority.

headline: 2 Large Dutch Banks Begin Merger Talks
abstract: LEAD: The two largest commercial banks in the Netherlands have begun merger talks aimed at creating the world's 20th-largest bank, officials of the two companies announced today.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   East German Communists End Campaign on Upswing
abstract: LEAD: The former Communist Party, now called the Party of Democratic Socialism, wound up its campaign tonight for Sunday's first free parliamentary elections in East Germany with the largest and most enthusiastic rallies the capital has seen.

headline: Brokerage Settlement Made
abstract: LEAD: Nearly two and a half years after the stock market collapse of 1987, creditors of a failed brokerage firm have reached a settlement with former options investors who lost $12.4 million that day.

headline: Arab Students in West Bank Protest Israel's School Ban
abstract: LEAD: Palestinian students protesting Israel's two-year shutdown of their universities held sit-ins today in the occupied West Bank and one rally ended in clashes with troops.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Gorbachev and the Party: 5 Years of Breathless Change
abstract: LEAD:    March 1985: Mikhail S. Gorbachev is named to succeed Konstantin U. Chernenko as Soviet leader and outlines an urgent agenda to improve the economy. At 54, he is the youngest man to take charge of the Soviet Union since Stalin, who was 45.       April 1985: Presiding over the first full session of the Central Committee since the one that brought him to power, Gorbachev elevates three new members to the Politburo: Viktor M.

headline: Harvard Administrator to Head Stanford Business School
abstract: LEAD: A. Michael Spence, a renowned economist and the second-highest administrator at Harvard University, today was named the next dean of the Stanford University Graduate School of Business.

headline: India, Stymied, Pulls Last Troops From Sri Lanka
abstract: LEAD: India withdrew the last of its troops from Sri Lanka today, ending an ill-fated three-year involvement in the island's ethnic strife.

headline: Mandela Says He'll Lead Panel In April Session With de Klerk
abstract: LEAD: Nelson Mandela returned home today and said he would lead the African National Congress delegation that has been invited to meet President F. W. de Klerk on April 11.

headline: The Fed Intervenes to Slow Dollar's Rise Against Yen
abstract: LEAD: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, forcing the Federal Reserve to intervene by selling dollars several times to stem its rally against the Japanese yen.

headline: Bank Yields Are Mostly Up in Week
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly up for the week that ended yesterday.

headline: Getting Burned By the Frying Pan
abstract: LEAD: Kentucky Fried Chicken's middle name is beginning to spell trouble.

headline: Mass Graves in East Germany
abstract: LEAD: An East German newspaper today reported the discovery of mass graves of thousands of people, including civilians, who died at a former Soviet prison camp set up after World War II.

headline: Four U.S. Congressmen Barred From Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has denied permission to four United States Congressmen who want to travel to Lithuania for this weekend's elections in the Soviet Baltic republic, the legislators said today.

headline: Rite Aid Trial Scheduled
abstract: LEAD: Charges that the Rite Aid Corporation and its president bribed a member of the Ohio Board of Pharmacy will be heard in a trial set to begin April 16, officials of Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court have said. Judge Lillian J. Greene had previously set a tentative trial date of Jan. 15. Rite Aid and its president, Martin Grass, have been charged with bribing Melvin L.

headline: Senior Note Issue Priced by Kroger
abstract: LEAD: The Kroger Company, the large Cincinnati-based retail food company, yesterday priced $250 million in senior notes due in 1998 through Goldman, Sachs & Company. Underwriters offered the notes at par, to yield 11 1/8 percent, with interest on the securities payable March 15 and Sept. 15 annually, beginning this

headline: A Ford Moves Up at Ford Motor
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company announced a series of executive changes today that included an important promotion for William Clay Ford Jr., improving his chances of one day running the company that his great-grandfather founded 87 years ago.

headline: Business Digest
abstract: LEAD:       Companies

headline: Argentines Take to the Streets Against Inept Police
abstract: LEAD: In a notable shift from the fear Argentines felt of the police during the military Government just a decade ago, residents of several provincial towns have recently risen up in mass protest and accused their local police of corruption and laziness.

headline: F.D.I.C. Suit In Suits Unit Failure
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said yesterday that it had sued Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and two former executives of a Texas savings and loan association, accusing them of fraud in a complex scheme to help finance a corporate takeover.

headline: BUSH IS SET BACK BY HOUSE OVERRIDE OF VETO ON CHINA
abstract: LEAD: Handing President Bush a major defeat, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly reaffirmed legislation protecting Chinese students in the United States from deportation. The Senate is expected to vote on Thursday, and the outcome is too close to predict.

headline: Savings in Japan Rise
abstract: LEAD: Personal savings in Japan grew 11.2 percent in 1989, reaching a total of 700.08 trillion yen ($4.6 trillion) at the end of December, the Bank of Japan said on Tuesday. It was the largest yearly increase since 1981, the report said. Savings rose because of deregulation of interest rates on time deposits as well as larger company bonuses last year as Japan's economy boomed, the bank said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Yellow Pages Space
abstract: LEAD: The Yellow Pages Publishers Association said it would commit $62 million in ad space in its directories to the anti-drug campaign of the Partnership for a Drug-Free America.

headline: Market Place;   Allure of Spain's Phone Company
abstract: LEAD: THE national telephone monopoly of Spain, Telefonica de Espana S.A., is most popular with investors and stock analysts who use its services least.

headline: U.S. Acknowledges Arrest of Agent
abstract: LEAD: United States officials confirmed today that the Soviet Union had arrested an American agent working deep within the Soviet bureaucracy, and expressed mild surprise that the Russians had made public his capture.

headline: Costs of Oil War Cited
abstract: LEAD: An oil research specialist was quoted this week as saying that OPEC states lost more than $200 billion in revenue because of their price war in the mid-1980's. Quoted in a United Arab Emirates oil journal, Nicolas Sarkis, head of the Paris-based Arab Center for Oil Studies, said the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries could have avoided the oil price collapse if they had not started undercutting each other.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Moves by Carnation
abstract: LEAD: Citing a desire to bring its roster of advertising agencies into line with those of its corporate parent, Nestle S.A., the Carnation Company has taken three accounts, worth $12 million to $15 million in billings, from Ogilvy & Mather in Los Angeles. Advertising for Carnation's Contadina Fresh refrigerated pasta and sauces, and for its infant nutritional products, will go to McCann-Erickson in Los Angeles.

headline: Hungarian Security Chief Said to Have Resigned
abstract: LEAD: The chief of state security has resigned after allegations that his agency illegally monitored opposition activities, the Hungarian press agency said today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * British Airways P.L.C., London, has introduced Economy Select, an airline class that is more expensive than economy class but below first class and business class.

headline: A Different Drummer in Japan
abstract: LEAD: So often in Japanese business life, success comes to those who avoid risks and follow the well-trodden paths. Then there are people like Kazuo Wada, chairman of the Yaohan Department Store Company, who personifies another Japanese type: the devoted renegade.

headline: Ford Settles A Mexican Walkout
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had resolved some of its labor problems in Mexico by reaching a tentative contract agreement with workers at an engine plant in Chihuahua.

headline: Market Place;   Unusual Setbacks For Nordstrom
abstract: LEAD: WHILE most of the 1980's were years of soaring fame and profits for Nordstrom Inc., the specialty-apparel retailer based in Seattle suffered some unusual setbacks as the decade came to a close.

headline: Next Selling Retail Unit
abstract: LEAD: Next P.L.C., a British retailer, agreed today to sell its Biba chain of women's fashion shops to the Hapeni Portfolio Company for $:47.6 million, or about $76 million. Biba operates a chain of 60 fashion shops in the North Rhine-Westphalia region of West Germany.

headline: Parcel Bomb Wounds Leading Spanish Judge
abstract: LEAD: A parcel bomb severely wounded the president of Madrid's High Court today, the police said.

headline: German Car Makers Defend Status
abstract: LEAD: When the Toyota Motor Corporation and the Nissan Motor Company began shaping plans to make luxury cars, one of the first things they did was to buy several Mercedes-Benz and BMW autos and meticulously dissect them.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   WORLD VOTE URGED BY SHEVARDNADZE ON GERMAN UNITY
abstract: LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, expressing concern over ''the revival of sinister shadows of the past'' associated with German unification, proposed today that the issue be put to an international referendum.

headline: Census Bureau Tries New Promotional Tack
abstract: LEAD: The Census Bureau's decennial advertising campaign, to be presented today by Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher, differs from previous campaigns in its attempt to include more members of minority groups in its count.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Citizens and Southern Corp., Atlanta and Sovran Financial Corp., Norfolk, Va., both bank holding companies, said their shareholders had approved the combination of the two businesses under a new holding company, Avantor Financial Corp.

headline: 40 at Random House Critical of Pantheon
abstract: LEAD: Forty Random House editors and publishers issued a statement yesterday supporting Pantheon's ''high editorial standards'' but faulting Pantheon as not having practiced fiscal responsibility. ''There is no reason,'' the statement added, ''why Pantheon shouldn't live by the same fiscal rules as the rest of us at Random House and throughout the industry.

headline: Campbell Soup's New Chief Offers Strategy for Growth
abstract: LEAD: In an energetic first day in office, David W. Johnson, the Campbell Soup Company's new president and chief executive, outlined his plans to revitalize the big food company, pledging to maintain its independence and to increase profits by curbing costs and possibly pruning operations.

headline: Controlling The Damage;   Regulators Move Fast To Reassure Markets
abstract: LEAD: The speed with which Federal regulators responded to financial problems at Drexel Burnham Lambert's parent illustrates their awareness of how quickly problems at this particular Wall Street firm could spread through the complex structure of today's financial markets.

headline: 2 PARTIES IN SEOUL AGREE TO A MERGER WITH RULING GROUP
abstract: LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo's party and two opposition parties announced today that they would merge into a conservative majority party to break a two-year political deadlock in Parliament.

headline: Even as U.S. Fights for Entry, Some Companies Quit Japan
abstract: LEAD: For nearly two decades Avon Products Inc. was one of America's biggest success stories here, a company that spent years tailoring its products for Japanese women and learning how to outsmart a distribution system that has defeated many foreign companies. It paid off: Last year Avon reaped a quarter of its corporate profits in

headline: SEOUL UNCOVERS A BORDER TUNNEL
abstract: LEAD: After grinding through more than 1,000 feet of granite, engineers today reached a tunnel that military officials said had been built by North Korea to stage a surprise invasion of the South.

headline: Fannie Mae Buying Sears Mortgages
abstract: LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, announced yesterday that it had agreed to purchase over the next year about $2 billion in home mortgages orginated by the Sears Mortgage Corporation, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

headline: How Shamir at Home Caused Storm Abroad
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet official announced in Tunis this weekend that the Soviet Union would not allow direct flights from Moscow to Tel Aviv for Soviet immigrants to Israel, despite a commercial agreement between the two nations to begin the flights in January.

headline: A Grieving Israel Pushes Politics Aside
abstract: LEAD: Stunned Israelis postponed politics, canceled trips to Egypt and lamented what seemed to be a further blow to regional peace today as the nation recovered its dead and wounded from the terrorist attack on a tour bus near Cairo on Sunday night.

headline: 81 Nations Seeking More Food Aid for Africa
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the representatives of more than 80 other countries appealed today for additional donations of food and money for Ethiopia, Angola, Mozambique and the Sudan. They called existing pledges inadequate and said that without further aid hundreds of thousands of people could die of starvation this year.

headline: Money Fund Assets Fall
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $955.0 million, to $365.04 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds increased by $625.7 million, to $88.23 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were down $112.1 million, to $119.87 billion.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          Companies

headline: Lower-Income Housing;   New Jersey Town Sees 2 Projects Straining Services
abstract: LEAD: Seven years after the New Jersey Supreme Court mandated affordable housing for the area, the township of Branchburg in Somerset County is finding that the new homes it authorized in the wake of the decision are causing a growth spurt that is straining services.

headline: Eastern Is Pressed On Its Debt
abstract: LEAD: After almost a year of supporting Frank Lorenzo's plans to rebuild Eastern Airlines, the carrier's unsecured creditors are apparently running low on patience. People close to the creditors' committee said yesterday that it was considering actions that could lead to the liquidation of the airline unless Mr.

headline: Bondholders Balk at Southland's 'Junk Bond' Plan
abstract: LEAD: Bondholders and analysts said yesterday that the Southland Corporation's plan to sell control to a Japanese company and then exchange Southland ''junk bonds'' for new bonds and stock with much lower face value would probably be rejected by creditors as inadequate.

headline: East Berlin Faults Opposition on Raid
abstract: LEAD: The East German police asserted today that protesters who raided State Security headquarters on Monday had caused millions of dollars in damage, and they said the opposition group New Forum was partly to blame for the incident.

headline: Continental Air and Denver Sign Lease on New Airport
abstract: LEAD: Ending a yearlong stalemate, Continental Airlines said yesterday that it had signed an agreement with Denver officials to lease space at the city's new $2.3 billion airport.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Russian 'Patriots' Scorn Gorbachev and the Left
abstract: LEAD: The devout of the Russian hard-liners gathered in a sports arena here tonight to condemn President Mikhail S. Gorbachev for his attempts to liberalize and Westernize Soviet society, and to celebrate being Russian nationalists when many consider such attitudes chauvinist.

headline: MONGOLS PROTEST PARTY'S MONOPOLY
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of Mongolians stirred up by the Soviet Communist Party's decision to give up its monopoly on power demanded today that their country's Communists do the same, a Mongolian official said.

headline: UAL Moves Up Meetings on Buyout
abstract: LEAD: The UAL Corporation said today that it was accelerating talks with its nonunion workers over a possible employee buyout, but the parent of United Airlines will still miss a deadline set by a big shareholder for coming up with a plan.

headline: Growing Use of Electricity Raises Questions on Supply
abstract: LEAD: Electricity use, up by 50 percent since the first oil crisis, in 1973, will continue to grow strongly in the next few decades, far outpacing the increase in non-electric energy, experts attending a conference at George Washington University here said today.

headline: Wang to Sell Unit
abstract: LEAD: Wang Laboratories Inc. agreed in principle to sell its international lease-financing operations for about $250 million to GE Capital, a unit of the General Electric Company. Wang said about $215 million of the proceeds would be used to reduce its bank debt and $35 million would be used to increase its cash position.

headline: Doubleday Book Shops Sale Is Seen
abstract: LEAD: Bertelsmann A.G., the owner of Bantam Doubleday Dell, is believed to be close to reaching a deal to sell its 39 Doubleday Book Shops to Barnes & Noble/B. Dalton.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Assembly Plans a Powerful Gorbachev Presidency
abstract: LEAD: A working group of the Soviet Parliament has drafted a law that would give President Mikhail S. Gorbachev extensive new powers over both the legislative and executive branches of Government, including the authority to disband Parliament.

headline: Boeing, Japanese In Talks About Jet
abstract: LEAD: The Boeing Company said it might give three Japanese aerospace companies a larger share in a new version of its 767 jetliner. ''Boeing continues to have ongoing discussions on an exploratory basis with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries,'' said Dick Schleh, a

headline: $1 Billion Venture Set To Provide Satellite TV
abstract: LEAD: NBC, Rupert Murdoch and one of the nation's largest cable companies have agreed to become partners with Hughes Communications Inc. in a satellite service that will beam television programs directly to homes.

headline: MANDELA APPEAL CALLS ON PRETORIA FOR NEGOTIATIONS
abstract: LEAD: In his first major public pronouncement since he was imprisoned for life more than a quarter of a century ago, Nelson Mandela has appealed to South Africa's white rulers to move urgently toward negotiations for majority rule so as to save the country from ''civil strife and ruin.''

headline: Upheaval in the East;   In Russian Farm Village, Issues Are Down to Earth
abstract: LEAD: By noon today, when the morning shift had finished tending the dairy cows on the state farm in this small village, nearly all the eligible voters had cast their ballots at the polling station. Only 14 holdouts remained, mostly those who were still out doing their chores.

headline: Thai Wants Cambodia Refugees in Neutral Camps
abstract: LEAD: The Thai Prime Minister has proposed moving about 276,000 displaced Cambodians from existing border camps to neutral ones free of political control by the warring Cambodian factions.

headline: Guatemala Bus Crash Kills 12
abstract: LEAD: Twelve Guatemalan refugees were killed and five seriously injured when a bus collided head on with a gas tanker near the Mexican town of Chetumal, about 900 miles southeast of Mexico City, the police said today.

headline: 2 Producers' Unusual Deal At Paramount
abstract: LEAD: Paramount Pictures said today that it had agreed to a deal with two of Hollywood's most successful producers that sets a benchmark for creative and financial freedom.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * BMR Financial Group Inc., Atlanta, and First Chattanooga Financial Corp., Chattanooga, Tenn., said they would merge in a deal worth more than $76 million.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   In East German Army Ranks, A Headlong Farewell to Arms
abstract: LEAD: On paper, the mission of the East German Army's Eighth Motorized Rifle Division has been to strike into West Germany at the outbreak of war and to seize Hamburg, 60 miles to the west.

headline: Swedish Electricity Plan
abstract: LEAD: Sweden will have to pay up to $670 million a year in extra costs if it scraps two nuclear power reactors as scheduled in 1995 and 1996, the state electricity board said last week. In addition, companies that consume large amounts of electricity would face higher charges and some might go out of business, the board said in a report.

headline: Italy Devalues Lira by 3%
abstract: LEAD: The Italian lira was devalued by 3 percent against other major European currencies late today, while its trading band within the European Monetary System was narrowed.

headline: Job Growth in Health Care Soars
abstract: LEAD: The number of jobs in American health care is soaring at a rate three times faster than the growth of the population, troubling experts concerned about the sharp rise in the nation's medical costs. Thirty-seven of every 1,000 Americans worked in health care last year, compared with about 28 for every 1,000 just 10 years earlier.

headline: Multifoods Filling By Archer-Daniels
abstract: LEAD: The Archer-Daniels-Midland Company, the giant grain company based in Decatur, Ill., has acquired 6.7 percent of the International Multifoods Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Archer-Daniels-Midland said it had acquired the shares of the Minneapolis-based company for investment purposes.

headline: Union Criticizes Volvo-Renault Tie
abstract: LEAD: France's Communist-led trade union criticized a deal announced last week that links the Swedish car maker Volvo and its French rival Renault, saying it was bad for France. ''The Renault-Volvo deal is a confidence trick,'' said C.G.T., France's largest trade union, which includes most of Renault's 70,000 workers.

headline: Believers Score in Battle Over the Battle of Jericho
abstract: LEAD: After years of doubt among archeologists, a new analysis of excavations has yielded a wide range of evidence supporting the biblical account about the fall of Jericho. It may well be true that, in the words of the old spiritual, ''Joshua fit the battle of Jericho, and the walls come tumbling down.
