headline: Auto Sales Were Flat in Mid-January
abstract: LEAD: Sales of the eight companies that build cars in the United States were flat in mid-January, compared with a year ago.

headline: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East German Premier Offers a Coalition
abstract: LEAD: Facing spreading disaffection and a growing loss of confidence in his leadership, the head of East Germany's interim Government urged the opposition today to join his Cabinet and share the responsibility for guiding the country through its troubles.

headline: U.S. Remarks On Hostages And Rumors
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from a briefing by the White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, today on reports of efforts to gain the release of American hostages in Lebanon. It was provided by Federal News Service, a transcription company.

headline: EXECUTIVES
abstract: LEAD: * Central Paper Co., Newark, named David H. Berkowitz president and chief operating officer.

headline: Nasdaq Would End Trades in Most Penny Stocks
abstract: LEAD: The Nasdaq over-the-counter market, responding to a crackdown on ''penny stocks'' by regulators, proposed new rules today that would end trading in most stocks worth less than a dollar. The rules would scratch hundreds of penny stocks from the 4,910 issues now traded on the Nasdaq.

headline: Tarlow-Cosmopolitan
abstract: LEAD: Citing a limited potential for growth, Tarlow Advertising has resigned the $1 million trade advertising account of Cosmopolitan magazine. ''I want us to be working in areas where if you a do a great job, you reap the benefits,'' said Dick Tarlow, the agency's president. George H. Simpson, a spokesman for Cosmopolitan, said creative differences had existed as well.

headline: PRAGUE DISMAYED AT TROOP TALKS
abstract: LEAD: A Czechoslovak official said today that negotiations with the Soviet Union on withdrawal of its forces stationed here by the end of this year may have been slowed by Moscow's preoccupation with domestic political problems.

headline: Safeway Stores Plans To Go Public Again
abstract: LEAD: Safeway Stores Inc. is going public again.

headline: Michigan Yields At 5.8% to 6.85%
abstract: LEAD: The Michigan Municipal Bond Authority yesterday tentatively priced $57.7 million in tax-exempt local government loan program revenue bonds for the Detroit School District.

headline: Mitsui Bank Joins in U.S. Buyout Fund
abstract: LEAD: The Mitsui Bank, which started a modestly successful mergers and acquisition team in New York four years ago, announced yesterday that it had formed a relationship with the Carlyle Group, a Washington-based merchant banking firm.

headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Bulgaria;   Thousands of Slavs, Defying Sofia, Continue Anti-Turkish Protests
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of people from Bulgaria's Slavic majority defied the Government and kept up protests today in at least four cities to try to overturn new laws granting religious and cultural freedom to ethnic Turks.

headline: GRUMBLING GROWS IN CHINA'S MILITARY
abstract: LEAD: China's 3.1 million soldiers are enjoying a higher budget as their reward for crushing the democracy movement last summer, but Chinese officials say significant tensions are festering within the military leadership.

headline: Qintex Unit Posts Loss
abstract: LEAD: Qintex Entertainment Inc., a producer and distributor of television programs, has reported a quarterly loss of $3.8 million on sales of $8.2 million. The company is stalled in bankruptcy proceedings and is looking for a buyer or investor.

headline: Aid Hanoi on Boat People, U.N. Official Urges
abstract: LEAD: Faced with continuing United States opposition to the forced repatriation of boat people from Hong Kong to Vietnam, a leading United Nations official appealed today for a sharp increase in international aid to Vietnam. The aim of the aid would be to stop the boat people from fleeing Vietnam in the first place.

headline: Gerber Charge Set
abstract: LEAD: The Gerber Products Company said it would take an after-tax charge of $8.3 million, or 22 cents a share, against its fourth-quarter income to consolidate its Gerber Childrenswear business. The move will eliminate certain ''nonstrategic product lines and reduction of excess manufacturing capacity,'' the company said.

headline: Singapore Air's Marketing Plans
abstract: LEAD: Singapore Airlines is holding talks with its partners, Delta Air Lines and Swissair, on creating a new marketing image for their alliance, a Singapore Airlines executive said. The Straits Times quoted the airline's managing director, Cheong Choong Kong, as saying, ''The next step for Swissair, Delta and Singapore Airlines is to work out a joint identity and to market this so that travel agents would know of this identity.

headline: Court Blocks a Newsletter From Printing Ernst Article
abstract: LEAD: The Atlanta newsletter that in May broke the story of the merger of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young, two large accounting firms, has been temporarily blocked by the surviving firm from publishing an article on the merger in its January issue.

headline: Israeli Planes Raid 2 Areas in Southern Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli Air Force raided targets in southern Lebanon today, killing 3 people and wounding 18 in the heaviest strikes in months, police and Palestinian spokesmen said.

headline: Chrysler Rebates
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation extended its guaranteed rebate program through the end of March. The cash incentives range from $500 to $2,000 off the price of all Chrysler cars and trucks except for the popular mini-vans and the LeBaron convertible models. The announcement marks the second time Chrysler has extended the rebates since they were introduced in mid-December.

headline: RJR Nabisco Had Loss in Quarter, Year
abstract: LEAD: RJR Nabisco Inc. yesterday reported a net loss in the fourth quarter of $144 million and a loss for the year of $1.15 billion. But analysts said the results largely reflected an increase in interest expense and other costs from being taken private early last year by the New York investment firm Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts &

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The Digest Will Promote Its Readers
abstract: LEAD: READER'S DIGEST says it has more male readers between the ages of 25 and 49 than the largest news magazine, more female readers in that age bracket than the largest women's service magazine and that it reaches one-third of all the Americans who participate in ''public activities'' like voting and writing their

headline: Market Place;   Stocks in Europe Start Year Strong
abstract: LEAD: THE stock markets in West Germany and Britain came out of the blocks like a shot this New Year's week, hitting record highs and carrying into 1990 much of the euphoria and buying sentiment of the end of last year. But even as these markets were taking off, several analysts were waving a caution flag, expressing concerns about the effect of Europe's rising interest rates and doubts about the optimism that has greeted changes in Eastern

headline: Upheaval in the East;   An Abundance Of Hired Guns
abstract: LEAD: A senior East German Government official gave a detailed report today on the history and scope of the Office of State Security.

headline: Sony's Newest Portable Is an Electronic Book
abstract: LEAD: A bit more than 10 years after it brought out the Walkman, the Sony Corporation has provided a glimpse of one of the device's most offbeat descendants: the Data Discman, for people who would rather jog through the park reading encyclopedia entries than listening to Simon and Garfunkel.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   GGT Acquires Texas Agency
abstract: LEAD: The GGT Group of London, a fast-growing, publicly traded group of advertising and marketing service companies, has agreed to acquire GSD&M of Austin, Tex., the two companies said today.

headline: Market Place;   Higher Yields From Municipals
abstract: LEAD: FOR now, it is a marriage made in heaven, or perhaps at the Securities and Exchange Commission. The bride is municipal bond funds; the groom something called ''residual interest bonds,'' a new security announced yesterday by the financial engineers at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

headline: Germans Move to Unite Economies, As Kohl Leads and Modrow Follows
abstract: LEAD: After meeting with the caretaker leader of East Germany, Chancellor Helmut Kohl announced today that a joint committee would start immediate preparations for currency and economic union, the first major step in Mr. Kohl's drive toward rapid reunification.

headline: Underwriting Fees Dropped 20.9% in 1989
abstract: LEAD: Despite record amounts of cash being sought by corporate America in 1989, fees on Wall Street for underwriting stock and bond offerings dropped sharply last year.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1990
abstract: LEAD:    The Savings Industry

headline: Talks on Satellites Stalled
abstract: LEAD: Talks between United States and Japanese negotiators have failed to make progress in trying to open Japan's markets to foreign space satellites, a Government trade official said today.

headline: Sovereignty Hinders U.S.-Mexican Drug Alliance
abstract: LEAD: Efforts by Mexico and the United States to halt drug trafficking across the border are being hampered by strong disagreements over how to go about it, Mexican and American officials say.

headline: Business and the Law;   Troubles Persist In Asbestos Cases
abstract: LEAD: FACING a severe cash squeeze, the trust set up by the Manville Corporation to compensate victims of asbestos - who often suffer from fatal diseases - has begun to offer settlements of up to 40 percent in cash and the rest in non-marketable, long-term notes.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LEAD:    MONDAY: Personal income figures for December will be announced.       President Bush is scheduled to submit his 1991 budget to Congress.       WEDNESDAY: Leading economic indicators and new housing sales for December will be released.       Richard Darman of the Office of Managment and Budget testifies before the Senate Budget Committee.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  A Traditional Leader For Columbia Savings
abstract: LEAD: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association, which ran into trouble over its large ''junk bond'' holdings, has turned to an executive with a background in traditional lending and banking to be its new president and chief executive.

headline: Judge Quickly Assumes Active Role in the Stores
abstract: LEAD: In signing five orders yesterday morning, a Federal bankruptcy judge in Cincinnati quickly showed how involved he would be in the operations of one of the world's largest retailing empires.

headline: South Africa's Infuriated Rightists Vow a Battle to Defend Apartheid
abstract: LEAD: The right-wing Conservative Party, furious that President F. W. de Klerk has legalized the African National Congress and promised to free Nelson Mandela, is planning to fight back with a campaign of opposition that it hopes will eventually force Mr. de Klerk out of office.

headline: Bank of Boston Revamping
abstract: LEAD: The Bank of Boston Corporation, the biggest bank in New England, is streamlining as part of a plan to expand in the region and upgrade its services worldwide, the company's chairman, Ira Stepanian, said today.

headline: Record Number of Ratings Lowered by S.& P. in 1989
abstract: LEAD: A record number of debt ratings were lowered by the Standard & Poor's Corporation last year, according to preliminary figures compiled and released yesterday by the financial rating service.

headline: Surajkund Journal;   Where India Would Make Fun, It Makes Enemies
abstract: LEAD: Not far from here, on more than 28,000 acres of rocks and dust that languished uncoveted for centuries under the Indian sun, the opening shots have been fired in a battle that could determine how the recreational needs of nearby New Delhi will be met in the next century.

headline: Market Place;   The Pressures On Drug Stocks
abstract: LEAD: THE robust earnings growth that polished the attractiveness of drug stocks in the 1980's owed much to aggressive increases in drug prices. But pressures to restrain prices are building and that may at least partly explain why pharmaceutical stocks have slipped. This year, pharmaceuticals trail the market by about 5 percent.

headline: Castle & Cooke to Spin Off Dole Foods
abstract: LEAD: Castle & Cooke Inc. said today that it would spin off its Dole Food Company as a separate company.

headline: U.S. Delegation on Managua Vote Disbands
abstract: LEAD: A 20-member Congressional group named by President Bush to observe the elections in Nicaragua this month was disbanded after members were denied visas by Managua's leftist government, Senator Richard G. Lugar said today.

headline: Mad Dashes to Cash the Stores' Checks
abstract: LEAD: When Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation announced last week that they would issue checks to pay suppliers for more than $100 million in merchandise, some suppliers went to great lengths to try to cash those checks before the stores could file for bankruptcy.

headline: Mexico Angry at U.S. Over Use of a Satellite
abstract: LEAD: Mexico has complained that the United States used a satellite to observe drug cultivation without Mexico's knowledge and that Washington has not responded to requests for an explanation.

headline: Treasury Refunding Scheduled This Week
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills and a quarterly refunding that begins tomorrow.

headline: Simmering Battle on Penrod Begins to Boil
abstract: LEAD: A simmering battle for control of the world's largest offshore oil-drilling company, the Penrod Drilling Corporation, has pitted several of its big bankers against a group of investors headed by Richard E. Rainwater, an influential investor from Fort Worth.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Hungary;   Hungary to Recognize Vatican
abstract: LEAD: Hungary removed 40-year-old restrictions on the Roman Catholic Church today, and the Vatican announced that it was re-establishing diplomatic relations with Budapest.

headline: $158 Million Bid for Justin
abstract: LEAD: Justin Industries, a maker of bricks and leather boots, said today that it had received an unsolicited takeover offer for $18.50 a share, or about $158 million, for all of its 8.6 million shares.

headline: Producer Prices Unchanged in February
abstract: LEAD: After posting the biggest increase in more than 15 years in January, producer prices were unchanged last month, the Labor Department said today.

headline: G.M. Is Backed On Plant Closing
abstract: LEAD: An arbitrator ruled that the General Motors Corporation was within its rights under a labor contract with the United Automobile Workers union in 1988 when it closed an assembly plant in Pontiac, Mich., that produced the Pontiac Fiero. But the subject of plant closings and job security will probably be a primary issue when Big Three and union negotiators begin bargaining for a new contract later this year.

headline: Man Always Out of Step May Now Lead in East
abstract: LEAD: Ibrahim Manfred Bohme is in Moscow today, to see Soviet officials, perhaps even President Mhahail S. Gorbachev.asast weekend he was elected chairman of the Social Democratic Party, a promotion that before the month is over might make him Prime Minister.

headline: A Setback for Bailout, And a Bid to Speed It
abstract: LEAD: In a decision that could upset much of President Bush's savings and loan bailout, a Federal district judge ruled that the appointments of the top savings regulator and his predecessor were unconstitutional.

headline: Microsoft President Comes From Boeing
abstract: LEAD: The Microsoft Corporation has found a new president and chief operating officer in its own backyard. He is Michael H. Hallman, president of the Boeing Company's Computer Services division, near Microsoft in the Seattle area.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Bucharest;   NEW RULING GROUP IN RUMANIA TO VIE IN APRIL ELECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: A leader of Rumania's provisional Government said today that the ruling group would put forward its own candidates in the free elections promised for April.

headline: New Move For Buyout Of UAL
abstract: LEAD: The management of the UAL Corporation and the unions at its United Airlines unit are preparing another effort to assemble a buyout proposal, people involved in their discussions said yesterday.

headline: POLITICAL TENSION IN ISRAEL DEEPENS
abstract: LEAD: Labor Party ministers stormed angrily out of an Israeli Cabinet meeting today after Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's Likud party refused to put to a vote a plan by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d for starting Israeli-Palestinian peace talks.

headline: Company News;   8-Day Extension For Eastern Plan
abstract: LEAD: Burton R. Lifland, the chief judge of the United States Bankruptcy Court of the Southern District of New York, granted Eastern Airlines an eight-day extension yesterday to file its plan of reorganization to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

headline: Bonn Panel to Plan for Common Currency With East
abstract: LEAD: The West German Government established a ''German unity'' committee today, charged with creating a blueprint for monetary union to rescue East Germany from economic disaster and preparing detailed plans for political reunification of the two German states.

headline: Article 931390 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported the full cost of its mammoth reorganization effort that began last November, saying that it would take a charge of $470 million against earnings for the last quarter of 1989 to pay for it.

headline: Investor Cools On Bond Bid
abstract: LEAD: A little-known investor, Jeff Reynolds, said Friday that he would probably withdraw his proposal to buy a majority stake in Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., the ailing Australian business empire.

headline: Bank Unit to Martin
abstract: LEAD: The Martin Agency, which won the Banc One Corporation account in December, picked up the account of the Columbus, Ohio, holding company's Texas operation, Bank One Texas N.A., on Friday. The account, formerly at the Richards Group, reportedly bills between $10 million and $12 million.

headline: 400,000 Kashmiri Protesters Urge Independence
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched through the streets of Srinagar today to press demands for independence for the predominantly Muslim border region. It was the largest such demonstration in decades.

headline: Investment Bankers Play Football's Newest Position
abstract: LEAD: There was an extra player in the huddle when the National Football League prepared for its contract negotiations with the televison networks: an investment banker.

headline: Venezuela and Banks Near Agreement on Debt Relief
abstract: LEAD: Venezuela and its commercial bankers are moving toward a debt agreement that is expected to include a provision for substantial, but temporary, debt relief.

headline: Belgium Eases Its Abortion Law
abstract: LEAD: Overcoming 17 years of opposition by Christian Democratic parties, the Belgian Parliament approved a law this afternoon that would allow abortions in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy for women ''in a state of distress.''

headline: Mutual Funds;   Cool Judgment, Hot Results
abstract: LEAD: Ken Oberman, manager of Oppenheimer & Company's Global Fund, keeps several cartoons taped near the computer in his crowded New York City office. One depicts the late Andrei Sakharhov as a diminutive figure on one end of a seesaw upending a massive stone monument of Stalin. Another shows Lech Walesa and asks: How many Poles does it take to change the world?

headline: Business Scene;   Stock Buybacks Vs. Risky Outlays
abstract: LEAD: FOR six years, American corporations have been buying their own stock in a big way. The original idea was to help protect the company from a takeover. But now the takeover threat is waning while the buybacks are as strong as ever. Clearly, they have taken on a life of their own, with important consequences for

headline: Employees Write G.M.
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it had received proposals from a group of employees seeking a vote by the company's shareholders on measures to increase stock value.

headline: Carbide Defends Bhopal Settlement
abstract: LEAD: The Union Carbide Corporation said a $470 million settlement for victims of the industrial disaster in Bhopal, India, was binding even though the country's new Government had disavowed it. ''There is simply no basis for overturning it,'' said Joseph E. Geoghan, Union Carbide's vice president and general counsel.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Della Femina Gets Ramada
abstract: LEAD: Ramada Franchise Systems Inc. yesterday announced the selection of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS as its new advertising agency. The winning of the account enables Della Femina to return to hotel advertising; the agency lost the Sheraton hotel account to Wells, Rich, Greene last March.

headline: ADVERTISING;   Hal Riney Gets Carvel Account
abstract: LEAD: After a run of 35 years, the Carvel Corporation is hanging up Tom Carvel's voice. The ice-cream store chain selected Hal Riney & Partners yesterday to handle its advertising and said future ads would no longer feature the gravelly narration of Mr. Carvel, 84, who founded the company in 1934.

headline: China Reports Release of 573 Held in Revolt
abstract: LEAD: The Government said today that it recently released 573 people who had been imprisoned for taking part in the democracy movement last year.

headline: New Savings Regulator
abstract: LEAD: President Bush today named an Assistant Treasury Secretary, Salvatore R. Martoche, as acting director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, the agency that regulates the nation's savings and loan institutions. Advance notice of the interim appointment was given by Administration officials on Monday.

headline: Tax Fraud Discussions
abstract: LEAD: The European Community and the United States plan talks next week to increase cooperation against tax fraud. Officials said today that the European Community Tax Commissioner, Christiane Scrivener, would meet with top Bush Administration officials.

headline: Analysts See Lower Rates In First Half
abstract: LEAD: Most credit market analysts predict that the gradual decline in interest rates that began last spring is likely to continue well into the first half of 1990. By summer or early fall, however, the bottom will have been reached and a firming trend will emerge, they say.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Yugoslavia on the Brink
abstract: LEAD: Deep in the night, when the Slovenes stalked out of the grand hall, turning their backs on the red flag, the bust of Tito and 1,000 fellow delegates, they did more than paralyze the National League of Communists, Yugoslavia's only national party.

headline: PLOT ON BUSH'S JET POSSIBLE, U.S. SAYS
abstract: LEAD: United States intelligence has picked up indications that Colombian drug traffickers may be planning to attack President Bush when he visits the city of Cartagena next month for a four-nation meeting on narcotics, Administration officials said tonight.

headline: In Poland, Capitalism Brings Hope Tempered With Worry
abstract: LEAD: At the stroke of midnight, Poland becomes the first Eastern European country to leap into the capitalist era.

headline: FORUM;  In Defense of Program Trading
abstract: LEAD: Once again, program trading is in the spotlight. It seems that every time the market experiences a significant drop - as it recently did in Tokyo - or loses the confidence of the investor, it is attributed to program trading. No hard facts are presented, no detailed studies are cited, just blunt claims and emotional outcries.

headline: Real Estate;   S.R.O. Hotel Razed; Long Fight Ended
abstract: LEAD: FOR the first time in more than five years the owners of a single room occupancy hotel in New York City have demolished their property as a matter of right. The action ends a decade-long battle over the S.R.O. issue in City Hall, which led to protest demonstrations by advocates for the homeless and legal fights that stretched from New York to Albany to

headline: 3 Issues in This Week's Treasury Auctions
abstract: LEAD: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's auction of three- and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of two-year notes.

headline: Treasury Issues Decline Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply and long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels in more than six months yesterday in a selloff that traders said was largely spurred by comments from two Federal Reserve Board governors that suggested the Fed was not about to ease monetary policy again any time soon.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * J& J Snack Foods to Grace & Rothschild, with a budget of $4 million.

headline: Your Own Account;  When Renting Makes More Sense
abstract: LEAD: The sagging national real estate market means that many American families who must relocate are unable to sell their homes at the price they want - or at any price. For some, renting is becoming increasingly attractive.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Neutral-Germany Stand By Soviets Is Softening
abstract: LEAD: Soviet foreign policy experts have indicated that Moscow might eventually compromise on its demand that a united Germany be a neutral nation outside NATO.

headline: Investor Joins Blackstone
abstract: LEAD: Henry R. Silverman, an investor known for stepping in and managing his acquisitions, is leaving the Reliance Capital Group to join the Blackstone Group.

headline: POLAND RESHAPING ITS LOCAL VOTING
abstract: LEAD: Poland is preparing for free elections for a completely reorganized local government that Solidarity supporters hope will break the grip of the Communist Party bureaucracy throughout the country.

headline: 39 Die as Storm Pounds Britain With Gusts Exceeding 100 M.P.H.
abstract: LEAD: At least 39 people were reported killed today as storm winds of 100 miles an hour, with even higher gusts and driving rains, swept Britain and surrounding seas.

headline: As Big Brokers Trim, The Small Add Talent
abstract: LEAD: Amid the chaos and upheaval on Wall Street, several small and foreign investment-banking and brokerage houses are finding reason to celebrate.

headline: How Major Studios Missed a Hit
abstract: LEAD: When Lili and Richard Zanuck and their partner tried to sell the major Hollywood studios on investing in a movie about an elderly Jewish widow and her black chauffeur, the response was an enthusiastic no. The script was brilliant, they were told, but in terms of appeal to a wide audience, it wasn't exactly ''Batman.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Altos Computer Systems, San Jose, Calif., said it would repurchase up to two million shares of its 10.8 million common shares outstanding.

headline: May Stores Appoints Chief of Its G. Fox Chain
abstract: LEAD: The May Department Stores Company has filled the top post at its G. Fox department store chain in Hartford with the appointment of Eugene S. Kahn, a young executive from R. H. Macy & Company.

headline: Group Split Over Law On Drugs
abstract: LEAD: A split has developed in the biotechnology industry, pitting the two leading companies against two other major companies in the field. At issue is how much protection should be awarded to those first in the market with a product.

headline: The Executive Life;  Bringing Up Managers For the Factory Floor
abstract: LEAD: Could the Rust Belt rise again? Lewis Cullman thinks so. And he has been right before.

headline: Voices of Bulgaria Tell Story of Hate
abstract: LEAD: Around the equestrian statue of Czar Alexander II, the 19th-century Russian liberator of Bulgaria from Turkish domination, the talk today was of civil rights and racism, of patriotism and perfidy.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Soviets Reinforcing Troops Along Iranian Border
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Government reinforced its troops along the Iranian border today in the face of continuing reports of destructive protests by Azerbaijani crowds demanding an open frontier.

headline: Holiday Inn Deal Completed by Bass
abstract: LEAD: Bass P.L.C. completed its acquisition of Holiday Inns Inc. for $2.2 billion and said the motel chain's headquarters would be moved to Atlanta from Memphis. Bryan D. Langton, the chairman of the Bass hotel and restaurant division, will become chairman and chief executive of Holiday Inns and move from Britain to

headline: SOVIET LEADERS AGREE TO SURRENDER COMMUNIST PARTY MONOPOLY ON POWER
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party leadership agreed today to surrender its historic monopoly of power in the Soviet Union and accept a program that recommends the creation of a Western-style presidency and Cabinet system of government.

headline: New India Leader Dismisses Gandhi's Loyalists in Capital
abstract: LEAD: The new Government has dismissed an opposition party corporation that controls major utilities and services here in the capital, accusing it of inefficiency.

headline: Secret Ballots To Be Allowed
abstract: LEAD: The directors of Texaco Inc., the Amoco Corporation and the Foxboro Company have agreed to allow secret ballots for proxy votes, according to the office of the New York City Comptroller, Elizabeth Holtzman.

headline: Court Clears Aid For Bhopal Victims
abstract: LEAD: India's Supreme Court approved a Government plan to pay interim compensation of $12 a month to each of the 500,000 people living near the site of the 1984 Bhopal disaster. The Supreme Court also ruled that the Government must pay $44 a month to 3,110 people disabled by the toxic gas leak.

headline: Savings Bond Sales Up
abstract: LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds totaled $826 million in January, up 39 percent from December, the Treasury Department reported last week. January's sales, which were 2 percent higher than those of January 1989, brought the total value of bonds held by the public to a record $118.2 billion. Savings bonds are earning interest at a rate of 6.98 percent when held five years or longer.

headline: Your Own Account;  Beware the Early Payouts
abstract: LEAD: When the Prudential Insurance Company of America said last month that it would pay death benefits in advance to terminally ill policyholders, it drew attention to a relatively new type of life insurance that offers a so-called accelerated death benefit, or living payout.

headline: BUSINESS DIARY: January 7-12
abstract: LEAD:    COMPANIES       Debt Ahead for UAL       The UAL Corporation had better learn to love debt. Either management and the employees will load the company with debt to buy it, or the board will undertake a buyback - mortgaging the company to pay some impatient stockholders a premium. The noisiest of these stockholders, Coniston Partners, threatens to unseat most of the board unless UAL coughs up a satisfactory payoff.

headline: Opposition Sees Gain in Moscow Vote
abstract: LEAD: Encouraged by its role in crafting the new national presidency, the budding Soviet political opposition predicted further progress today as citizens voted in local and republic elections in various parts of the nation. Most crucial for the opposition was a battle with the Communist Party for control of the Moscow City

headline: Realty Hurts American Express
abstract: LEAD: The American Express Company's dabble into real estate in the 1980's is proving to be one of its biggest blunders.

headline: Burmese Troops Said to Win Battle for Rebel Stronghold
abstract: LEAD: Government troops have overrun a stronghold of minority rebels along the Thai border after 10 days of fighting in which at least 36 people were killed, a military spokesman said today.

headline: Phelan Plans to Retire As Head of Big Board
abstract: LEAD: John J. Phelan Jr., who presided over an extraordinary period of growth, turmoil and change on Wall Street during his six years as the chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that he planned to retire by the end of the year to pursue other interests.

headline: Honda Export Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Honda Motor Company plans to export a United States-made Accord station wagon to Europe, Honda's chief executive, Tadashi Kume, said. Honda will begin making the Accord wagon at its assembly plant in Marysville, Ohio, later this year for the 1991 model year. Honda's Marysville plant now makes the Civic and Accord models.

headline: Con Ed Wants to Stifle Demand
abstract: LEAD: Consolidated Edison, which like other utilities has historically earned its profits by building generating stations and selling customers more electricity, is now moving instead to insure that it will not have to build another power plant for many years.

headline: Patents;   A Tape Measure With Digital Readout
abstract: LEAD: The Kyoto Measuring Instruments Corporation, based in Kyoto, Japan, has invented a retractable tape measure with a digital readout. The device is said to be easier to use and to read than the standard tool, in which measurements are marked on the tape itself.

headline: Iraq Said to Build Launchers for Its 400-Mile Missiles
abstract: LEAD: Iraq has constructed for the first time launchers for missiles within range of Tel Aviv and Damascus, according to classifed American intelligence reports. While the weapons could be used for offensive purposes, American intelligence experts believe that the missiles are intended in part to discourage any possible Israeli attack on

headline: Stocks Drift Lower to End Dismal Week
abstract: LEAD: Stocks continued to drift lower yesterday in brisk trading as bonds weakened, interest rates showed no sign of coming down any time soon and investors pored anxiously over a new batch of discouraging earnings reports.

headline: Policy Shift at Engelhard
abstract: LEAD: The Engelhard Corporation, a leading metals refiner, said it would sell those businesses to concentrate on chemical production. The Edison, N.J., concern will also cut 500 jobs from its work force of 8,100 and shut a number of plants. Engelhard's stock fell $1.125 on Friday, to $20.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Consumer Debt Rose 5.9% In January on Auto Sales
abstract: LEAD: Americans took out $3.54 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in January as they flocked to auto dealerships to lock in the latest round of sales incentives, the Federal Reserve reported today.

headline: Continental Air Cuts Staff by 150
abstract: LEAD: The Texas Air Corporation's Continental Airlines laid off about 150 employees earlier this week as part of a ''belt tightening'' program, a Texas Air spokesman, Art Kent, said. The layoffs, which occurred Tuesday, affected employees who have no direct contact with customers, Mr. Kent said.

headline: Trade Gap at $105.89 Billion In 1989, Lowest in 5 Years
abstract: LEAD: The United States trade deficit declined to $105.89 billion last year, its lowest level in five years, as merchandise exports grew and travel abroad increased, the Government said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: On Economic Front, Changes Continue
abstract: LEAD: G.M. Deal With East Germany. The largest American auto maker tentatively agreed to a joint venture with the larger of East Germany's two car makers. General Motors could invest as much as $600 million in the venture, which would make components and assemble cars at a factory near the West German border.

headline: The Complete Return on Investment
abstract: LEAD: Behind every tract of rain forest that is cleared, every factory that is shuttered and locked and every oil-clogged beach lies an investment decision. These decisions may have paid big dividends to shareholders and other investors - they may have made certain individuals wealthier - but they also have harmed the economy, society and environment.

headline: Stock Split At Teledyne
abstract: LEAD: Teledyne Inc. said today that its directors had approved a 5-for-1 split of its common stock and a plan to spin off its insurance and finance units.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Soviet Congress Rejects Lithuanian Secession Move
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Parliament today overwhelmingly rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence as invalid, and it directed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to protect Soviet citizens and interests in the republic.

headline: Patents: Hunt Goes On For a Better Mousetrap;   New Tracking Compound
abstract: LEAD: An attempt to develop a more child-proof rat poison comes from ICI Americas, a subsidiary of Imperial Chemical Industries P.L.C. The poison is a new form of tracking compound, a substance that gets into the fur of a rodent.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of March 4, 1990:       MONDAY       Albertsons Inc    Harnischfeger    Davis Wtr & Wste Inds Inc    Rykoff Sexton Inc       TUESDAY       Alaska Air Group Inc    Premier Indl Corp    Premark Intl Inc       WEDNESDAY       Browning Ferris Inds Inc    Neiman-Marcus Group Inc    Chemical Wste Mgmt Inc    Stanhome Inc    Corroon & Black Corp    Starrett L S Co    Dillard Dept Stores Inc    Tis Mtg Invt Co    General Dynamics    USF&G Corp    Handleman Co Del    Wolverine World Wide Inc    Helmerich & Payne Inc

headline: U.P.I. Action On Reuters
abstract: LEAD: United Press International asked a Federal court on Monday for an injunction to prevent Reuters from backing out of a photo exchange agreement between the two news agencies.

headline: Fiscal Bureaucracy in Japan Loses Credibility
abstract: LEAD: By engineering Japan's miraculous economic recovery after the war, steering the shaken economy deftly through the oil crises of the 1970's and then stabilizing the nation's financial markets quickly after the United States stock market collapsed in October 1987, Japan's economic policy makers won an international reputation for unparalleled management ability.

headline: The Executive Computer;   The Font Wars: New Weapons Are Rolled Out
abstract: LEAD: Six months after the first major battle of the so-called Font Wars, the smoke is starting to clear. One camp is led by Adobe Inc., which once had a virtual monopoly on outline fonts, the typography that is stored as mathematical formulas rather than as images formed by a collection of dots. The other camp is led by Apple Computer Inc.

headline: Punch Account to Ayer
abstract: LEAD: The Proctor & Gamble Company, which acquired Hawaiian Punch from Del Monte in January for $150 million, has assigned the advertising account for the beverage brand to Ayer, New York. The brand has not been advertised much of late, as Del Monte had emphasized promotions.

headline: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;   U.S. Keeps Distance From New Rulers in East
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration has decided to keep a certain distance from the revolutionary government in Rumania, as well as from other new regimes in Eastern Europe, because of doubts that they have committed themselves to democratic free-market reforms, Administration officials said today.

headline: Continental Plans $9 One-Way Fare
abstract: LEAD: Continental Airlines introduced a $9 one-way fare within Texas and a few destinations outside the state but with several restrictions.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          Markets

headline: Perrier Recall: How Damaging Is It?
abstract: LEAD: Over more than a decade, Perrier convinced Americans that its French spring water was chic enough to be worth $29 a gallon when consumed in small bottles in restaurants. But over just two days, Perrier has seen its marketing efforts of endangered by a swell of bad publicity.

headline: Hazard Sign for Soviets As the Ukraine Wavers
abstract: LEAD: If President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is alert to the omens of his decomposing realm, he may have noticed the strong election-day showing of Genrikh O. Altunyan and Yegor I. Kravtsiv, two former political prisoners who campaigned in Kharkov on a platform of full independence for the Ukraine.

headline: Treasury Notes and Bonds Rise
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose in thin trading yesterday, as many dealers who sold securities on Monday turned around and bought them yesterday.

headline: TBS Allowed Vietnam Link
abstract: LEAD: Turner Broadcasting System said Thursday that it had won its battle with the Bush Administration over providing its Cable News Network and a satellite receiving station to Vietnam.

headline: Santa Fe Pacific To Cut 2,700 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said it planned to reduce employment on its railroad by 2,700 jobs over five years. The reductions would take place through job buyouts, attrition and possible layoffs, and would affect union and white-collar workers, said Robert Gerht, a spokesman for Chicago-based company.

headline: Christian Army Drives on Beirut Rivals
abstract: LEAD: Lebanese Army troops loyal to the Christian commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, mounted a fierce tank and artillery offensive against militia forces in East Beirut today, and the police said there were more than 100 casualties.

headline: Soviets Ask Czechs To Extend the Time To Pull Out Troops
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union told Czechoslovakia today that it needed more time to withdraw the 75,000 Soviet troops in that country, East European diplomats said.

headline: Cable TV Is No Longer A Stepchild
abstract: LEAD: AS if it weren't bad enough that advertising executives have to deal with three networks and Fox television, the dozen large advertiser-supported cable services are demanding more attention. And their numbers continue to grow.

headline: Turkey Remains Confident It Will Join European Community
abstract: LEAD: Some political analysts here fret that the West's preoccupation with Eastern Europe has pushed Turkey onto a back burner - even worse, perhaps off the stove - in its dogged pursuit of full membership in the European Community.

headline: MGM/UA Sale Seen as Stalled
abstract: LEAD: Jeffrey Barbakow, chairman of the MGM/UA Communications Company, has told company executives that efforts to sell the entertainment company are on hold, the trade publication Variety has reported, quoting unidentified sources.

headline: Why Let Fund Managers Off the Hook?
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Bonn Far Right Loses Steam As Germans Focus on Unity
abstract: LEAD: German unity might seem to be the stuff of right-wing dreams. In fact, it has proved something of a nightmare for the far-right Republican Party.

headline: Bill Farley Learns More of The Downside
abstract: LEAD: Going down. And down.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   WPP Buys Agency
abstract: LEAD: The WPP Group P.L.C. announced yesterday that it had acquired Thomas G. Ferguson Associates Inc., a health-care marketing and advertising communications agency based in Parsippany, N.J. Ferguson has about $130 million in billings and a client roster that includes Johnson & Johnson and the Warner-Lambert Company.

headline: Reporter's Notebook;   Pope's Themes on Africa Trip: 'Drops of Water on a Stone'
abstract: LEAD: From start to finish on his latest African pilgrimage, Pope John Paul II has sent up danger flares about otherwise welcome developments in Eastern Europe.

headline: Patents;   A Chain That Becomes As Rigid as a Bar
abstract: LEAD: In a similar spirit, a Brooklyn inventor won a patent several weeks ago for what she called a ''chain bar.''

headline: Albanian-Americans Rally at White House
abstract: LEAD: A group of Albanian-Americans began three days of demonstrations today in front of the White House urging the Bush Administration to ask the Government of Yugoslavia to stop the killing of ethnic Albanians in the Kosovo region.

headline: Honda to Make Chips
abstract: LEAD: The Honda Motor Company said Friday that it plans to make gallium arsenide semiconductors on an experimental basis at a plant it is building at a cost of two billion yen, or about $13.7 million, at its laboratory in Tochigi Prefecture near Tokyo. It plans to produce prototypes of the heat-resistant chips by the end of this month and to mass-produce the semiconductors in the early 1990's for use in sensors and other electronic devices.

headline: Bankruptcy Pay Ruling
abstract: LEAD: Federal Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. granted a request yesterday in Bankruptcy Court in Cincinnati by Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation to take back about $5.3 million due to Thomas M. Macioce, the former chairman and chief executive of Allied Stores.

headline: Talking Business; with Kelly of Resolution Trust;   Property Auction On an Epic Scale
abstract: LEAD: Lamar C. Kelly Jr. is the Government official with the task of organizing the sales of thousands of single-family homes, apartments, office buildings and other properties held by hundreds of troubled savings institutions now controlled by the Resolution Trust Corporation.

headline: Rig Count Falls in Week
abstract: LEAD: The number of working United States oil and gas rigs declined by 15 last week, to a total of 908, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. The decrease conforms to previous first quarters when the count generally was in decline, said Ike Kerridge Jr., an economist at Baker Hughes. The count remains well ahead of the 1989 tally at this period.

headline: Upheaval in ht e East;   Pope Praises Christian Role In Collapse of Communism
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II pronounced a stinging epitaph for Communism in Europe today but said the road to a world of freedom and justice was strewn with obstacles.

headline: Peruvian Police Ambush and Kill 18 Rebels
abstract: LEAD: A police patrol ambushed and killed 18 Marxist guerrillas in Peru's Andean foothills, the Government said today. The clash added to a surge in rural political violence that has claimed at least 30 lives in the past four days.

headline: P.L.O. Pressing Moscow on Jewish Emigres
abstract: LEAD: Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization are trying to persuade Moscow to stop the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel, senior Palestinians say.

headline: Rig Count Drops Again
abstract: LEAD: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States continued to decline last week, dropping by six, to a total of 931, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. But the number was higher than the 780 posted for the corresponding week last year. In the two previous weeks, the count plunged by a total of 82 rigs.

headline: Drug Study Faults Role Of State Dept.
abstract: LEAD: An internal State Department review has concluded that the agency has not taken its role in the drug war seriously because it is hampered by the complexity of its mission, limited resources and a lack of interest among senior agency officials.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   ZHIVKOV IS PLACED IN BULGARIAN JAIL
abstract: LEAD: Todor Zhivkov, the deposed Bulgarian leader, has been moved from house arrest to a prison for people accused of murder and other major crimes, the chief prosecutor's office said today.

headline: Stocks Mixed Despite Rally In Blue Chips
abstract: LEAD: Blue-chip stocks rallied in the final half-hour of trading yesterday, but the overall market finished the day mixed.

headline: Imperial Bankruptcy Filing
abstract: LEAD: The Imperial Corporation of America, parent company of a savings and loan association seized by the Government, said today that it had filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

headline: Where Executives Dress Up And Let Their Hair Down
abstract: LEAD: On most days they can be found running large corporations, banks and brokerage houses. But once a year they attend a secretive, all-male dinner party at which new members sometimes dress in drag and perform silly skits. They have been known to add even more levity by tossing rolls at each other.

headline: New I.B.M. Prices
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said that it would raise prices 3 percent for many of its computers, 4 to 5 percent for selected printers and 10 percent for services and many of its software products. The company also said it was reducing the price of memory for its most powerful 3090 mainframe computer by up to 20 percent.

headline: Rorer Shares Rise on Deal
abstract: LEAD: The share price of Rorer Group Inc. rose $1 yesterday in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange after an announcement on Thursday that the company had signed an agreement to merge with the pharmaceutical operations of Rhone-Poulenc S.A., a chemical company owned by the French Government.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   East Germany Discloses Serious Accident at Nuclear Plant in 1976
abstract: LEAD: The East German Government said today that a power plant on its Baltic coast had suffered the country's ''most serious and grave'' nuclear accident in 1976, and that a single pump might have prevented the reactor's radioactive core from melting down after a fire.

headline: The Pioneers of Wind-Shear Warning Systems
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Pan Am Offers Refund Policy
abstract: LEAD: Pan American World Airways announced a new policy yesterday, promising a free flight to anyone with a valid complaint about service in first class on its flights between New York and San Francisco or Los Angeles and between Washington and Los Angeles.

headline: More Nixdorf Cuts
abstract: LEAD: Nixdorf Computer A.G., the troubled computer maker that has agreed to be acquired by Siemens A.G. said it would reduce its work force by about 4,880 as part of a reorganization. About 1,600 jobs, out of a total of 31,000, were cut as part of an earlier reorganization.

headline: Receivership For Empire
abstract: LEAD: Federal banking regulators have placed Empire of America Federal Savings Bank in receivership and changed its name to Empire Federal Savings Bank of America.

headline: Firm's Chief Hopes Troubles Remain Behind: FREDERICK H. JOSEPH, Drexel Burnham
abstract: LEAD: With Drexel Burnham Lambert's ''junk bond'' money machine sputtering, Frederick H. Joseph now faces the challenge of navigating the firm through what may be its toughest time in the market.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   11.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.25   8.31   9.70        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.76   7.81   8.63        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.76   7.76   8.66        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.57   8.59   9.34        30-YR.

headline: Tourism Up In Sri Lanka After a Slump
abstract: LEAD: The nervous young waiter in his obviously new orange uniform was clearly smitten by the first French tourist of the season.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Smithsonian's Lighter Touch
abstract: LEAD: Like other relatively highbrow magazines, Smithsonian is concerned about being overlooked by young media planners, who, those magazines fear, often favor trendier publications.

headline: Tamils Flee Sri Lanka, but India Limits Entry
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of ethnic Tamils who cooperated with Indian peacekeeping forces in Sri Lanka since 1987 are fleeing to India in boats, fearing violence when New Delhi's troops leave the island at the end of this month.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Prime Minister Is Bullish on Yugoslavia's Economic Changes
abstract: LEAD: There is one big optimist in this country of great economic changes and political tensions. His name is Ante Markovic, and he happens to be the Prime Minister.

headline: Curtiss-Wright Fills Top Posts
abstract: LEAD: The Curtiss-Wright Corporation said today that it had named Shirley D. Brinsfield chairman and Charles E. Ehinger president. The appointments of Mr. Brinsfield, formerly executive vice president and a director, and Mr. Ehinger, also previously an executive vice president, fill the vacancies created by the death of T.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Paramount to Ogilvy
abstract: LEAD: Graham Phillips called one of his senior executives over the weekend to exult: ''We're back in show business!'' The chief executive of Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide was reveling because his Los Angeles office had just won the media planning and buying account of the Paramount Pictures Corporation. The account, which is worth $60 million to $70 million in annual billings, was pulled four weeks ago from D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles's Los Angeles office after less than two years there.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
abstract: LEAD: * Hal Riney & Partners has moved its New York office to 100 East 42d Street, Manhattan.

headline: With Martial Law Lifted, An Eerie Quiet in Beijing
abstract: LEAD: The streets of the capital were quiet this morning after the lifting of martial law, more than seven months after it had been imposed to crush the pro-democracy movement. But there appeared to be no slackening of the authorities' determination to suppress any new sign of unrest.

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change                $      Net Income   Percent        Oct.-Dec.   Change        1989   From '88        Allegheny Ludlum Corp.   $ 28,600,000    +21.2        Armstrong World Industries   55,300,000    +59.8        Bausch & Lomb Inc.   34,400,000    +19.0        Beckman Instruments Inc.

headline: Bond Prices Dip in Slow Session
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in extremely lethargic trading yesterday, as dealers watched developments in the foreign exchange markets and waited for the release tomorrow morning of February employment data.

headline: Volkswagen and Czechs In Talks About Venture
abstract: LEAD: Volkswagen A.G., Western Europe's largest automobile manufacturer, is holding wide-ranging talks with a Czechoslovak auto maker, Skoda, on possible areas of cooperation, a Volkswagen spokesman said today.

headline: Rising Opposition To Soviet Garrisons
abstract: LEAD: The Hungarian Government told an international conference on conventional forces in Europe that it wants the Soviet Union to withdraw all its troops from Hungarian soil. And in a meeting with a Soviet official in Gdansk, the Polish union leader, Lech Walesa, demanded the removal of the Soviet garrison in Poland.

headline: 44 Injured in Italian Theft
abstract: LEAD: A holdup went awry today when an explosive that robbers planned to used to blast open a safe went off prematurely, injuring 44 people in a crowded post office, the police said. Among the wounded were retirees lining up to receive their monthly pension payments, the police said.

headline: 10-Year U.S. Notes Sell Well
abstract: LEAD: A better-than-expected turnout at the Treasury's quarterly auction of 10-year notes spurred a sharp turnaround in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities moved off their lows and closed higher for the day.

headline: BTR Acts to Force Norton Meeting
abstract: LEAD: The British conglomerate BTR P.L.C., whose hostile bid for the Norton Company was rejected on Thursday, asked a Federal court to force Norton to restore its canceled April annual meeting. The Worcester, Mass., plastics and ceramics company Thursday rejected BTR's offer of $75 a share, or $1.64 billion, as inadequate.

headline: Coke Settles Case in Europe
abstract: LEAD: The European Community Commission said Tuesday that it had closed an anti-competition case against the Coca-Cola Company, satisfied that the soft-drink maker had ended anti-competitive practices in the European Community.

headline: Couple Settle With S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: An Ohio woman and her estranged husband, who were accused of an insider trading scheme involving the stock of Revco Drug Stores and two other companies, settled without admitting or denying wrongdoing, Federal regulators said today.

headline: Pretoria Asserts Its Views Gain Support
abstract: LEAD: President F. W. de Klerk said today that the South African Government was approaching its first formal talks with the African National Congress with confidence that Pretoria was gaining international support because of the ''archaic policies'' espoused by Nelson Mandela and other congress leaders.

headline: Eastern Plan For Review
abstract: LEAD: The management of Eastern Air Lines said today that it would ask the United States Bankruptcy Court to review 12 transactions between Eastern and its parent company, the Texas Air Corporation.

headline: Salvadoran Military Accepts Responsibility for Bombing
abstract: LEAD: El Salvador's military accepted responsibility today for the bombing of a refugee site last Sunday that killed at least five civilians.

headline: Small-Town Ad Agency Takes on the Big City
abstract: LEAD: When the makers of Very Fine juice went looking for a new advertising agency last fall, the company put together a list of six top Madison Avenue names and one agency that some of the contenders had never heard of: Mullen Advertising.

headline: Manila Caution to Banks
abstract: LEAD: The Philippine Finance Secretary today warned overseas banks that refused to lend more money to the heavily indebted country that their actions could affect future business with Manila. ''The Philippines cannot be taken for granted, and those who are going to support us will be treated very favorably,'' the Finance Secretary, Jesus Estanislao, said.

headline: Salvadoran Chief Asks U.N. Help To Restart Talks With Guerrillas
abstract: LEAD: On the eve of White House talks, President Alfredo Cristiani of El Salvador asked the United Nations today to help restart stalled peace talks with the Salvadoran guerrilla alliance.

headline: Honda Blurs Line Between American and Foreign
abstract: LEAD: When the Honda Accord became the best-selling car model in the United States last year - the first foreign car ever to do so - not everyone viewed the event as simply another sign of American industrial decline at the hands of Japan.

headline: U.S. Disputes Korean's Account
abstract: LEAD: The United States took the unusual step of criticizing former President Chun Doo Hwan's ''distorted'' testimony last week regarding American actions during the 1980 Kwangju incident in order to stem anti-American sentiment, officials said on Saturday.

headline: Sony's New Recorder
abstract: LEAD: The Sony Corporation said today that it had developed an ultracompact digital memo recorder. The recorder uses tapes the size of postage stamps that can record for up to two hours. It will be commercially available later this year, a spokesman said. No indication of price was given today.

headline: Subjugating Hong Kong
abstract: LEAD: The most symbolic action of the China-appointed committee deciding Hong Kong's fate was perhaps the choice this week of the flag that will flutter over the territory beginning in 1997: a white bauhinia flower against a revolutionary red background.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Michael Fromowitz has been appointed regional creative director for Backer Spielvogel Bates Asia.

headline: Security Pacific Chief Decides to Step Aside
abstract: LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest banking company, said yesterday that Richard J. Flamson 3d had stepped aside as chief executive at the age of 60 and had been replaced by Robert H. Smith, who formerly headed the company's major bank subsidiary.

headline: Lawmakers Urged by Baker To Back Shift in Foreign Aid
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d sought Congressional leaders' approval today to free about $250 million in 1990 foreign aid money designated for specific countries so that the department can redistribute the money to other nations.

headline: U.S. Officials Suspect Israelis Sent Ethiopia Cluster Bombs
abstract: LEAD: Administration officials said today they strongly suspected that Israel has sent cluster bombs to Ethiopia. They said there were unconfirmed reports that the Soviet-backed Marxist Government in Addis Ababa has already used the weapons against rebels in the northern part of the country.

headline: Unisys, I.B.M. Set Up Units
abstract: LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Unisys Corporation said separately yesterday that they had set up special units to help customers manage computer operations.

headline: Why We 'Interfered' With G.M.
abstract: LEAD: My decision to ask the board of directors of the General Motors Corporation to describe the process of selecting a new chairman and chief executive was prompted by a number of concerns I have as a major shareholder.

headline: Late Buying Gives Dow Gain of 25.23
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices rose broadly yesterday, helped by a late spurt of futures-related ''buy'' programs. As arbitragers sold futures and bought stocks, the Dow Jones industrial average climbed 25.23 points, to 2,649.55.

headline: Comment on Mexican Debt
abstract: LEAD: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari said today that Mexico's recent debt-reduction accord was agreed upon hours after his Government secretly decided to suspend its foreign debt payments.

headline: The U.S. and Panama;   Peruvians Give Asylum To a Noriega Associate
abstract: LEAD: Peru said today that it had granted diplomatic asylum to a Noriega associate who is wanted by the United States and to 11 others who took refuge in the Peruvian Ambassador's residence in Panama City.

headline: Money Fund Assets Up
abstract: LEAD: The assets of the nation's 497 money market mutual funds increased by $3.57 billion, to $390.68 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 152 institutional funds rose $1.25 billion, to $92.67 billion. The assets of the 244 general-purpose funds rose $1.33 billion, to $132.55 billion.

headline: Long-Range Libyan Bombers
abstract: LEAD: The Pentagon says Libya has successfully tested a system to refuel fighter-bombers in flight, enhancing their range for attack. Page A15.

headline: Article 483490 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: The Chubb Capital Corporation, a unit of the Chubb Corporation, is offering $100 million in notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities.

headline: Soviet Trade Pact Expected
abstract: LEAD: United States officials said today that they expect to conclude a new trade accord with the Soviet Union in time for a superpower summit meeting in June, a move that would end a 16-year dispute linking trade with Soviet emigration policy.

headline: Ambac Indemnity
abstract: LEAD: Citicorp announced yesterday that it was considering selling the Ambac Indemnity Corporation, a subsidiary of Citibank that insures interest and principal payments on municipal bonds. The possibility of a sale, which has been previously suggested by banking analysts, is part of Citicorp's plans announced earlier this year to raise capital by selling some operations, the banking company said.

headline: U.S. Penalty On Silverado
abstract: LEAD: Federal regulators said today that they had penalized the former chairman of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver and confirmed they met this week with a son of President Bush who was a director of the institution.

headline: Jobless Rate Soars in Poland And Prices Rise Nearly 70%
abstract: LEAD: The rate of unemployment soared nearly 600 percent last month after the Solidarity-led Government imposed a host of market-oriented economic changes.

headline: Simmons to Fight Lockheed Rule
abstract: LEAD: The Texas financier Harold C. Simmons, already waging a proxy fight for control of the board of the Lockheed Corporation, said he would also seek to eliminate the anti-takeover plan of the Calabasas, Calif., military contractor. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons said he would solicit proxies to remove the plan.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   GORBACHEV TELLS THE LITHUANIANS TO TURN IN ARMS
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made use of his new executive powers tonight to tighten Soviet resistance to Lithuanian independence, ordering civilians in Lithuania to surrender private firearms to representatives of the central Government, and putting foreigners under stricter controls in traveling to the increasingly anxious republic.

headline: Peru Rebels Kill 2 Officials
abstract: LEAD: Maoist guerrillas shot to death the deputy mayors of two Andean villages who were members of the Democratic Front, the opposition coalition of presidential candidate Mario Vargas Llosa, the police said. The Shining Path rebels left notes on both bodies that said: ''This is how the new starvers of the people die,'' the police said.

headline: Pope Asks Affluent Lands Not to Scorn Africa
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II arrived today in this struggling land and begged affluent nations ''not to scorn'' Africa's hungry millions.

headline: U.S. Officials Say Outcome Promises to Benefit NATO
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration today hailed the election in East Germany as a victory ''for all who support democratic values'' and some officials said it would increase the chances that a unified Germany would remain in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: U.S. Rethinks Strategy
abstract: LEAD: The Bush Administration and Congress began work on reshaping American military strategy in the face of upheavals in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Page A11.

headline: Angola Sees Gain in a Free Namibia
abstract: LEAD: The President of Angola says independence for Namibia will give a military advantage to his Government in its long-running war with rightist rebels.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising
abstract: LEAD: AN urban landscape of freeways, palm trees and jumbled communities, Los Angeles confounds many because it lacks geographical focus.

headline: Your Own Account;  Linking Love and Money
abstract: LEAD: The predivorce wrangle between Donald Trump and his wife, Ivana, has focused attention on an increasingly common element in the contemporary marriage - the prenuptial agreement.

headline: Settlement in Abbott Case
abstract: LEAD: Richard W. Dutrisac, a former director of Pancretec Inc. today settled a Federal civil accusation that he had passed information about merger negotiations between Pancretec and Abbott Laboratories to a close friend in January 1989.

headline: Court Takes Price-Fixing Case
abstract: LEAD: Urged by state attorneys general, the Supreme Court agreed to decide if states can bring Federal antitrust suits charging energy producers with illegal price-fixing. Page D1.

headline: OPEC Quota Rise Sought
abstract: LEAD: Because of the high price of oil, OPEC should look at the possibility of increasing quotas when the group's oil ministers meet in March, the Kuwaiti oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah said today.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   2 Die in Ethnic Protests In a Yugoslav Province
abstract: LEAD: At least 2 ethnic Albanians were killed and 20 seriously injured today in battles with the police on the sixth day of unrest in Kosovo province.

headline: Anti-Apartheid Group Forming Stand on Changes
abstract: LEAD: The governing body of the African National Congress is meeting here this week to develop a response to reforms announced by President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa and to determine what role Nelson Mandela will play in the organization.

headline: Black & Decker
abstract: LEAD: The Black & Decker Corporation said it expects to sell its footwear materials unit to the United Machinery Group Ltd. for about $125 million in cash, and its capacitors business, excluding the United States segment, to the Nissei Electric Company for $80 million in cash. Both businesses had been for sale since Black & Decker acquired the Emhart Corporation last year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Y.&.R. Loses Heublein
abstract: LEAD: Heublein Inc., the alcohol importer, and Young & Rubicam have parted company. Y.&.R. had the accounts for Finlandia vodka, Jose Cuervo tequila and Inglenook wine. Estimated billings were about $7 million.

headline: Federated Shuns Further Asset Sales
abstract: LEAD: G. William Miller, the new chairman and chief executive of Federated Stores Inc., told creditors today that the company would not be ''broken up'' beyond the possible sale of the Bloomingdale's chain.

headline: Campbell Soup
abstract: LEAD: The Campbell Soup Company said it plans to sell its Juice Bowl Products Inc. subsidiary and close a foreign plant. Campbell acquired Juice Bowl in 1982 to produce the company's tomato-based juices and expand the company's vegetable juice line. The Camden-based company said that Juice Bowl, based in Lakeland, Fla., was no longer needed.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Bulgarian Secret Police Said to Be Disbanded
abstract: LEAD: Bulgaria said today that the secret police had been disbanded.

headline: Pan Am Seeking Berlin Routes' Sale
abstract: LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation offered to sell its international routes to Berlin to Lufthansa, a spokesman for the West German airline said. According to a report in the daily West German newspaper Suddeutsche Zeitung, Pan Am initially offered the routes for $350 million. The offer was rejected, the paper said, and Pan

headline: China's Premier Urges Tighter Control
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Li Peng opened the annual session of China's legislature today with a call for tighter control on what he described as ''hostile elements at home.''

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Security Pacific Fills Main Position at Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation said yesterday that it had named Donald K. Johnson president and chief executive of Security Pacific Alliance Ltd., a holding company responsible for managing Security Pacific's international network of investment banking and brokerage affiliates.

headline: Some in U.S. Congress Kept From Nicaragua
abstract: LEAD: A group of conservative Republican members of Congress said today that the Nicaraguan Government had rejected their request to observe the national elections on Sunday.

headline: Britain Set For Linkage
abstract: LEAD: The European Community's Competition Commissioner, Sir Leon Brittan, said today that Britain had met the conditions for becoming a full member of the European Monetary System.

headline: U.S. Securities Prices Rebound
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities rebounded yesterday, continuing a recent pattern of highly erratic movement.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Moscow Is Reticent on Germanys
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union gave little prominence today to reports of the agreement reached in Ottawa by the four major World War II allies on a format for working out the reunification of Germany.

headline: In the Air Where the Martyrs Fell, A Question: Where To From Here?
abstract: LEAD: In Palace Square, where the worst of the fighting had taken place, the people came slowly across the cobblestones, huddled against the cold, as if a long hibernation had just ended.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   A Piece of the Pie for Each East German?
abstract: LEAD: Facing almost certain defeat in parliamentary elections on Sunday, the Government of Prime Minister Hans Modrow has proposed a fanciful plan to divvy up the property of the Communist state into 16 million equal shares, offering one share to each East German citizen.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Caucasus;   Irate Azerbaijanis Seize Radio Station
abstract: LEAD: Azerbaijanis blockaded government offices and seized a radio station in a Caspian Sea port, and Georgians demanding independence drove bureaucrats from their offices in the Caucasus, according to reports in Moscow today The turmoil coincided with a visit to Lithuania by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is trying to counter an independence drive in that

headline: Talking Business with Robert A. Stanger;   Real Estate Woe For Syndicators
abstract: LEAD: Last week's announcement that VMS Realty Partners, one of the nation's largest sellers of real estate partnerships, was suspending nonessential payments to outsiders provided further evidence of serious problems in the real estate syndication business.

headline: Kuwait Asks End of Quotas
abstract: LEAD: Kuwait's oil minister was quoted today as saying that OPEC's oil output quotas should be scrapped as soon as possible.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS:Advertising;   Moves at Family Media
abstract: LEAD: If, as it promises, Family Media Inc. restarts Taxi and Model magazines in the fall as controlled-circulation publications, the company will do so with an almost entirely new staff. Departing staff members at the magazines said several dozen people were dismissed last week. Only Mary Peacock, Model's editor in chief, and Sharri Jurmain, Model's publisher, have been retained for the new magazines, said Eileen Koslow, Family Media's promotions director.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Jews;   Soviet Rabbi Tells of the New Anti-Semitism
abstract: LEAD: An East German newspaper published an unusual interview today with the chief rabbi of Moscow, in which he expressed fears about rising anti-Semitism in the Soviet Union.

headline: Business Diary
abstract: LEAD:    COMPANIES       A New, More Subdued, Mood at Shearson Lehman       An era of daring and deal-making at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. undoubtedly ended Tuesday night with the resignation of Peter A. Cohen as chairman and chief executive. His replacement, Howard L. Clark Jr., has been chief financial officer at the American Express Company, Shearson's corporate parent.

headline: Top Operating Post Is Filled By Kemper
abstract: LEAD: Continuing a corporate reorganization that has paid off in the stock market, the Kemper Corporation yesterday named David B. Mathis president and chief operating officer among several other executive changes.

headline: Talking Deals;   What NBC Sees In Notre Dame
abstract: LEAD: EXCEPT for end-of-the-season bowl games, NBC has been shut out of the college football market since the 1960's. In one bold stroke last week, NBC filled that hole, luring the University of Notre Dame away from the other major football powers that have a deal with ABC, starting with the 1991 season.

headline: South Africa's New Era;   Attention Is Turning to the Obstacles To de Klerk's Plan for Major Change
abstract: LEAD: As South Africans began today to absorb the sweeping changes in the political landscape brought about by President F. W. de Klerk's far-reaching relaxation of political restrictions, attention among whites and blacks turned to some of the major obstacles that black groups have said stand in the way of the negotiations for ''a new democratic constitution'' that Mr.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.       Monday    None       Tuesday    Balance of Trade ... Jan.    Consumer Price Index ... Feb.       Wednesday    None       Thursday    None       Friday    Durable Goods ... Feb.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV DENIES PLAN TO QUIT POST
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today denied a report that he was considering resigning as Communist Party leader, saying it was the sort of ''groundless'' invention that typically precedes important party meetings like a critical one scheduled for next week on the party's future.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Angotti Wins Saab Account
abstract: LEAD: Saab-Scania of America Inc., the United States unit of the Swedish car maker, yesterday awarded its $25 million advertising account to Angotti, Thomas, Hedge. Saab selected the agency, best known for its work for Wild Turkey bourbon and Orangina soda, over two other finalists, Kirshenbaum & Bond and Slater Hanft Martin.

headline: Soviet Aide Welcomes Bush's Troop Proposal
abstract: LEAD: A Soviet spokesman today welcomed President Bush's proposals to reduce American and Soviet troop levels in Central Europe and said Moscow was ready to discuss them.

headline: Chrysler Workers Skeptical On Detroit Plant's Last Day
abstract: LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation shut the doors of its crumbling downtown Jefferson Avenue assembly plant for the last time today, amid an atmosphere of uncertainty among laid-off auto workers. The 3,500 workers are awaiting completion of a factory less than a mile from the old one, and many hope to get jobs there.

headline: World Steel Output Up
abstract: LEAD: World crude steel output rose to a record of 783.5 million metric tons in 1989, up five-tenths of 1 percent from 1988, the International Iron and Steel Institute said this week. The rise was led by developing countries, which increased output by 3.7 percent, to a record 100.9 million tons, from 97.3 million tons in 1988, the institute said.

abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: U.S. Opposing Bid by Gillette
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department said today that it planned to file an antitrust suit to block the Gillette Company's acquisition of the Wilkinson Sword wet razor blade business outside the European Community.

headline: Rumania Averted Massacre By Executions, Official Says
abstract: LEAD: A leading tactician of Rumania's Provisional Government said today that if Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife had not been swiftly executed last week the country might have endured ''a blood bath with hundreds of thousands of dead.''

headline: Your Money;   Knowing Rules On Charity Gifts
abstract: LEAD: Charitable donations provide one of the few tax deductions left largely intact in the huge overhaul of the nation's tax laws in recent years, an important consideration for the 85 percent of people who say they give.
