headline: Really Useful Plan in Doubt
abstract: LEAD: Stoll Moss Theaters Ltd., the entertainment company of the Australian businessman Robert Holmes a Court, said Friday that it had acquired a 6.61 percent stake in Really Useful Group P.L.C., threatening Andrew Lloyd Webber's plan to take the company private.

headline: Less Delay Encountered On Real Estate Inquiries
abstract: LEAD: Prospective buyers eventually encountered fewer delays today in telephone calls seeking to learn more about the thousands of single-family homes, apartments, office projects and other properties inherited by the Government from failed savings institutions and now being auctioned off.

headline: Korea in Uranium Pact
abstract: LEAD: The South Korean Government approved a plan on Monday that would allow the state-owned Korea Electric Power Corporation to import enriched uranium from the Soviet Union for nuclear power plants, an official said. The decision cleared the way for South Korea and the Soviet Union, which have no diplomatic relations, to begin cooperation in nuclear power.

headline: A Giant Sale By Uncle Sam
abstract: LEAD: The biggest real estate sale in American history is under way as the Federal Government acts on Administration orders to move quickly to dispose of properties taken over from failed savings and loan institutions. Last week the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency handling the dispositions, listed about 30,000 properties it had acquired since Sept.

headline: I Thought Software Was My Answer
abstract: LEAD: I got my first, and worst, tax headache of the year choosing a program to prepare the return.

abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: C.D.'s, Bank Funds Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as banks showed signs of pulling back on yields.

headline: A Big Chicago Realty Firm Stops Paying Some Bills
abstract: LEAD: One of the nation's largest real estate firms said today that many of its commercial properties were so troubled financially that it had no choice but to stop paying certain bills.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    Economic and Social Council       INTERGOVERNMENTAL OCEANOGRAPHIC COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Koreans Weigh Iran Role
abstract: LEAD: South Korea is encouraging its companies to help to complete a huge war-damaged Iranian petrochemical plant, a project abandoned by Japan, Energy Ministry officials said last week. They said the Minister of Energy and Resources, Lee Bong Suh, had held talks with Iranian officials on a possible role for South Korean companies in the project in a recent trip to Teheran.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Larry Cole, United States media director of Ogilvy & Mather, and Fran Devereux, United States personnel director, have been named executive vice presidents.

headline: Soviet Georgia Wants Talks on Independence
abstract: LEAD: The parliament of the Soviet republic of Georgia today condemned its forcible annexation to the Soviet Union more than a half-century ago and demanded talks on the restoration of its independence, a local press agency reported.

headline: New President Of Lane Bryant
abstract: LEAD: Cheryl Nido Turpin was named president this week of Lane Bryant, the 720-store division of the Limited Inc. Lane Bryant is the country's largest retailer of special-size women's apparel.

headline: California Fights Utilities' Merger
abstract: LEAD: Saying the proposed merger between the San Diego Gas and Electric Company and the Southern California Edison Company was not in the public interest, Attorney General John Van de Kamp of California announced that his office would try to block the merger. Mr. Van de Kamp cited five reasons for opposing the merger, including contentions it would violate antitrust laws, thwart public regulation by creating a large and powerful utility and deprive the San

headline: Lin Expecting Loss in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The Lin Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it expects a net loss for the fourth quarter because of the costs of its settlement with the BellSouth Corporation after its merger agreement with the telephone company was canceled.      In a press release, Lin, a New

headline: Israel in Transition: Shamir Does All
abstract: LEAD: As Israel struggles to form a new government over a period that could last weeks or months, Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir will be a very busy man.

headline: Seventh Avenue Suppliers Are Breathing a Little Easier
abstract: LEAD: Only the most perceptive and dedicated shopper would have found Bloomingdale's lacking in goods yesterday. And on Seventh Avenue, there was a sense of relief one day after the American retailing units of the Campeau Corporation filed for bankruptcy, with suppliers getting ready to ship goods normally to such stores as Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Jordan

headline: World Markets;   Bullish, but Just Barely, on Gold
abstract: LEAD: ''So,'' you ask, ''where is the price of gold going?'' ''Up,'' say the gold prognosticators, the gold bugs. This is the beginning of a new bull market.

abstract: LEAD:          Companies

headline: Solzhenitsyn's Conditions
abstract: LEAD: Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn has promised to return to the Soviet Union but only when his once-reviled books are freely available, the cellist Mstislav Rostropovich, a close friend of the Nobel-prize winning author, said today.

headline: Pratt Order Placed By Singapore Air
abstract: LEAD: In a deal potentially worth $2.2 billion, Singapore Airlines has placed orders and options for 234 PW4000 Pratt & Whitney engines, the jet-engine maker and the airline announced. The orders come on the heels of a record-breaking $12 billion year for Pratt in 1989 and represent ''the largest single order for the PW4000 on record,'' a Pratt spokesman, David

headline: G.N.P. Rate For Late '89 Put at 0.9%
abstract: LEAD: The nation's economy grew at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of nine-tenths of 1 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989, somewhat stronger than the Commerce Department had initially estimated, but still the weakest quarterly performance since 1986, even allowing for last year's long strike at the Boeing

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    COMPANIES       Drexel Burnham Lambert paid bonuses totaling hundreds of millions of dollars to executives shortly before its parent filed for bankruptcy, Wall Street executives said. [Page A1.]      First Boston has arranged to get money from several affiliates by selling some bridge loans. Company executives said the move was intended to provide greater liquidity.

headline: Peace Plan Critic Is Elected President in Costa Rica
abstract: LEAD: Rafael Calderon Jr., a critic of the Central American peace efforts of President Oscar Arias Sanchez, was elected Sunday to succeed Mr. Arias, according to nearly complete returns.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Allegheny Power System Inc., New York, a utility holding company, named Stanley I. Garnett 2d chief financial officer. He replaces Alan J. Noia, who becomes executive vice president of Allegheny's Potomac Edison Company unit.

headline: Carnation Shifts Shops, Plans Interpublic Moves
abstract: LEAD: Two weeks after assigning the consumer advertising account for its infant nutritional products to McCann-Erickson in Los Angeles, the Carnation Company has taken the professional advertising for the products away from McCann Healthcare Advertising. Carnation, a subsidiary of Nestle S.A., has moved that portion of the account to M.E.D.

headline: Ms. Magazine Prepares For a Life Without Ads
abstract: LEAD: If Ms. was the magazine that defined feminism, can the new Ms. magazine, scheduled to appear in June, be described as post-feminist?

headline: Allegheny Selling Stake in Titanium
abstract: LEAD: Allegheny International Inc. reached an agreement to sell its interest in the Titanium Metals Corporation of America to the Baroid Corporation. Allegheny said Baroid, based in Houston, would pay $50 million for about 30 percent of Titanium Metal's outstanding stock and for a $3.25 million note to be paid by the metal company.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Campbell-Mithun Buys Drossman Lehmann
abstract: LEAD: Drossman Lehmann Marino, a seven-year-old New York agency known for its application of marketing creativity to packaged goods, has been acquired by Campbell-Mithun-Esty, the Saatchi & Saatchi unit that has been trying to re-establish itself after some executive shuffling and client defections.

headline: G.M.A.C. President Started at the Bottom
abstract: LEAD: William J. Lovejoy got his start with the General Motors Acceptance Corporation repossessing cars in Brooklyn 28 years ago. Yesterday, he was named president of the giant financing organization.

headline: Real Estate;   An Addition To Newark's Downtown
abstract: LEAD: DOWNTOWN Newark has a striking addition to its evolving skyline, the $74 million Newark Legal Center. The structure, which was completed last month and got its first tenant this month, was built to house law firms and keep them in the city.

headline: U.S. Aide Hints at a Deal If the General Tells All
abstract: LEAD: Federal prosecutors insisted today that they would prevail in a trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but a senior Administration official said the Government would be prepared to discuss a negotiated settlement if the deposed Panamanian leader provided detailed information about international drug trafficking activities.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Job for Lintas
abstract: LEAD: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Corporation awarded the account for its Consumer Specialty division lines of personal and home care products to Lintas:New York. The account, which bills an estimated $10 million, was formerly handled by Chiat/Day/Mojo and Campbell-Mithun-Esty.

headline: Marshall Field's
abstract: LEAD: The JMB Realty Corporation is negotiating with the First Chicago Corporation's new merchant banking group and top management at the Marshall Field's & Company department stores to make a joint bid for the retailer, according to a report in Crain's Chicago Business. The group seeking to buy Marshall Field's, which has been offered for sale by Britain's B.A.T.

headline: Fund Agency Acquired
abstract: LEAD: The American Express Company said Monday that its unit for processing information for mutual funds had acquired a mutual-fund transfer agency from the Mellon Bank Corporation. The Boston-based American Express unit, Shareholder Services Group Inc., acquired Mellon Mutal Fund Services Group for an undisclosed price.

headline: I.M.F. Is Asked To Sell Gold
abstract: LEAD: The United States asked the International Monetary Fund today to sell $1.2 billion worth of its gold to give 11 of the world's poorest countries a chance to pay debts.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Victor in East Germany Now Says He's Ready to Head Government
abstract: LEAD: Lothar de Maiziere, chairman of the Christian Democratic Union, which won the parliamentary elections on Sunday, ended five days of uncertainty today by declaring his readiness to head East Germany's first freely chosen and non-Communist Government.

headline: Market Place;   Fewer Companies Lifting Dividends
abstract: LEAD: THE economy may not be in a recession, but more and more companies are acting as though they think it may enter one. They are doing that by forgoing dividend increases that might have been made in other years.

headline: Morgan Stanley Net Jumps; Shearson Has a Slim Profit
abstract: LEAD: Defying the downturn on Wall Street, the Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that it had a substantial jump in profits in the fourth quarter and for the year.

headline: Hungarians Will Again Fly Soviet Jews to Israel
abstract: LEAD: The Hungarian state airline will resume flights of Soviet Jews to Israel that were suspended last week after the carrier received threats from Arab fundamentalists, the state press agency reported today.

headline: Publisher at Scribner's
abstract: LEAD: Barbara Grossman has been named publisher of Charles Scribner's Sons, effective Jan. 29, the company announced Wednesday. She is currently a senior editor at Crown Publishers, where she has worked for eight years. The current Scribner's publisher, Robert Stewart, will have his own imprint at Scribner's and will be a senior editorial vice president of the adult trade division of the Macmillan Publishing Company, of which Scribner's is an imprint.

headline: COMPANY NEWS Stride Rite Rejects $32-a-Share Bid
abstract: LEAD: The Stride Rite Corporation announced it had rejected a $900 million takeover bid from a group of investors, declaring the company would best be served by pursuing an independent strategy for growth. Stride Rite, the leading children's shoe maker in the country, received the $32-a-share offer in December from a group led by Walsh, Greenwood & Company, a Greenwich, Conn., investment concern.

headline: Top Suppliers of Weaponry
abstract: LEAD: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is still the nation's biggest military contractor, but Tenneco Inc. has plummeted from fourth to 21st on the Defense Department's list of arms suppliers, the Pentagon said today.

headline: Italian Bank in Iraq Accord
abstract: LEAD: Italy's largest state bank, Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, which was stunned last August by the discovery that a branch had made $3 billion in unauthorized loans to Iraq, has struck a deal with Baghdad for two-thirds of the money.

headline: YOUR TAXES: Taxpayers' Savvy Strategies;   FINDING THE CASH FOR A NEW BUSINESS
abstract: LEAD: LESTER D. MORAN, who left his job as vice president of Bloomingdale's Dallas store last year, put the tax laws to work for him to help get the cash flow needed to start his own company.

headline: Anheuser-Busch's Campaign Against Abusive Drinking
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Nuns Died in Contra Ambush, Rights Group Says
abstract: LEAD: An investigation by Americas Watch, the New York-based human rights group, has concluded that contras were responsible for the deaths of two Roman Catholic nuns whose car was attacked on a remote Nicaraguan highway on Jan. 1.

headline: Bull to DDB Needham
abstract: LEAD: The French computer company Groupe Bull has awarded its new corporate advertising account to DDB Needham France. The image-building account, which will cover North America, Europe and Southeast Asia, will have billings of $10 million. The other finalists for the account were TBWA, Publicis and HDM.

headline: Excerpts From Remarks by Gorbachev Before Central Committee of Party
abstract: LEAD: Following are excerpts from remarks by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev yesterday to the Central Committee of the Soviet Communist Party, as provided by the English-language service of the Soviet press agency Tass:       A Pivotal Gathering

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LEAD:    MONDAY: Whittle Communications begins its Channel One classroom news program.    USX and two union leaders go on trial in Birmingham, Ala., on charges that USX gave pensions to union officials in return for contract concessions.       TUESDAY: The Senate takes up a clean-air bill. The House Banking Committee holds a hearing on the Federal takeover of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association.

headline: Greenspan Sees Modest Growth In the Economy
abstract: LEAD: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board and the dominant force in economic policy making, told Congress today that the economy's ''weakest point may have passed'' and that the nation could expect ''moderate economic expansion'' this year.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Atlas Citron's First Client
abstract: LEAD: Atlas Citron Haligman & Bedecarre, the San Francisco agency formed earlier this month by four executives from Hal Riney & Partners, has picked up its first client.

headline: Manama Journal;   Atop High Horses, Neighbors Again Cross Swords
abstract: LEAD: A soccer-tournament emblem depicting two horses that symbolize an old military setback for Saudi Arabia has caused a long-simmering feud between Saudis and Kuwaitis to explode.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Colgate-Palmolive Co., the consumer products company, said 6.3 million shares, or 96 percent of the outstanding shares of common stock, had been tendered in its $14-a-share offer for Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc., Fort Collins, Colo., a health care company.

headline: A.T.&T. Sues MCI; Says Rival Switched Clients
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a lawsuit yesterday charging its main rival, the MCI Communications Corporation, with ''unfair and deceptive'' marketing practices and with switching some of A.T.&T.'s residential customers over to MCI's long-distance network without the consumers' consent.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Radio Deals By Evergreen
abstract: LEAD: The Evergreen Media Corporation, a privately held radio company, agreed today to acquire a station and a statewide network in Texas for $58.5 million in cash and debt.      Evergreen is purchasing

headline: Bowie Kuhn Is Said to Be In Hiding
abstract: LEAD: Bowie K. Kuhn, the former Commissioner of Baseball, is said to be somewhere in Florida, but not for spring training. In fact, a New York bank and several of his former law partners charged that he was hiding from the bankruptcy of the defunct law firm that bore his name.

headline: Zubki Duze Journal;   To Market, to Market: How Will Garden Grow?
abstract: LEAD: Jan Kitlinski's 30-acre farm is undeniably primitive, with a horse-drawn cart that lugs coal to his home and dozens of squawking fowl wandering about the bare-earth front yard.

headline: Reagan Aide Denies Report Of Talk at East Berlin Rally
abstract: LEAD: A spokesman for former President Ronald Reagan said today there was no basis for a report by the East German press agency Wednesday that Mr. Reagan would speak at a political rally in East Berlin in support of a small grouping of liberal, centrist parties.

headline: 5 Arrests in Ghana Plot
abstract: LEAD: Five men, including three military officers, were arrested after trying to destroy evidence linking them to a reported attempt to assassinate Flight Lieut. Jerry Rawlings, the Ghananian leader, the Ministry of Defense said today. The action followed the arrest of seven officers in November on charges of planning to kill Lieutenant Rawlings.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Kwikset Corporation, a manufacturer of locks and keys, to Eisaman, Johns & Laws, Los Angeles.

headline: Egyptian and Syrian Leaders Meet With Qaddafi in Libya
abstract: LEAD: In their first encounter since their countries ended a 12-year rift in December, President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt and President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met today in Libya, the official Libyan news agency said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Needham in Canada
abstract: LEAD: DDB Needham, a unit of the Omnicom Group, has increased its presence in Canada through the acquisition of Carder Gray Advertising of Toronto, which it will merge with DDB Needham Canada. The new agency, to be called Carder Gray DDB Needham Advertising, will have billings of $85 million, with $55 million of that coming from Carder Gray.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Atlas Corp., Denver, a mining company, appointed Francis M. Ricci chief financial officer.

headline: Economic Scene;   Blue-Collar Blues: Who Is to Blame?
abstract: LEAD: ARE you better or worse off than you were four years ago, asked Ronald Reagan in 1980. But George Bush's image-makers chose not to press the rhetorical point in his Presidential campaign, and for good reason.

headline: Bill Would Curb Disclosure Of Phone Caller's Number
abstract: LEAD: Responding to concern that a new telephone service is an invasion of privacy - it discloses the phone number of the caller to the party being called - legislation was introduced in the Senate yesterday to give callers the right to block their numbers from being seen.

headline: Bush Meets Prague Leader
abstract: LEAD: After meeting with President Vaclav Havel, President Bush waived some restrictions on trade with Prague. Mr. Havel will address Congress today at 11 A.M. Page A10.

headline: Bofors to Cut Jobs
abstract: LEAD: Bofors A.B., Sweden's largest weapons producer, will cut its work force by 500 because of falling orders from the Swedish military. The decision, which is to take effect July 1, follows a reduction last October of 1,300 workers. Bofors had counted on continued orders from India, but they were suspended amid allegations that Bofors paid bribes to secure a $1.3 billion artillery sale in 1986.

headline: A Tax Ruling Aids Holders Of Rights Under 'Poison Pill'
abstract: LEAD: Shareholders no longer have to worry about paying taxes at the time they receive rights to buy shares under ''poison pill'' plans, a popular device used by companies seeking to prevent hostile takeovers.

headline: Jerusalem Post Fills 2 Jobs Left Vacant by Resignations
abstract: LEAD: The Jerusalem Post has named a new managing editor and magazine editor in the first replacements of high-ranking staff members who resigned last week in a dispute over the newspaper's editorial policy.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Marketing Campaign By Airborne Express
abstract: LEAD: Airborne Express, which has refrained from active participation in the advertising wars fought by its rivals the United Parcel Service and the Federal Express Corporation, is joining the fray, with Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley as its new marketing partner. The $15 million San Francisco agency would not disclose billings for the account.

headline: Nicaragua Approaches an Election That May Rise or Fall on Its Fairness
abstract: LEAD: With less than a month to go before Nicaragua's elections, leaders of the governing Sandinista Front and their opponents are entering the final phase of what all sides say will be a decisive referendum on a decade of Sandinista rule.

headline: Through the Form 1040 Step by Step
abstract: LEAD: Top tax professionals work with their clients year round to draw up financial plans tailored to their goals and means, taking advantage of whatever deductions and opportunities are allowed under the nation's tax laws. Thus, studying an expertly prepared return can help taxpayers understand tax strategies, as well as aid in organizing records, even if they, too, turn to a professional to fill out the forms.

headline: Rhone-Poulenc Link With Rorer Detailed
abstract: LEAD: Announcing a definitive agreement to merge their drug businesses, Rhone-Poulenc S.A. and the Rorer Group said yesterday that Rhone-Poulenc would put up $1.68 billion in cash.

headline: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;   Baker and West German Envoy Discuss Reunification Issues
abstract: LEAD: With the momentum seeming to build for unification of the two Germanys, the West German Foreign Minister, Hans-Dietrich Genscher, met today with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to coordinate positions on the German question before Mr. Baker meets with Soviet officials next week.

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article last Sunday about expenditures at Merrill Lynch & Company misstated the location of the company's executive offices. They are in the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan.

headline: U.S. Says Fire at Libya Arms Plant May Be a Hoax
abstract: LEAD: Bush Administration officials said today that a chemical weapons plant in Libya might still be functioning and that they were investigating the possibility that a fire reported at the installation two weeks ago was part of a hoax engineered by Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's leader.

headline: Bread, Up 38%, Gas, Up 100%, But Still the Poles Are Hopeful
abstract: LEAD: The Government's economic program to move Poland toward capitalism went into full force today, and Poles were shaken but optimistic as bread prices jumped by 38 percent and coal prices for households by 600 percent.

headline: Sihanouk Sees 'Stumbling Blocks' to a Settlement
abstract: LEAD: Prince Norodom Sihanouk said today that he was pessimistic about the chances for a settlement soon in Cambodia, and he accused Vietnam of moving its border to seize Cambodian territory.

headline: Man Slain in South Africa Town Where Police Fired on Marchers
abstract: LEAD: A young schoolteacher died on a quiet street corner in this black township today, becoming another statistic in a confrontation between the police and inhabitants that began Monday when the police fired on a crowd of demonstrators.

headline: MCI Mexican Link
abstract: LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation and Telefonos de Mexico S.A. signed an agreement to provide voice and other telecommunications services between the United States and Mexico. MCI, whose international division is based here, and Telefonos de Mexico said they expected to begin providing voice service early next week.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Havel Plan for Summit Site
abstract: LEAD: President Vaclav Havel today offered Prague instead of Washington as the site of the next summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: Rethinking the Engineer Shortage
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Ranieri, Wilson Founder Quits
abstract: LEAD: Less than two years after helping to found Ranieri, Wilson & Company, a small, New York investment firm, Kendrick R. Wilson 3d will be stepping down as president and leaving the company.

headline: Off-Duty Israeli Soldier Is Stabbed in Jerusalem
abstract: LEAD: An off-duty Israeli soldier was stabbed as she walked along a narrow street in Jerusalem's Old City today, and 30 Palestinians were detained for questioning, the police said.

headline: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;   A Worried Washington Is Keeping Its Distance
abstract: LEAD: Soviet experts in the Bush Administration were scrambling late today for information on the fighting in Baku between the Soviet Army and Azerbaijanis, which Administration experts said seemed the inevitable next step in the drama in the Caucasus.

headline: Nicaragua Rebels Agree to Start Disbanding Troops in Honduras
abstract: LEAD: The Nicaraguan rebels agreed today to disband their forces in Honduras by April 20, five days before the inauguration of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro of Nicaragua.

headline: OPEC Chief Sees Demand Keeping Prices High
abstract: LEAD: Fewer oil shipments from the Soviet Union to Eastern Europe have led to higher demand for oil from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. That should keep world prices above $18 a barrel this year, the head of OPEC said today.

headline: Patents;   New Jump Rope Offers Greater Control
abstract: LEAD: Priscilla Burton, a retired secretary in Providence, R.I., liked the aerobic exercise of jumping rope but wanted a rope she could swing more slowly and with less stress.

headline: Bank Lockout in Sweden
abstract: LEAD: Financial business in Sweden virtually ground to a halt today after banks shut their doors to the public and locked out about 50,000 employees in a dispute over demands for more pay.

headline: Political Unrest Abroad Raises Oil-Supply Fears
abstract: LEAD: Political unrest and food riots shaking major oil-producing countries, including the Soviet Union and some OPEC nations, may lead to significant worldwide oil shortages in this decade.

headline: Arabs to Assail Israel on Soviet Jews
abstract: LEAD: Arab nations are planning a major diplomatic campaign to warn the world that the expected arrival of hundreds of thousands of Soviet Jews in Israel over the next few years threatens to increase tension in the Middle East and reduce the chances of peace.

headline: Patents: Hunt Goes On For a Better Mousetrap;   A Maple Concentrate
abstract: LEAD: A simpler approach to bait shyness, using an artificial maple concentrate, has been developed by John P. Hollis of San Antonio. Mr. Hollis, the retired owner of a pest control service, said maple was one of the more persistently successful natural attractants he has encountered. His artificial maple is a new composition consisting of saccharin and alcohol tinctures containing coffee, vanilla and extracts from several other plants.

headline: B-Schools Out of Step on the Environment
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Aoun Attack on Rival Stronghold Sets Off Artillery and Tank Duels
abstract: LEAD: More artillery and tank battles broke out in Christian East Beirut today as army troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun moved against strongholds of rival Christian militiamen led by Samir Geagea.

headline: Tektronix to Cut 600 Employees
abstract: LEAD: Tektronix Inc. said it would lay off 600 employees by late May because an anticipated sales increase had not materialized. Most of the layoffs will occur in the test and measurement group, the electronics company said. The group manufactures various products, including Tektronix's original product line, oscilloscopes.

headline: 7 Days Magazine Is for Sale
abstract: LEAD: Just two years after it was started, 7 Days magazine, which has amassed a small but dedicated following among Manhattan's trend-setters, is up for sale.

headline: S.A.S.'s Chile Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Scandinavian Airlines System said the Chilean Government had approved its acquisition of 30 percent of the Lan Chile airline and an increase of its stake in the carrier to 35 percent later this year. S.A.S. said the parties had agreed that S.A.S. would occupy three of the nine seats on the Lan Chile board.

headline: CAMPEAU BANKERS ARE SAID TO AGREE TO NEW DEADLINE
abstract: LEAD: The bank syndicate that lent $2.34 billion to the American retailing subsidiaries of the Campeau Corporation has decided to give them four more days to meet a deadline for providing assurances that their operations are solvent, banking and retailing executives said yesterday.

headline: Visitors to U.S. Expected To Increase 75% in Decade
abstract: LEAD: The number of visitors to the United States will increase more than 75 percent by the end of the decade from last year's 38 million visitors, the Commerce Department said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1990
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Military Division Chief Promoted at FMC Corp.
abstract: LEAD: The FMC Corporation, a chemical producer and maker of military equipment, has named Robert N. Burt as its president.

headline: U.S. Recalls Its Ambassador In Guatemala Over Slayings
abstract: LEAD: The United States Ambassador to Guatemala has been temporarily recalled in a protest at the Guatemalan Government's failure to curb politically motivated killings, the State Department said today.

headline: Upheaval in the East: The Dossier;   Rumanian Finds His File: 12 Years of Being Watched
abstract: LEAD: When Doru Pavaloiae, an economist, met an old classmate on Lipscani Street here at a time when Nicolae Ceausescu was still in power in Rumania, the two men talked, and in the conversation he let slip that he would like to leave the country.

headline: Manila Arrests Fugitive General For Role in December Rebellion
abstract: LEAD: The highest-ranking officer involved in the latest attempt to overthrow President Corazon C. Aquino was arrested today, the Philippine military authorities said.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   Prague Wants Soviet Pullout by Year's End
abstract: LEAD: Czechoslovakia said today that it will push for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from its territory by the end of the year while its own army tries to re-establish an independent identity after years of control by Moscow.

headline: Israeli Warplanes Hit Guerrillas Near Sidon
abstract: LEAD: Israeli fighter jets destroyed a southern Lebanon base of a radical Palestinian guerrilla group today, in the second such air strike in a week, the police said.

headline: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East Germany Agrees to Pay Reparations to the Jewish Victims of the Nazis
abstract: LEAD: East Germany, which has long refused to accept responsibility for the crimes of the Nazis against the Jews, has for the first time agreed to pay reparations to Jewish victims, the World Jewish Congress said yesterday.

headline: Abitibi Is Set to Raise Newsprint Price by $35
abstract: LEAD: North America's largest producer of newsprint, Abitibi-Price Inc., has said it wants to increase the price for the low-grade paper by $35 a metric ton, to $685. But analysts said yesterday that soft demand and ample supply would allow newspaper publishers to shift to other suppliers, making it unlikely that

headline: An Israeli Paper Says Jews Were Released And Ceausescu Paid
abstract: LEAD: Israel paid thousands of dollars in cash to Nicolae Ceausescu for every Rumanian Jew he allowed to emigrate for two decades, an Israeli newspaper reported.

headline: Chiang Mai Journal;   Verdant Land Where Victoria Stares and Stares
abstract: LEAD: Amid the many gracious temples of Chiang Mai, still one of the most charming cities of booming Thailand, there is a bit of consecrated ground presided over not by the Buddha but by an equally plump representation of a more earthly suzerainty, Queen Victoria.

headline: A New Name: Greyhound Dial
abstract: LEAD: Tired of being confused with the bus company it sold off in 1987, the Greyhound Corporation changed its name yesterday to the Greyhound Dial Corporation.

headline: Praising Big Blue
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: On 59th St., The Topic Is a Hot One
abstract: LEAD: The Campeau Corporation's decision to put its American department stores into Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings was topic No. 1 on both sides of the counters at Bloomingdale's yesterday.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: LEAD: The Mutual Funds table last Sunday gave incorrect headings for two columns showing percentage change. One column was for January, not December, and the other was for 1990, not 1989.

headline: All About/Composite Materials;   Light and Tough, New Materials Head for the Mass Marketing Stage
abstract: LEAD: From the outside, today's automobiles still appear to be nearly all steel. But about 8 percent of their weight consists of composites -strong, light combinations of complementary substances. Bumpers, doors, body panels and station wagon tailgates are all commonly made from these materials. Ten years ago, the composite content was less than 2 percent; by the year 2000, some producers of composites contend, their materials will predominate.

headline: Seoul and North Korea Spar Over Tunnel Under the DMZ
abstract: LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo attacked North Korea today over a tunnel found under the border between the countries, and he said Pyongyang was risking its own destruction.

headline: Sweden's Socialist Government Resigns
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Ingvar Carlsson submitted the resignation of his Social Democratic Government today after losing a vote in Parliament on an economic rescue bill.

headline: Sugar Policy Is Debated
abstract: LEAD: Members of the House Ways and Means Committee called today for revision of the United States sugar program, saying the current system costs taxpayers and sugar-exporting nations billions of dollars each year.

headline: Jet Engine Companies Add to Ties
abstract: LEAD: In a move to spread costs and assure access to European markets, the United Technologies Corporation said yesterday that it would tighten its links to Daimler-Benz A.G., the big West German auto, aerospace and electronics manufacturer.

headline: BLAMING U.S., CUBA SUSPENDS PULLOUT
abstract: LEAD: Blaming the United States for a rebel attack on Cuban troops in Angola, Havana said today that it was temporarily suspending its troop withdrawal.

headline: A FINANCIAL CRISIS MAY FORCE DREXEL TO SEEK A MERGER
abstract: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the once-powerful Wall Street investment house whose fortunes rose and fell with the high-risk ''junk bond'' market, announced yesterday that its worsening troubles had forced it to seek new funds or a merger partner, heightening concerns about the firm's stability.

headline: Treasury Notes and Bonds Steady
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury bonds and other fixed-income securities were mainly unchanged yesterday in a shortened pre-holiday weekend trading session.

headline: Ritual of Political Cleansing in Japan
abstract: LEAD: Looking gaunt and speaking in a hoarse voice, a politician viewed as among the most likely to become the next Prime Minister of Japan is reminding audiences that newspapers were all but writing his obituary last year.

headline: Mach 3 Passengers? No Simple Formula
abstract: LEAD: By about the year 2010, it may be possible for globe-trotters to fly from Los Angeles to Tokyo at two or three times the speed of sound - cutting the nine-hour trip to three or four hours - and pay only slightly more than they would for a ticket on a Boeing 747.

headline: Mexico and Vatican Move Toward Restoring Ties
abstract: LEAD: After more than a century of estrangement, the Mexican Government and the Vatican are suddenly moving toward re-establishing formal diplomatic relations and are also having informal talks on restoring some civil rights to the Roman Catholic Church here.

headline: U.S. Resists Japan Plea To Aid Yen
abstract: LEAD: Japan asked the United States today for help in checking the fall of the yen, but the United States went along only part way, arguing that the reasons for the yen's weakness are largely Japanese and that there is little Washington can do.

headline: Slump in Securities Industry
abstract: LEAD: Four senior securities executives told Congress today that their industry was in a period of economic decline, but said only minor legislative changes were needed.

headline: Swiss Insurer Buys Unit of Reliance
abstract: LEAD: The Winterthur Swiss Insurance Company, one of Switzerland's largest insurers, said today that it had acquired a unit of the Philadelphia-based Reliance Insurance Company for $630 million in cash.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Kremlin Turns Conciliatory Toward Azerbaijani Group
abstract: LEAD: The Gorbachev Government took a more conciliatory tone today toward the Azerbaijani Popular Front, saying it undoubtedly included ''healthy forces'' with whom occupation authorities might negotiate.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Azerbaijan;   Story of Action in Baku Is Framed in Questions
abstract: LEAD: Between the tight rationing of official information and the unchecked explosion of rumors presented as fact, the outside world can still claim only an incomplete picture of what happened Saturday when Soviet troops rolled into Baku.

headline: Answering the Car Phone When Away From the Car
abstract: LEAD: At the Consumer Electronics Show here this week, a company introduced a portable handset system that allows people with cellular car phones to receive calls up to 1,000 feet from their vehicles.

headline: 2d Round of Global Bonds Is Priced by the World Bank
abstract: LEAD: The World Bank yesterday priced its second $1.5 billion issue of global bonds in nearly five months.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   SANDINISTAS MOVE TO CLAIM PROPERTY AND GAIN IMMUNITY
abstract: LEAD: With less than two months before they are scheduled to hand over power to the opposition, Sandinista leaders are taking steps to enact sweeping changes in Nicaragua's laws, giving away large amounts of Government property and declaring immunity for all unprosecuted crimes that may have been committed during their 10-year rule.

headline: Japan Now Ahead in Nuclear Power, Too
abstract: LEAD: Japan is rapidly outpacing the United States in the field of nuclear power, American experts in Government, academia and the utility industry say.

headline: Syrians and Lebanese Troops Clash as a Cease-Fire Falters
abstract: LEAD: Syrian troops clashed today with Lebanese Army units loyal to the Christian general, Michel Aoun, in the first such encounter since an Arab-brokered cease-fire last September ended six months of fighting between the two sides.

headline: Perkin-Elmer Sells One Chip Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Perkin-Elmer Corporation yesterday took the first step toward spinning off its troubled semiconductor business by selling its electron-beam-technology division. The buyer is a management team backed by six United States corporations, including I.B.M. and Perkin-Elmer itself.
