headline: Account
abstract: LEAD: * Nature Organics Inc., to Rutkin Costello McCullam Whitley, with a budget of $1.2 million.

headline: Beijing Avoids New Missile Sales Assurances
abstract: LEAD: The United States has sought but failed to obtain additional assurances from China that Beijing will not sell medium-range missiles to the Middle East, Administration officials said today.

headline: Puberty Rite for Girls Is Bitter Issue Across Africa
abstract: LEAD: In the sprawling cattle country of southwestern Kenya, a 12-year-old girl walked bravely along a dirt track, swathed in a brightly colored cloth and carrying an open black umbrella. Shilling notes dangled from her headgear, framing her face, as village people dressed in tree branches clapped and sang to her.

headline: Phillips to Take A Write-Down
abstract: LEAD: The Phillips Petroleum Company will take a $280 million after-tax write-down on its offshore California investments that will cause the company's fourth-quarter earnings to plunge, company officials said. The investments include the oil-rich Point Arguello field off Santa Barbara, which could hold as many as 500 million barrels of oil.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * DIG Acquisition Corp. said it would extend until Friday its $30-a-share tender offer for all common shares of Di Giorgio Corp., San Francisco, a food and consumer products company.

headline: Patents;   Using Sound Waves To Break Stones in Body
abstract: LEAD: William S. Filler, a former research physicist with the Navy's Surface Warfare Center, has patented a system using sound waves to break up kidney stones and gallstones without surgery.

headline: Pollution Control Bonds For Texas
abstract: LEAD: The Matagorda County Navigational District No. 1 of Texas yesterday tentatively priced a $50 million tax-exempt bond issue due 2020 through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Market Place;   Industry Attack On Market Study
abstract: LEAD: EXECUTIVES in the securities and futures industry have mounted an intense lobbying campaign to change the conclusions of a draft report by an independent Congressional agency that questions some fundamental aspects of the nation's financial system.

headline: Talking Deals;   It's Slow Going In Eastern Europe
abstract: LEAD: THE Samsonite Corporation, the world's biggest luggage producer, has been working on a deal for six months to make luggage in Hungary for sale in Western Europe. Production is already under way, even though details of a joint venture with a Government cooperative are far from complete.

headline: U.A.W. Faces Test at Mazda Plant
abstract: LEAD: The auto industry is closely watching a dispute between the Mazda Motor Corporation and the United Automobile Workers union over the use of temporary employees.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   The Standoff In Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: The Kremlin's decision to try to draw a veil over Lithuania's independence crisis by ridding the republic of foreign journalists amounts to a tribute of sorts to the increasingly fragile presidency of Vytautas Landsbergis.      It showed the depth of

headline: IN DEFENSE OF NUCLEAR POWER.    YES IT IS CLEAN - AND NOT A SOURCE FOR WEAPONRY
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Preferred Stock

headline: The Sandinista Machine vs. Avid Opponents
abstract: LEAD: Less than three weeks before national elections here, diplomats say the campaign has become a showdown between the organizational skills of the Sandinista Front and the disorganized but energetic rallies of Government opponents.

headline: The Executive Computer;   Can the Old Processing Technology Beat Back a Challenge?
abstract: LEAD: Some hot new processors still rely on Complex Instruction Set Computing. THE Series 6000 work stations introduced by the International Business Machines Corporation earlier this month clearly demonstrate the fundamental speed advantages of the technology called Reduced Instruction Set Computing. The RISC machines use a type of simplified processor chip that yields performance once found only among computers costing 10 to 100 times as much.

headline: 2 Die and 2 Are Lost in Alps As Snow Buries French Area
abstract: LEAD: Heavy snowfalls in the French Alps caused avalanches today that killed two people, and two other people were missing, the police said.

headline: Brazilian Loans Decline In International Trading
abstract: LEAD: The price of Brazilian debt has fallen since the country's new President, Fernando Collor de Mello, announced his tough economic program 12 days ago. But traders in the highly specialized market that deals with such debt say the decline is not a reflection of unhappiness with Mr. Collor's program.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Pro Bono
abstract: LEAD: * American Soviet Youth Orchestra, sponsored by the Conservatory of Music at Oberlin College, the Moscow State Conservatory and the Soviet Ministry of Culture, to Hal Riney & Partners.

headline: Jittery Over Junk Bonds, Wall Street Hits the Books
abstract: LEAD: Getting investors today to pony up for high-yield bonds will take more than a convincing sales pitch. In the wake of recent disasters in the ''junk bond'' market and the bankruptcy filing last week of Federated Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, Wall Street brokerages are having to respond to a new call by investors for more puncture-proof research.

headline: Turnover in Nicaragua;   Recovering From Injury
abstract: LEAD: In many photographs of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, the Nicaraguan President-elect appears on crutches or a wheelchair, because of a fractured right kneecap that she suffered in a fall in her home at midday on Jan. 2.      The injury was treated in

headline: Some East Germans See Their Hopes Eclipsed by Bonn's Ascendancy
abstract: LEAD: New Forum, the mass citizens' movement that played the leading role in the overthrow of Communist rule last autumn, has fallen from elation into dejection now that its victory appears complete.

headline: Shareholders' Suit Favors BTR's Bid
abstract: LEAD: A group of shareholders of the Norton Company filed a class-action lawsuit in favor of a $1.64 billion takeover offer by BTR P.L.C. of Britain. The group asked that Norton's management seek to ''maximize shareholder value'' in weighing the offer. Thomas Shapiro, a lawyer for the shareholders, declined to identify them or provide details about the size of their holdings in the Worcester,

headline: Deadline Set By the I.M.F.
abstract: LEAD: The International Monetary Fund extended a deadline today on talks for a new financing increase until June 30, but it said it hoped to fashion a deal in the next few weeks.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  7 Hired From Drexel To Bolster Jefferies
abstract: LEAD: Jefferies & Company, the Los Angeles-based brokerage subsidiary of the Jefferies Group, has moved to increase its activities in high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' by hiring seven former employees of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., including Marc Rapaport, a key executive at the collapsed firm.

headline: Sound Becomes the New Frontier for TV Ads
abstract: LEAD: A new Coca-Cola commercial probably has some television viewers thinking they are hearing things. At one point during the spot, chirping birds seemingly can be heard flying overhead while the wind whistles through the living room.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Top Officer Is Named At Detroit Edison
abstract: LEAD: The Detroit Edison Company said yesterday that John E. Lobbia will become chairman and chief executive in May when the current chairman, Walter J. McCarthy Jr., reaches mandatory retirement age, which is 65.

headline: Banks Given Order by U.S.
abstract: LEAD: A top Federal regulator ordered commercial bank officers today to correct promptly ''a significant number of fundamental deficiencies'' in their real estate lending operations.

headline: More Sallie Mae Floating Rates Set
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, is offering its second floating rate issue for the week.

headline: Illinois Tool Unit In Bid for Binks
abstract: LEAD: Illinois Tool Works Inc. said its Ransburg subsidiary had offered to acquire the Binks Manufacturing Company for $45 a share in cash or a combination of cash and Illinois tool stock, in a deal valued at $132.3 milion. Binks shares soared $10.75 today, to $43.75, in trading on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: Vancouver Journal;   Where Minorities Find Riches and Resentment
abstract: LEAD: When David Lam and his family arrived here as immigrants, friends back home gave him three months until he came to his senses and returned to Hong Kong.

headline: First Boston To Close Unit
abstract: LEAD: The First Boston Corporation said on Friday that it planned to close its listed fixed-income futures brokerage business and lay off the operation's 29 employees.      After Drexel Burnham

headline: Bush May Revive Plan for Warships Off Colombia
abstract: LEAD: At his meeting in Colombia on Thursday, President Bush is likely to try to revive a United States proposal to deploy Navy warships off South America to monitor drug-trafficking flights, senior Administration officials said today.

headline: West's Exhibits Bring The Leipzig Fair to Life
abstract: LEAD: The Leipzig Trade Fair, for decades a dull Communist showcase of East German industry, has been transformed this year into a bustling forum of East-West deal-making. With the recent democratic reforms in East Germany and hopes of strong growth fueled by the coming unification of the two Germanys, Western companies have flocked in record numbers to the one-week Leipzig fair, which began on

headline: Asarco Fights Sale Of Freeport Unit
abstract: LEAD: Asarco Inc. challenged the proposed sale of the Freeport-McMoran Inc.'s gold mining subsidiary to South African-controlled Minorco S.A. In a lawsuit filed in New York Supreme Court, Asarco said its interest in a joint venture with the Freeport-McMoran unit could be violated by the sale.

headline: Fighting Resumes in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of artillery shells rained down on most parts of the Christian enclave here today as fighting resumed between rival Christian forces, virtually shattering a cease-fire that began early this month.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:       Debt

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Burson-Marsteller Inc., New York, a public affairs and government relations firm, named Nancy Maloley a senior vice president in its Washington office.

headline: U S West Posted Increase Of 26.8% in Fourth Quarter
abstract: LEAD: U S West Inc., the regional telephone holding company based in Denver, said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profits rose 26.8 percent over the comparable 1988 period.

headline: Merrill Lynch Trims Staff at Research Unit
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had dismissed 10 of the 130 employees in its equity research department as part of a program to improve profitability by reducing costs.

headline: Profits at Anheuser-Busch Rise by 2.1% in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The Anheuser-Busch Companies, the country's largest brewer, said yesterday that fourth-quarter earnings rose 2.1 percent and that its profit for the year was up 7.2 percent.

headline: Taylor-Gordon Wins
abstract: LEAD: Six months after it resigned the $5 million Helmsley Hotel Corporation account over a fee dispute, Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company has returned to the hospitality field. The agency has won the account for the Vista International Hotel at the World Trade Center in New York. Billings for the new account, formerly at Albert Frank-Guenther Law, are projected at $1 million to $2 million.

headline: Colombians Choose Centrist To Run for President in May
abstract: LEAD: Voters chose a centrist today as the ruling Liberal Party's candidate in presidential elections scheduled for May, party officials said.

headline: 69 Die in Sudan Land Feud As Nomads Battle Farmers
abstract: LEAD: Arab nomads and tribal farmers clashed in the western Sudan in the latest outbreak of an ancient feud over grazing rights, killing 69 people and burning down 14 villages, the Sudan News Agency reported today.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   The Romanian Revolution Over, It's Back to Old Hatreds in Transylvania
abstract: LEAD: More than two months after a revolution that briefly united them, the Hungarians and the Romanians who live together in what is now Romanian Transylvania are once again locked in a centuries-old rivalry that is reviving nationalist fervor on both sides.

headline: Coca-Cola to Raise Dividend by 18%
abstract: LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company, enjoying a strong global beverage business, raised the quarterly dividend on its common stock by 18 percent and said its board would recommend a 2-for-1 stock split at its annual meeting. Coke's shares rose sharply in on the New York Stock Exchange today, closing at $69.50, up $2.375 each.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Hungary and Soviets See Pact
abstract: LEAD: After months of discussions, the Governments of Soviet Union and Hungary said today they had agreed to draft an accord quickly on a full withdrawal of Soviet troops.

headline: Upheaval in the East: The Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV GAINS SUPPORT IN RAUCOUS DEBATE ON ROLE OF PARTY, DELEGATES REPORT
abstract: LEAD: Communist Party leaders went through a raucous day of debate over their future today, with delegates at the closed-door session reporting a strong majority favoring the end of the party's power monopoly and pointing to the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe as the ultimate object lesson.

headline: State Elections in India Today
abstract: LEAD: In elections that are expected to test the political strength of Prime Minister V. P. Singh and the political survivability of his predecessor, Rajiv Gandhi, voters in eight Indian states are to choose state governments on Tuesday.

headline: Monsanto Shares Up Sharply On Hopes for Fat Substitute
abstract: LEAD: Even though frozen desserts made with Nutrasweet's new fat substitute will be in grocers' freezers this summer, the Monsanto Company subsidiary is unlikely to find itself gorging on profits for years.

headline: Fed Nominee Backs Policy On Inflation
abstract: LEAD: David W. Mullins Jr., the Bush Administration's first nominee to the Federal Reserve Board, testified today that he supports the central bank's current strategy of fighting inflation by keeping interest rates high.

headline: Judge in Jury Trial Orders Northrop to Halt TV Ads
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge presiding over a criminal fraud trial involving the Northrop Corporation has ordered the company temporarily to stop showing television commercials here because they could taint the impartiality of prospective jurors. The Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit in San Francisco later suspended the order, pending further review, a

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addendum
abstract: LEAD: The Block Group, New York, a public relations and promotional marketing firm, has merged with the graphics division of Everett Studios, White Plains. The new firm, Block Everett Nardizzi, will have offices in those cities and will be based in Stamford, Conn.

headline: Patents;   A WAtch to Ease Jet Lag
abstract: LEAD: Ross E. Mitchell, an inventor in Newtonville, Mass., obtained a patent this week for a watch to help travelers fight jet lag by making time fly. Mr. Mitchell noted that travelers arriving in a different time zone normally switched to the new time in an abrupt and disorienting way. His new watch is designed to smooth this transition by spreading the adjustment over the flight.

headline: Revival Bought With Tourist Dollars
abstract: LEAD: A small but growing number of American towns, no longer able to prosper from the industry, mining or farming that once defined them, are using imagination and ingenuity in hopes of snaring some of the tourist dollars that usually flow to big metropolitan hot spots.

headline: Son of Ex-President of Costa Rica Claims Victory in National Vote
abstract: LEAD: The 40-year-old son of a former president claimed victory in presidential elections today in Latin America's oldest democracy.

headline: Session Called on Soviet Chief's Role
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of the Soviet legislature voted today to convene an extraordinary session ''in the nearest future'' to expand the powers of the Soviet presidency, a post now held by Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

headline: Market Place;   Payout Increases Slumped in 1989
abstract: LEAD: THE end-of-the-year treat for shareholders of a dividend increase was less evident last year than at any time in nearly two decades.

headline: Company News;   Combined Net Off at SmithKline Beecham
abstract: LEAD: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. said yesterday that it was encountering delays in reaping the benefits of the trans-Atlantic merger that created the giant pharmaceuticals and household products company last July.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Public Policy Issues Draw Agency Man
abstract: LEAD: AN advertising man who once battled for the wallets of the wealthy on behalf of Mercedes-Benz will now be fighting for the hearts and minds of citizens concerned about drug cartels in Colombia.

headline: Iraq Pledge on Oil Quota
abstract: LEAD: Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalaby, pledged in remarks published Tuesday that Iraq was committed to its OPEC supply quota of 3.14 million barrels a day despite the expansion of its oil-shipping capacity. He told The Baghdad Observer that Iraq's export capacity was about 5 million barrels a day.

headline: Shell to Sell Methanol In California Program
abstract: LEAD: The Shell Oil Company said today that it would join Exxon, Chevron and ARCO in selling a methanol fuel in California as part of that state's program to test alternative fuels for automobiles.

headline: K Mart Will Accelerate Plan to Revamp Stores
abstract: LEAD: The K Mart Corporation announced today that it would speed up its previously announced $2.3 billion program to modernize its stores. The company said it would also broaden the program to include all of its 2,300 K Mart stores.

headline: Post for Nigel Lawson
abstract: LEAD: Nigel Lawson, who resigned abruptly as Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer in October, has been named a director of Barclays Bank P.L.C., the bank said today. Mr. Lawson, 57 years old, will continue as a Conservative Party Member of Parliament and also serve as a part-time adviser to the bank. Barclays declined to disclose how much he would be paid.

headline: South Africa Loosens Gag, and the Press Pipes Up
abstract: LEAD: When President F. W. de Klerk announced last month that the Government would release Nelson Mandela and legalize the African National Congress, he opened the door to another kind of liberty: freedom for South African newspapers, broadcasting outlets and book publishers to cover the country as they choose.

headline: Iranian Official Says All Hostages May Be Freed Within 10 Months
abstract: LEAD: Iran's First Deputy Foreign Minister said today that the chances of freedom for American and other Western hostages held in Lebanon have never been brighter. On the basis of his observations during a recent trip to Beirut, he predicted that they could be released within 10 months.

headline: PANAMA OFFICIALS SPLIT ON NORIEGA
abstract: LEAD: With the impasse over the fate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega entering its second week, the new President of Panama and his Attorney General disagreed today over whether to file charges against the deposed strongman or leave the question of his prosecution to the United States.

headline: Business Scene;   Learning to Invest In Eastern Europe
abstract: LEAD: SIFTING through Eastern Europe's startling developments, American corporations are slowly developing a strategy for investing in that part of the world - one that treats Eastern Europe as a source of low-cost labor and a platform for exporting products to rich Western Europe. Making consumer products for the hard-pressed Eastern Europeans is not, for

headline: Dow Climbs by 14.64; Tokyo Market Gains
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices advanced for the second straight session yesterday on slightly stepped-up volume.

headline: Lithuanians Cry 'Freedom!' On Eve of Gorbachev Visit
abstract: LEAD: A day before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is to arrive in Lithuania, tens of thousands of Lithuanians gathered here today in the center of their capital, carrying signs calling for ''Independence for Lithuania,'' and chanting, ''Freedom!''

headline: Dow Off Amid Worries About Rates and Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices retreated again yesterday, pulled down by worries about interest rates and another exceptionally steep decline in the Tokyo stock market.

headline: Iranian Report on Hostages Seen as a Signal to the West
abstract: LEAD: West German and French officials said today that an Iranian newspaper editorial calling for freeing the Western hostages in Lebanon represented an Iranian admission that the West will widen economic and diplomatic ties with Iran only after the hostages are free.

headline: First Boston To Absorb Voute Coats
abstract: LEAD: Five former Salomon Brothers executives, who last year founded a bond-trading ''boutique'' called Voute Coats Stuart & O'Grady, will be joining the First Boston Corporation, the two companies announced yesterday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Trump Plaza Hotel Gives Account to Babbit
abstract: LEAD: The Trump Plaza Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City has moved its advertising account from the Baltimore agency Van Sant Dugdale Advertising to the New York office of Babbit & Reiman Advertising.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Ex-Dissidents Will Monitor Bucharest on Rights
abstract: LEAD: A small group of former dissidents is setting up a committee to make sure that human rights are observed here as Rumania rids itself of the remnants of the Government of Nicolae Ceausescu.

headline: Upheaval in the East: The Germanys;   Bush to Press Kohl at Camp David On Easing Poland's Border Fears
abstract: LEAD: When President Bush meets over the weekend with Chancellor Helmut Kohl, he will urge the West German leader to calm Polish concerns about the future of the Polish-German border, Administration officials said today.

headline: Coca-Cola Report On Profit Margins
abstract: LEAD: The Coca-Cola Company's profit margins widened last year in every region of the world except the home base in the United States, the company said in a report to shareholders. Coke's operating profits as a percentage of sales in the slow-growing American market eased to 11.6 percent in 1989, from 11.8 percent the previous year, the report said.

headline: How Outrage in U.S. Spurred Action in Jesuit Case
abstract: LEAD: Behind the arrests of eight military men in the killing of six Jesuit priests and two women in El Salvador lies an extraordinary campaign of pleas to the Bush Administration by church groups and of pressure on the Salvadoran Government by American officials demanding a full investigation.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   EARLY SOVIET VOTE LEAVES OPPOSITION EXPECTING VICTORY
abstract: LEAD: Voters in the Slavic heartland of the Soviet Union went to the polls today in an exercise of limited democracy that pitted an array of grass-roots challengers against the vast Communist Party patronage network.

headline: President's In-Flight Show: New Pique Toward the Press
abstract: LEAD: In an extraordinary display of Presidential pique, George Bush accosted reporters aboard Air Force One today to let them know he was mad about news reports on his penchant for secrecy and wasn't going to take it anymore.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Common Stock

headline: Bid of $38 a Share Made for Apple Bancorp
abstract: LEAD: Stanley Stahl, a New York real estate developer who holds a 30.3 percent stake in Apple Bancorp Inc., last night made a $38-a-share cash offer for the New York City-based savings bank company. Mr. Stahl's offer values the company at $174 million.

headline: Group W Sports Gains
abstract: LEAD: Group W Sports Marketing has contracted to sell advertising time on the Madison Square Garden Network, a cable television sports service. The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company division was formed last year to serve as advertising representative for regional cable sports networks. The MSG Network will maintain responsibility for its local ad sales effort in New York.

headline: Notes are Offered By Export Group
abstract: LEAD: The Private Export Funding Corporation is offering $200 million in five-year secured notes due 1995. The BT Securities Corporation will act as the issue manager.

headline: Moscow Limits Flights Taking Jews to Israel
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has announced that it will severely limit flights to Israel for emigrating Soviet Jews, and Yitzhak Shamir, the interim Prime Minister, held urgent meetings to find a way to counteract the Soviet decision. The Soviet announcement said that Aeroflot would no longer issue tickets to Soviet Jews planning to emigrate to Israel by flying through Hungary, a heavily used transit point.

headline: FORUM;  How to Rescue the Peace Dividend
abstract: LEAD: President Bush, in his first budget submitted to Congress, may think he has set the ground rules for the peace dividend. But he is already losing control of the process.

headline: Digital Down; Tandem Off
abstract: LEAD: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported sharply lower earnings today for its second fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31. The results were below analysts' already pessimistic estimates, sending its shares down $5.875, to $82, on the New York Stock Exchange.

headline: Hungary to Raise Prices Over 25%
abstract: LEAD: The Government tripled water and sewer rates today and raised prices by more than 25 percent on milk, meat and bread to move the economy toward capitalism.

headline: FAILED KABUL COUP CHANGES OPINIONS
abstract: LEAD: The failed coup this month in Afghanistan, which united a hard-line Communist general with a fundamentalist guerrilla leader, has shaken the long-held assumptions of nearly all the principals in the nation's long civil war, Afghan exiles, diplomats and others say.

headline: 14 Die as Philippine Troops Fight Rebel Governor
abstract: LEAD: A Philippine general and 13 others were killed today when Government troops clashed with supporters of a provincial Governor who took over a hotel in Tuguegarao, 250 miles north of Manila.

headline: Hollinger Stake In Paper Chain
abstract: LEAD: The chief executive of Hollinger Inc. said Tuesday that the Canadian newspaper chain wanted to continue raising its stake in United Newspapers P.L.C. but was not planning a hostile takeover bid for the giant British publisher.      The chief executive, David

headline: C.F.T.C. Approves a Proposal to Restrict Dual Trading
abstract: LEAD: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today unanimously approved a proposed rule that would restrict dual trading on the nation's largest commodity markets, a first step toward the possible banning of the practice from all futures markets.

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: LEAD: * Ashland Oil Inc., Ashland, Ky., an energy and chemical company, appointed John D. Van Meter president of its subsidiary Ashland Oil International Ltd., London.

headline: Rebels Said to Kill 19 in Peru
abstract: LEAD: Shining Path guerrillas shot and killed 19 peasants, nearly all of them women and children, in a small Andean hamlet where they had fled to escape rebel attacks in their own village, the police said today. The reported massacre occurred late Tuesday in Pishupiaco, 60 miles southeast of Huancayo, a major trading center in the Andes 120 miles east of Lima.

headline: Soviet Inquiry Into a Hate Group Is Reported
abstract: LEAD: Prosecutors in Moscow have begun a criminal investigation into the activities of a militant Russian nationalist group that has been repeatedly accused by people around the country of instigating anti-Semitic actions.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Business People;   CS First Boston Hires Chief For Asia/Pacific Subsidiary
abstract: LEAD: After a frustrating year-and-a-half search, CS First Boston Inc. said yesterday that it had hired a chief executive for its Asia/Pacific subsidiary, Allen Wheat, who is the chairman of the London-based Bankers Trust International P.L.C., a unit of the Bankers Trust Company.

headline: Indian Troops Told to Shoot Kashmir's Curfew Violators
abstract: LEAD: Indian officials in the state of Jammu and Kashmir authorized soldiers to shoot curfew violators on sight today after violence in the secession-minded Vale of Kashmir left three-dozen people dead, according to reports from the area.

headline: Surplus Worries Maple Syrup Trade
abstract: LEAD: Bumper crops of maple sugar have created a huge surplus in Quebec, which supplies 70 percent of the world market. And that has left smaller American producers in Maine, Vermont, New Hampshire, Michigan, Ohio, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin worried about lower prices.

headline: Mutual Funds
abstract: LEAD: The flight to safety is on. Investors, worried about skittish stock and ''junk bond'' markets and lured by high interest rates, are shifting their cash to money-market funds. And fund experts say that investor nervousness shows no sign of clearing.

headline: Economic Scene;   An Old Trade Idea Wins New Favor
abstract: LEAD: THE latest round of trade negotiations between the United States and Japan is provoking rancor but few results. The Japanese have charged that America does not invest enough in education and research and development, while the United States contends that Japan's distribution network remains closed.

headline: S.&P. Downgrades Sears On $5.6 Billion of Securities
abstract: LEAD: The slower-than-expected recovery in Sears, Roebuck & Company's retailing operations has resulted in the downgrading of about $5.6 billion in the corporation's securities, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

headline: Checking Accounts Offer Buyer-Protection Insurance
abstract: LEAD: Some might call it a sales gimmick, but others see it as a valuable consumer service: The old-fashioned checking account is being adorned with new insurance that automatically protects goods bought by check against damage or loss and extends manufacturers' warranties.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   RUMANIAN RULERS CALL OUT THRONGS AND STAGE A RALLY
abstract: LEAD: In a show of strength for the ruling Council of National Salvation, about 20,000 demonstrators poured into the capital today and laid siege to the headquarters of opposition parties.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: LEAD: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.       Monday       Consumer Credit    Nov.       Tuesday       None       Wednesday       None       Thursday       None       Friday       Producer Price Index    Dec.       Retail Sales    Dec.

headline: Turnover in Nicaragua;   NICARAGUAN OPPOSITION ROUTS SANDINISTAS; U.S. PLEDGES AID, TIED TO ORDERLY TURNOVER
abstract: LEAD: The leader of Nicaragua's opposition coalition crushed President Daniel Ortega Saavedra in national elections here on Sunday, apparently bringing an end to 10 turbulent years of Sandinista rule.

headline: Sematech Today: Cash Dispenser
abstract: LEAD: Sematech, the Government-industry alliance formed two years ago to develop better ways of making computer chips, has been forced to become a financier as well as a coordinator of company research efforts.

headline: 19 Expelled U.S. Diplomats Leave Nicaragua for Miami
abstract: LEAD: Nineteen of the 20 American diplomats who were ordered to leave Nicaragua in a reprisal for a military raid on the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama departed today for Miami.

headline: 18 Tourists Killed in Brazil
abstract: LEAD: At least 18 Argentine tourists, including 4 children, died today when their bus overturned near the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre, radio reports said. The bus had left the town of Trenque Lauquen in Argentina on Sunday loaded with tourists bound for the coastal Brazilian town of Camboriu when it flipped on its side before dawn, the reports said.

headline: Amid the Publishing Slump, Norton Thrives
abstract: LEAD: At a time when many publishing houses are complaining about declining revenues and even losses, W. W. Norton & Company is not only profitable, but also independent.

headline: Business and the Law;   Brokerage Case Goes On and On
abstract: LEAD: Three years ago the Supreme Court was swayed by arguments of the securities industry that arbitration is swift, relatively inexpensive and fair. In their ruling in Shearson/American Express Inc. v. McMahon, the Justices locked the doors of Federal courthouses to most customers who contend that they were defrauded by stockbrokers.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Feb. 11, 1990:       MONDAY       Cooper Tire & Rubr Co    Genuine Parts Co       TUESDAY       Brunswick Corp    Chesapeake Corp    Cincinnati Milacron Inc    Cummins Engine Inc    Enserch Corp    First Miss Corp    Internat Flvrs & Fragrnces    Liberty Corp SC    Suntrust Bks Inc    V F Corp

headline: U.N., Bowing to Soviets, Halts Its Baltic Contacts
abstract: LEAD: Bowing to Soviet pressure, the United Nations Secretariat has agreed to suspend the informal contacts it has conducted for several months with Baltic nationalist groups seeking independence from Moscow, a senior official has announced.

headline: Labor Closer to Split With Likud
abstract: LEAD: As compromise efforts foundered, the Israeli Government moved closer to dissolution today when the Labor Party's governing body agreed to give Labor Cabinet ministers the power to end their coalition with Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his Likud party.

headline: Mandela Meets With Anti-Apartheid Coalition
abstract: LEAD: Anti-apartheid campaigners spent several hours today meeting with the black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela on developments in the anti-apartheid movement.

headline: Mandela Ally Rebukes Pretoria
abstract: LEAD: Walter Sisulu, a leader of the African National Congress, denied today that the group was responsible for the growing unrest in South Africa and said that the white-dominated Government had caused the violence by its policy of apartheid.

headline: Baker, in Africa, Will Press Mandela on Socialism
abstract: LEAD: On his trip to southern Africa next week, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will encourage Nelson Mandela to continue his campaign against apartheid and will also urge the black leader to abandon socialist economic principles, a senior State Department official says.

headline: Centuries of Strife Between 2 Groups
abstract: LEAD: Antagonism between Azerbaijanis and Armenians is longstanding, caused by religion, nationalism, territorial friction and other factors, experts at United States universities said in interviews this week.

headline: 5 Weeklies Are Acquired
abstract: LEAD: Five weekly newspapers in southwestern Connecticut and southern New York have been sold to Southern Connecticut Newspapers Inc., a unit of the Times Mirror Company that publishes The Advocate in Stamford and The Greenwich Time.

headline: Grand Met May Sell Alpo Pet Foods Unit
abstract: LEAD: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate, said today that it was exploring the possibility of selling its Alpo Pet Foods Inc. division.

headline: All About/Avionics;   American Electronics Companies Still Rule the Cockpit
abstract: LEAD: In 1929, Jimmy Doolittle flew blind - covering the cockpit of his biplane with a hood - to prove that a pilot could rely on flight instruments alone. Since then, cockpit electronics have become sophisticated enough to all but take the place of the pilot.

headline: G.M. Near Agreement On Venture in Hungary
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was at an advanced stage of negotiations to assemble cars and engines in Hungary.

headline: Meeting Narrows Gap Between U.S. and Japan
abstract: LEAD: Shintaro Ishihara, the Japanese economic nationalist who argues that the resentment in a declining America of his country's growing economic success is largely rooted in racism, crossed swords here today with a Congressman from Detroit.

headline: Alka-Seltzer Puts Humor Back in Ads
abstract: LEAD: Alka-Seltzer is at it again. In the 1960's and 1970's Alka-Seltzer entertained television viewers with a barrage of funny commercials that introduced such well-known lines as, ''Try it, you'll like it'' and ''I can't believe I ate the whole thing.''

headline: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
abstract: LEAD:            Net      Percent       Income      Change    M03,30,15,15        Net Income   Percent           Oct.-Dec.   Change           1989   From '88         Affiliated Publications Inc.   $ 13,500,000     *-       Coastal Corp.   71,400,000    +0.4        Colgate-Palmolive Co.   62,500,000    -50.7        A.T. Cross Co.   15,700,000    +6.8        Culbro Corp.

headline: Czech-Vatican Ties Restored
abstract: LEAD: Czechoslovakia's new Government decided today to restore full relations with the Vatican after a break of more than 40 years. The official news agency C.T.K. said the Government had decided that ''diplomatic contacts with the Holy See be restored'' but gave no details.

headline: Former Keating Lobbyist Got No-Bid U.S. Contract
abstract: LEAD: A lawyer who in 1988 pressed regulators to refrain from seizing a failing savings and loan was given a $49,000 no-bid consulting contract last year to advise a Federal agency involved in the bailout of the savings industry.

headline: Campeau Surrenders 29% Stake
abstract: LEAD: Robert Campeau, the Canadian developer who borrowed heavily to buy two big American retailers and then brought them into severe financial straits, surrendered about $100 million worth of his own stock in his flagship company, the Campeau Corporation, yesterday to a Canadian bank when he defaulted on a loan to two of his private companies.

headline: Goldman's 'Junk Bond' Shift
abstract: LEAD: In another indication of weakness in the ''junk bond'' market, investment bankers at Goldman, Sachs & Company recently told executives of the Georgia Gulf Corporation that the investment bank would act only as the agent, and not as the underwriter, on a proposed offering of $200 million in notes.

headline: Stocks Sag Again; Dow Drops 10.14 Points
abstract: LEAD: Pessimism about stocks involved in deals, primarily the UAL Corporation, depressed stock prices broadly yesterday as trading volume rose sharply.

headline: Wall St. Praises Helmsman Who Had a Difficult Watch
abstract: LEAD: John J. Phelan Jr.'s tenure at the helm of the New York Stock Exchange coincided with one of the most turbulent periods in the history of the United States stock market. Yet as Wall Street executives assessed his six years as chairman, there was almost universal praise for his leadership and the stature he lent an organization that in many ways came of age on his watch.

headline: Perkin-Elmer Accord Seen
abstract: LEAD: A Federal Government official familiar with the negotiations said yesterday that an agreement had been reached to insure that at least part of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation's troubled Semiconductor Equipment Group was purchased by an American buyer.      Earlier this week Electronic

headline: ALC Acquisition By Telecom-USA
abstract: LEAD: Telecom-USA Inc. of Atlanta signed a letter to acquire the ALC Communications Corporation for about $97.1 million. Under terms of the proposed transaction, holders of ALC's common stock and its series B and C preferred stock will receive Telecom-USA units worth $3 a share. The holders of ALC's series

headline: Avibras Industria
abstract: LEAD: Avibras Industria Aeroespacial S.A., one of Brazil's largest weapons makers, said today that it was seeking bankruptcy protection from its creditors. The company said one client had owed it $40 million for more than a year. People at Avibras identified the client as Iraq. Avibras, a private company, said it had $100 million worth of equipment ready for shipment to the same client, which has not been shipped because of nonpayment of the debt.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   No Undue Haste to Unity, Irate East German Urges
abstract: LEAD: Angered by signs of a growing West German certainty that East German economic and political weakness has made rapid unification on Bonn's terms inevitable, Prime Minister Hans Modrow told the East German Parliament today that this country should not sell itself cheap.

headline: New Leaders Of Ad Group
abstract: LEAD: The American Association of Advertising Agencies yesterday elected Keith L. Reinhard, the chairman and chief executive of DDB Needham Worldwide, as its chairman for the next year. Mr. Reinhard succeeds Glen W. Fortinberry, who is also the chairman, president and chief executive of the Ross Roy Group.

headline: U.S.-Soviet Grain Pact Due
abstract: LEAD: The United States and the Soviet Union should be able to seal a new long-term grain trade agreement at a meeting next week in Vienna, the chief United States delegate to the talks said today ''As far as I am concerned, we can and should wrap it up next week,'' said the deputy trade representative, Jules Katz, who will lead the

headline: NELSON MANDELA
abstract: LEAD: The hair has gone gray and the boxer's shoulders are shells under the awkward jacket now. The booming voice that had roared for justice in the 1960's became a gentle echo in his lonely cell long ago. But amid the many perils of South Africa's future, one thing seemed clear yesterday: the years of imprisonment had not broken Nelson R.

headline: Rebels' Allies Stand Firm in Salvador
abstract: LEAD: Every morning he combs the local newspapers, looking anxiously for the names of captured and killed guerrillas.

headline: Honda Asked To Sell Jeeps To Japanese
abstract: LEAD: The Honda Motor Company said today that the Chrysler Corporation had asked it to sell Jeep recreational vehicles in Japan, and some Honda officials hinted that they were likely to strike an agreement soon.

headline: SmithKline Lags On Cosmetics Sale
abstract: LEAD: The sale of the cosmetics operations units of the British-American pharmaceutical company SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. ''is not going as well as we wished,'' Robert Bauman, chief executive of the company, said in Tokyo, where it is starting a Japanese unit. There are fewer buyers than expected, partly because of the overall softness of the market, and some of the prices will probably be lower than original estimates, he said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Scoresby's Response To Success
abstract: LEAD: SCORESBY has become the fifth-largest brand of Scotch in America - without advertising. Scoresby Scotch has grown into the largest brand in California, indeed the Western United States -without advertising. While sales of domestic Scotch declined by 4.6 percent last year, Scoresby's sales grew by more than 11 percent - without advertising.

headline: Simmons Forms Slate For Lockheed's Board
abstract: LEAD: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas financier, moved forward today with his planned proxy fight for control of the board of the Lockheed Corporation by naming his slate of proposed directors. The slate includes John G. Tower, the former United States Senator from Texas, and Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., the retired admiral who is also a director of Mr.

headline: Perrier Says Employees Failed to Change Filters
abstract: LEAD: The contamination of Perrier sparkling water was caused when company employees failed to replace charcoal filters that screen out benzene, a chemical impurity in the natural gas present in the company's famous spring in southern France, Perrier officials said yesterday.

headline: How One Man Rescued Basketball, and Its Bottom Line
abstract: LEAD: David J. Stern is a friend of the Famous Chicken. He thinks it's wonderful that Orlando hates Miami. He sees no reason why fans shouldn't stuff themselves with Charlotte Hornets Caramel Corn.

headline: For Gorbachev, an Uncertain Anniversary
abstract: LEAD: Outside a polling place in Moscow last week, a voter framed the issue as a bitter joke: ''What is the difference between the Soviet Union and the United States?''

headline: Business Taps the East Bloc's Intellectual Reserves
abstract: LEAD: Most American companies view the Soviet Union and the newly opening nations in Eastern Europe as potential markets for their products or as sources of low-cost manufacturing labor. And a growing number are expected to tap another resource they describe as plentiful and underused: brainpower.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Pioneer Inc., Orlando, Fla., parent company of Pioneer Savings Bank, and HBJ Insurance Cos., said they had ended an agreement for the sale of American Pioneer Life Insurance Co. to HBJ.

headline: Fisher-Price Plant to Close
abstract: LEAD: The Quaker Oats Company said yesterday that it planned to close one of its five large toy plants for its Fisher-Price division. The closing will result in a charge against earnings of about $11 million, or 8 cents a share, in the third quarter ending on March 31.      The closing of the plant in

headline: Gorbachev Plan for Family Farms Is Approved by Soviet Lawmakers
abstract: LEAD: A qualified plan to allow revival of the family farm but maintain Communism's ban on private ownership of land was approved today by the Supreme Soviet and sent on to likely final approval in the Soviet Congress.

headline: Precious Metals Off Sharply As Tokyo Shares Fall Again
abstract: LEAD: Prices of precious metals plunged yesterday on extensive selling sparked by another sharp drop in share values in Japan. As share prices tumbled there, many private and institutional investors sold gold, platinum and silver to get cash to meet margin calls from their stockbrokers.

headline: Market Place;   Funds Questioned On Quoted Yields
abstract: LEAD: IN the fast-growing world of money market funds, two have stood out over the last year, largely because they have managed to pay higher interest rates than their competitors. They have done this by charging either no management fee or a lower one than other funds.

headline: American Airlines
abstract: LEAD: American Airlines Inc. said Monday it would add 39 domestic flights beginning next month, including two cross-country flights from Newark to Los Angeles. American also exercised options to buy seven MD-11 jumbo jets from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. The expansion also includes service at Stewart Airport in Newburgh, N.Y., and daily flights between Miami and both Newark and New York's Kennedy Airport - as well as new flights serving Dallas, Chicago and North Carolina.

headline: Wukeshu Journal;   The Perfect Union Still Eludes a Checkered China
abstract: LEAD: Bi Shucai furrowed his brow into a hundred wrinkles as he tried to think of the differences between himself, a member of the ethnic Sani minority, and the Han Chinese people who rule the country he lives in.

headline: Chase Official to Head Global Securities Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Chase Manhattan Bank, believing that institutional investors are taking a global approach, has combined its domestic pension trust and global custody business and put Marshall N. Carter in charge.

headline: Some of the Casualties Meet Their Commander
abstract: LEAD: Gregory Johnson's Purple Heart was pinned to his pillow, and a three-foot-high inflatable Santa stood near his bed.

headline: Cray in Deal To Acquire Supertek
abstract: LEAD: Cray Research Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Supertek Computers Inc. for an undisclosed amount of cash. Supertek, a privately held company based in Santa Clara, Calif., manufactures a mini-supercomputer compatible with Cray's machines. Cray said the purchase would accelerate its entry in the mini-super market.

headline: Quayle Trip: Resentment Dramatized
abstract: LEAD: Vice President Dan Quayle's trip to Latin America and the Caribbean was supposed to allay some of the region's resentment over the United States invasion of Panama, but instead it seems to have dramatized the depth of that resentment.

headline: More Wheat for China
abstract: LEAD: China has been authorized to buy an additional one million metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices, the Agriculture Department announced on Thursday. Under Secretary Richard T. Crowder said the wheat would be available to China under the department's Export Enhancement Program, which allows private exporters to sell American commodities at reduced prices and then collect Government surpluses of grain or other commodities as bonuses.

headline: U.S. Soldiers Detain Cuban
abstract: LEAD: American soldiers briefly detained the Cuban ambassador today, officials said. It was the second time the envoy, Lazaro Mora Secades, was stopped and searched since the Dec. 20 American invasion to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The Cuban Embassy has given refuge to the general's family.

headline: Punished by Bucharest, City's Choice Was Revolt
abstract: LEAD: The man described his day. He wakes. He goes to buy milk for his children. For the babies, there is no formula to buy. He goes to work. The bus line is long and slow. It is cold at work. There is no heat, no equipment for proper work. He finishes work and goes to buy something to eat. But there is no food to buy.

headline: Beirut Government, Facing Rivals, Asks U.S. Arms
abstract: LEAD: The Syrian-backed Government of President Elias Hrawi is seeking weapons from the United States to build up its military strength against Gen. Michel Aoun, the Maronite Christian officer who leads most of the country's armed forces, according to Government officials here.

headline: Tokyo Market Off Sharply
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices fell sharply today, with the Nikkei index of 225 stocks losing more than 1,000 points to close below 30,000.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD: General Assembly       Meets at 9:30 A.M.       Special Session meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.       COMMITTEE ON SPECIAL SESSION - 3 P.M.       COMMITTEE ON CHARTER - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.       Economic and Social Council       DEVELOPMENT PROGRAM, GOVERNING COUNCIL - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Architect's Lament: Moscow So Drab
abstract: LEAD: ''Moscow is the capital of unfortunate people,'' declared Aleksei A. Klimenko, an architectural historian, his native bitterness resonating across the soul-weary posture of the city.

headline: Soviets Said to Withdraw Fighters and Bombers From Vietnam Base
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has withdrawn all of its MIG-23 fighter planes and about half of its TU-16 bombers from its base at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, Pentagon officials said today, in a move the officials said would reduce Soviet military abilities in Southeast Asia.

headline: Soviets, in Protest, Say C.I.A. Maligns the K.G.B.
abstract: LEAD: Stung by a defector's charge that the K.G.B. once conspired to assassinate Pope John Paul II, the Soviet Union said today that it had complained strongly to the State Department that such accusations were ''clearly'' engineered by the Central Intelligence Agency.

headline: Precious Metal Prices Fall, With Gold Leading the Way
abstract: LEAD: Precious metal prices plunged yesterday as the dollar advanced against most leading foreign currencies. A sharp rise in Japanese interest rates also made platinum, gold and silver more expensive to buy in that nation, which has become a major consumer as well as dealer in precious metals.

headline: Drexel Creditors to Ask For Details on Bonuses
abstract: LEAD: Creditors of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group plan to file a motion today with the Federal judge overseeing its bankruptcy seeking the appointment of an official to examine Drexel's books.

headline: Radio Revenues Up
abstract: LEAD: Network radio revenues rose by 11.9 percent last year, to $427.2 million, according to the Radio Network Association. Revenues in New York rose just 1 percent, to $224.3 million, the group said.

headline: Ford Settles Dispute At 2d Mexican Plant
abstract: LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said today that it had reached a new labor agreement with the union representing 2,100 hourly workers at its plant in Hermosillo, Mexico.

headline: Levi Strauss Closing Plant
abstract: LEAD: Levi Strauss & Company said today that it will close one of three sewing plants in San Antonio in April and lay off 1,100 workers.

headline: S.E.C. Tells of Investigation Into Bonuses Paid by Drexel
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission began an investigation immediately upon learning that Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. had paid hundreds of millions of dollars in bonuses to executives in the weeks before its parent company filed for bankruptcy protection, the S.E.C.'s chairman, Richard C. Breeden, said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * AMI Healthcare P.L.C., London, a hospital group, said talks were under way with a number of potential purchasers for the 65 percent stake in the company owned by American Medical International Inc.

headline: Insults Fly in Bonn Parliament During Debate on Unification
abstract: LEAD: Catcalls and charges echoed through the West German Parliament today as it gave a rowdy and heated foretaste of the domestic political struggle shaping over German unity.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   The New York Post Aims to Improve Image
abstract: LEAD: In a new advertising campaign entitled ''The Three Biggest Lies in New York,'' The New York Post acknowledges that it has an image problem. A candid television commercial and several different billboard ads repeat things people say when they'd rather not tell the truth. The first two lies differ from ad to ad.

headline: Bond News;   Some Macy Debt Ratings Are Lowered by Moody's
abstract: LEAD: Moody's Investors Service Inc. said yesterday that it had lowered some debt ratings of R. H. Macy & Company and its wholly owned subsidiaries the Macy Credit Corporation and R. H. Macy Overseas Finance N.V.

headline: Saturday Australia Vote May Bring In Opposition
abstract: LEAD: Australians vote on Saturday in national elections that opinion polls show could bring the Conservative opposition to power and end the seven-year Government of Prime Minister Bob Hawke.

headline: Shoehorn Maker Has 'Concept' for Diaper
abstract: LEAD: Edward Reiss did well with shoehorns and is trying to repeat his success with a ''new concept'' in diapers.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Officer at BSB
abstract: LEAD: Hoping to add creative flair to an agency that many advertising executives say has grown a bit stale, Backer Spielvogel Bates has apparently lured Peter Murphy from his post as executive creative director of Hal Riney & Partners in San Francisco, advertising executives say. In a novel twist, Mr. Murphy, who left Marschalk/New York in 1986 to take the West Coast creative position, will take the title of executive vice presi-dent/copywriter at BSB.

headline: Gain for Italian Media Law
abstract: LEAD: The Italian Senate passed a bill today that would restrict ownership of television and newspapers, and ban commercials during film, opera and theater productions on television. The measure is seen as a major threat to the television empire of the Italian media holder Silvio Berlusconi.

headline: Hong Kong Bank Gains
abstract: LEAD: The Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, regarded as the largest bank in Asia outside Japan, reported today that its earnings rose 11 percent in 1989. Despite economic slowdowns in the bank's leading markets, the bank said its profits for the year rose to $4.77 billion (Hong Kong), or $612 million (United States), from $4.3 billion (Hong Kong) in 1988.

headline: Outsider Hired to Run Dun & Bradstreet Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Dun & Bradsteet Corporation yesterday named Ronald K. Glover, the head of the American Express Company's traveler's check business in the United States, to run the division that produces its well-known corporate credit reports.

headline: OPPOSITION LEADS IN HUNGARY'S VOTE
abstract: LEAD: Given their first chance to elect a government freely in 45 years, Hungarian voters split their vote between two newly formed parties from the anti-Communist opposition that are now battling over how quickly the country should complete its transition to a free-market economy.

headline: Easier Rules For A.T.&T. Suggested
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission said today that the market in long-distance telephone services was sufficiently competitive that the Government should consider removing some restrictions that were placed on the American Telephone and Telegraph Company before the breakup of the Bell

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Jonathan Harries has been named a creative director at Leo Burnett Company.

headline: Low-Tech Company In High-Tech Gamble
abstract: LEAD: Papken S. DerTorossian, an Armenian who emigrated from Syria, exudes patriotism. At the helm of a $130 million electronics business here, he is among the industry executives most outspoken on the importance of keeping American technology in American hands.

headline: Rebels in Ethiopia Claim Capture of Red Sea Port
abstract: LEAD: Rebels in Ethiopia's northern province of Eritrea said today that they captured the strategic Red Sea port of Massawa today after opening a major offensive two days ago.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       The savings industry had its worst year ever in 1989, with losses soaring to $19.2 billion, regulators said. Although a record loss had been expected, the amount surprised experts. Indeed, losses from operations for 485 troubled institutions amounted to $2.6 billion in the fourth quarter, equivalent to a taxpayer loss of $29 million a day as long as the institutions stayed open in that period.

headline: Colombia Envoy Angry About U.S. Trade Policy
abstract: LEAD: Recent Bush Administration trade decisions are squeezing Colombia's earnings and making its war against cocaine trafficking more difficult, the country's Ambassador, Victor Mosquera Chaux, said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    International

headline: Officer Quits At Doskocil
abstract: LEAD: The Doskocil Companies, the Hutchinson, Kan., food processing concern, said today that its president and chief operating officer, David S. Smoak, had resigned last week to pursue other interests.

headline: Bush Calls For Some Regulation
abstract: LEAD: In the most thorough presentation of his economic views since he took office, President Bush today embraced the mainstream Republican philosophy of reliance on private initiatives and market forces. But his first Economic Report to Congress did not have the ideological edge of those submitted by Ronald Reagan.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Pioneer Inc., Orlando, Fla., the parent company of American Pioneer Savings Bank, said it would sell certain assets and operations of its Catalina Homes Inc. and Jonathon Group Inc. units for $65.7 million to Catalina Homes Acquisition Ltd., a Florida limited partnership.

headline: Family Split Over French Publisher
abstract: LEAD: The latest episode in the bitter struggle for control of one of France's most prestigious publishing houses, Editions Gallimard, became public today as a Gallimard family member disputed the value of the privately owned empire.

headline: Warning by Big Oil;   Larger Bites From Profits Expected Because of Environmental Standards
abstract: LEAD: The charges against earnings taken by some oil companies in the most recent quarter to deal with environmental problems are a warning that pollution standards will be increasingly costly to meet and that more such charges are likely.

headline: Cost-Reduction Steps Are Begun by G.M.
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was beginning a new round of cost-cutting measures, including voluntary separation packages for salaried employees, in the face of depressed revenue and profits from the North American car market.

headline: U.S. Protests Attack on 2 in Zaire
abstract: LEAD: The United States has protested to Zaire over attacks on two lawyers who were investigating human-rights practices there, State Department officials said today.

headline: Soviets Propose Reduction in Armed Forces of Unified Germany
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union called today for cuts in the armed forces of a united Germany as part of any agreement on German unification.

headline: China Releases Prominent Dissident From Prison
abstract: LEAD: A prominent Chinese dissident has been released from prison after serving a 10-year sentence for campaigning on behalf of human rights, his friends say.

headline: NBC IS SELLING MULTIMEDIA 51% OF CLEVELAND TV STATION
abstract: LEAD: NBC will sell a majority ownership stake in WKYC-TV, its Cleveland television station, to Multimedia Inc., the companies announced yesterday.

headline: Inventories Fell by 0.2% In December
abstract: LEAD: Business inventories fell in December for the first time in more than a year, while sales remained unchanged, the Government said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    International

headline: Hong Kong Journal;   Help! Wicked Satirist Is Loose. Colony Skewered.
abstract: LEAD: Larry Feign's Hong Kong Chinese are shameless racists who love to gamble, toss garbage out their apartment windows and make money. A greedy, materialistic lot, they prefer stability and prosperity to democratic freedoms.

headline: Khmer Rouge Claim Assault on Major City
abstract: LEAD: Khmer Rouge guerrillas claimed today they had attacked Cambodia's second-largest city, setting it ablaze and forcing Government troops to call for reinforcements.

headline: Patents;   Alternative To Cortisone For the Skin
abstract: LEAD: The steroid cortisone rivals aspirin as one of the most widely used medications. Thanks to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation, cortisone relieves a host of skin irritations, from poison oak to eczema and psoriasis. Taken orally, it can relieve asthma and other forms of lung congestion.

headline: Bombs Hit Guatemala Town
abstract: LEAD: Six bombs exploded today in the provincial capital of San Marcos, including two at the homes of high-ranking politicians, the police said. One bomb exploded at the residence of Governor Carlos Godinez of San Marcos and seriously wounded his 24 year-old daughter, according to the police in San Marcos, 157 miles northwest of the capital.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Troop Proposal an Effort to Catch Up With Changes in Europe
abstract: LEAD: By the Administration's account, President Bush's new proposal for deeper troop cuts in Europe was dictated by the mounting desire of the leaders of Eastern Europe for the withdrawal of Soviet troops.

headline: Genentech Drops On Deal Analysis
abstract: LEAD: Genentech Inc.'s stock fell after analysts concluded that a proposed merger with Roche Holding Ltd. was less favorable to investors than it first seemed. ''If Genentech does well, the stock could rise, but the deal effectively puts a cap on the price.'' said Michael Cohen, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   2 Colleagues Back at Blau
abstract: LEAD: Jan Leth thought Barry Blau & Partners was too small. So in 1987 the art director left the direct-response ad agency, based in Fairfield, Conn., for Rapp Collins Marcoa, owned by the Omnicom Group. David Klang thought Blau was too big. So last February the creative supervisor left for the Saugatuck Group, a Westport,

headline: Apple Expands Stock-Buying Plan
abstract: LEAD: The board of Apple Computer Inc. approved the repurchase of up to 2.5 million more shares of its common stock. In August 1989, the company announced a plan for the repurchase of 2.5 million shares. ''We believe purchase of Apple shares represents good long-term value to our shareholders,'' said John Sculley,

headline: CORRECTIONS
abstract: LEAD: An article last week about the California clothing company L.A. Gear misstated the length of time the chief financial officer's post had been vacant. It was two months.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Retired Executive in Ohio Accused of Insider Trades
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Government yesterday accused a recently retired senior executive of Philips Industries of Dayton, Ohio, of violating Federal insider trading laws for selling blocks of the company's stock shortly before it announced unfavorable news.

headline: Parliament Questions Spain Aide on Scandal
abstract: LEAD: Deputy Prime Minister Alfonso Guerra appeared today in an emergency session of Parliament to defend himself against charges that he was implicated in his brother's personal financial activities.

headline: Nigerian Military Chief Postpones Visit to U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Confronted with a shake-up in his Cabinet, the President of Nigeria, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, has postponed a visit to the United States.

headline: Archive Agrees to Buy Cipher Data
abstract: LEAD: The Archive Corporation said that it had agreed to acquire Cipher Data Products Inc. for $8.25 a share, or about $114 million, ending a three-month-long takeover fight.

headline: Renewed Muslim-Christian Battle in Beirut Kills 3
abstract: LEAD: Tank, artillery and rocket duels resumed today across the Green Line that splits the Lebanese capital into Muslim and Christian halves, and the police said three people were killed and three were wounded.

headline: Purina Setting Up New Pet Food Unit
abstract: LEAD: The Ralston Purina Company said it would establish a new division for its specialty pet food unit and to promote its premium Pro Plan pet foods. Pro-Visions Pet Specialty Enterprises will market Pro Plan products to pet shops, feed stores and veterinarians, the company said.

headline: Killings Scandal Weighs on de Klerk
abstract: LEAD: Efforts by President F. W. de Klerk have failed to still the controversy over allegations that death squads under military control have been killing opponents of apartheid. The continuing disclosures in South African newspapers appear to pose a growing embarrassment to Mr. de Klerk as he seeks a new political arrangement between whites and blacks.

headline: Canada's Banks Increase Rates
abstract: LEAD: Canada's largest banks raised their prime lending rate three-quarters of a percentage point today, to 14.25 percent, the highest level since 1982.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    INTERNATIONAL       Brazil's orange producers stand to profit handsomely from frost damage in Florida. Bolstered by a record crop, 1990 exports are expected to surge by as much as 36 percent, to a record $1.5 billion. To Brazilians, the orange has become a symbol of easy wealth; a popular soap opera centers on the industry.

headline: Washington Post Shift to Big Board
abstract: LEAD: The Washington Post Company announced yesterday that it would move its class B stock to a listing on the New York Stock Exchange, leaving the American Stock Exchange after 19 years. The company said it expects to be listed on the Big Board by the end of January.

headline: U.S. to Unveil Drug Plan With Wide Military Role
abstract: LEAD: The Pentagon will announce a new anti-drug strategy on Friday that will increase the use of warships and airplanes in the Caribbean to help block drug shipments, officials said today. But the plan sets aside a politically troublesome proposal to post Navy ships off the Colombian coast.

headline: Eli Lilly Earnings Rise; Upjohn Reports a Loss
abstract: LEAD: Eli Lilly & Company said yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings grew by double digits over the previous year, helped by higher unit sales in United States and foreign markets. The Upjohn Company, meanwhile, said it had a $118 million loss in the quarter, reflecting the costs of a previously announced restructuring.

headline: In Kashmir, Muslim Police Go on Strike
abstract: LEAD: One hundred local policemen shouted Islamic and anti-Government slogans today as they briefly went on strike to press for relief of long-simmering frustrations at a time when the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir is being swept by a separatist upsurge.

headline: Robots Transform Coal Mining
abstract: LEAD: The four-inch carbide-steel claws of a screaming yellow robot tore relentlessly at the coal seam 1,000 feet below the surface, digging enough in 30 seconds to meet the electric needs of a typical suburban house for a year.

headline: Hong Kong After 1997: Blueprint for Rule Expected in March
abstract: LEAD: As alarm mounts over China's tough attitude toward Hong Kong and hopes rise that Britain will introduce greater democracy here, there is a growing sense that Hong Kong's future will be largely determined in the next few months.

headline: Business and the Law;   A Paper Spill Due In the Valdez Case
abstract: LEAD: THE Exxon Valdez case is coming - ''one or two million pieces of paper,'' by one lawyer's estimate - and it is already testing the courts' ability to adjudicate for thousands of people at a time.

headline: Tech Notes;   Beauty of the Simulated Weld
abstract: LEAD: Researchers at the College of Aeronautics, Queens, N.Y., and at Ixion Inc., a Seattle-based computer and video programming company, have devised an interactive video system that can teach oxygen acetylene welding under different conditions without danger.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Can Shops Stay Small And Alone?
abstract: LEAD: ''THERE is a fresh new wind blowing in the advertising business,'' James H. Quest said two years ago about the improved prospects for small national agencies, citing client dissatisfaction with the conglomeration of the industry.

headline: China-Soviet Ventures
abstract: LEAD: China and the Soviet Union are discussing possible joint projects in the mining of Chinese copper, aluminum and tungsten, The China Daily said on Sunday. The newspaper said Soviet technical experts had recently visited some sites. One possible joint project involves a large copper mine in northeastern China.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Bush Urges Gorbachev to Avoid A Military Assault in Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: President Bush appealed to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today to avoid using military force in Lithuania as the Administration sought to balance its formal support for Lithuanian independence with its concern for stability in Eastern Europe.

headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Bulgaria;   Sofia Party Picks Supporter of Change as Premier
abstract: LEAD: Eager to polish their image for elections this spring, Bulgaria's ruling Communists today chose an advocate of change as the country's new Prime Minister.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       PREPARATORY COMMITTEE FOR THE SPECIAL SESSION ON INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC COOPERATION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.       Economic and Social Council       SCIENTIFIC AND TECHNICAL SUBCOMMITTEE ON OUTER SPACE - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: Aristech Offer Is Withdrawn
abstract: LEAD: The Huntsman Holdings Corporation, whose unsolicited $813 million bid for the Aristech Chemical Corporation prompted the chemical company to seek a friendly Japanese suitor, said today that it had dropped its offer.      Huntsman, based in Salt

headline: Honecker Says He Takes Blame for '89 Vote Fraud
abstract: LEAD: Erich Honecker, the former East German leader, took political responsibility today for vote fraud in local elections last year as well as the nation's current crisis, but denied any criminal guilt.

headline: Late Rally Sends Prices Soaring
abstract: LEAD: A late rally sent prices of Treasury securities soaring and yields tumbling yesterday.

headline: Kenyan Leader to Visit U.S.
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya will begin a three-day private visit to the United States on Monday, diplomatic sources said today. Kenya is one of Washington's closest allies in Africa and the United States Navy has access to the base at the Kenyan port of Mombasa. Mr. Moi last visited the United States in March 1987.

abstract: LEAD:          $   Steel Production     Dec.    Nov.    Year Ago        Thousands of net tons     7,221    7,385    7,954        Automobile Production     Dec.    Nov.
