headline: 30,123 Entries On Sale List
abstract: LEAD: Savings institution regulators today printed what amounts to one of the largest real estate listings ever published.

headline: Libya Says Several Are Held In Rabta Chemical Plant Fire
abstract: LEAD: Libya's Ambassador to Italy said today that several people had been detained in connection with the fire last week at a chemical plant that Washington says made chemical weapons.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   17 Nations Plan to Relax Rules on Exports to East
abstract: LEAD: A watchdog group including Western nations has agreed to begin relaxing controls on the export of advanced technology to Eastern Europe, but the United States has insisted that some of the concessions not yet apply to the Soviet Union, Western officials said today.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   Bulgarian Leader Is Out of Communist Party Job After Stormy Congress
abstract: LEAD: Bulgaria's Communist Party chief, Petar Mladenov, was removed from the post today at an emergency party congress that has been struggling to break from the nation's Stalinist past.

headline: Steel Imports Decline
abstract: LEAD: Steel imports in November fell 13 percent from October's level, and represented 18.9 percent of the domestic supply, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. The November imports came to 1.49 million tons, compared with 1.7 million tons in October and 1.8 million tons in November 1988, the institute reported.

headline: Northwest Airlines
abstract: LEAD: Northwest Airlines, the carrier owned by NWA Inc., said it would invest $422 million in the next five years to upgrade its service. Frederic V. Malek, president of the carrier, which was acquired last year by a group headed by Alfred A. Checchi, said four areas would be worked on: performance, cleanliness, trouble-free customer experience and employee attitude.

headline: California Accuses Lincoln Of Misleading Bond Buyers
abstract: LEAD: A California agency said today that it had filed a multimillion-dollar lawsuit against Charles H. Keating Jr. and the American Continental Corporation, contending that the company put pressure on unsophisticated investors to buy its ''junk bonds'' by saying they were insured by the Government and were free of risk.

headline: Pactel Will Reduce Work Force by 16%
abstract: LEAD: The Pacific Telesis Group, the regional telephone and communications company based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it plans to eliminate 11,000 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force, in the next five years to cut costs.

headline: Riding the 'Junk' Whirlwind
abstract: LEAD: Despite the swift demise last week of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the ''junk bond'' market seems certain to survive, money managers, analysts and traders said. But the form that it will take is not clear, they said, and in the short term, as the Drexel network of lenders is dismantled, some highly leveraged companies will have to scramble to find new sources of financing.

headline: Heavy Activity Despite a Shortened Week
abstract: LEAD: Treasury financings this week include today's weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed by an auction of two-year notes tomorrow and a five-year note on Thursday.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   G.M.'s Response To 'Roger & Me'
abstract: LEAD: The General Motors Corporation has asked its advertising agencies not to place commercials on television programs that feature Michael Moore, the director and star of the satirical documentary film ''Roger & Me,'' an executive at one of G.M.'s agencies said yesterday.

headline: Manila Views Coup's Impact
abstract: LEAD: The recent unsuccessful coup attempt in the Philippines is likely to worsen inflation, put pressure on the currency and dampen foreign investment in the first half of 1990, Vicente Jayme, the Finance Secretary, said Friday.

headline: From a Dark Convoy, Stalin's Specter Looms
abstract: LEAD: When Povilas Zavadskas arose and saw the tanks go by his front window at 4 o'clock this morning, all the shadowy appeal to memory that is at the heart of Lithuania's struggle for sovereignty was before him.

headline: Greenspan's Man on Savings Board
abstract: LEAD: Even before Daniel P. Kearney left the offices of the Resolution Trust Corporation's Oversight Board Friday night, his replacement, William Taylor, the acting president and chief executive, was on the premises.

headline: Protesters Occupy the Communist Party Headquarters in Warsaw
abstract: LEAD: As protesters occupied Communist Party buildings to demand that they be taken over by the state, more than 100 members of the Polish Parliament rallied today behind proposed legislation that would seize Communist Party property and turn it over to the state.

headline: Reporter's Notebook;   The Diplomat Dances Away From Trouble
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d found himself caught the other day in what was, for him, a difficult choice: a chat with either the Palestine Liberation Organization chairman, Yasir Arafat, or the recent Democratic Party presidential aspirant, Jesse Jackson. Mr. Baker opted for Mr. Jackson.  The awkward moment unfolded at midnight on Wednesday as Mr.

headline: A Cigarette Campaign Under Fire
abstract: LEAD: Here in the root and stalk of tobacco country, everyone knows that marketing something that carries a health warning from the Surgeon General is bound to provoke an argument. Mix in race and you really have a shouting match. Just ask the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

headline: Putting the Best Face on Bankruptcy
abstract: LEAD: It is not easy to make bankruptcy look like a positive development, but Bloomingdale's certainly tried this week. The president of the famous retailer, Marvin S. Traub, appeared on the three big television networks with a message directed mainly at consumers: The stores are open for business; the worst is behind us; suppliers will continue to deliver goods, and a new period is beginning.

headline: 11 Kashmir Cities Get Curfew to Counter Militants
abstract: LEAD: The authorities in the northern state of Kashmir have imposed an indefinite curfew in Srinagar, the capital, and 10 other cities after militants seeking independence threatened to disrupt the region, Government officials said today.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it would set up a trust to borrow about $550 million through a private placement to buy stock that will be used for future company contributions to its existing non-management employee savings plan.

headline: Trade Talks Seem to Be at Impasse;   Tokyo Says Requests Are 'Unreasonable'
abstract: LEAD: When the political leaders of the United States and Japan agreed last summer to begin talks over how the most fundamental characteristics of their national economies might change, bureaucrats on both sides said the effort would create frustration and ill will.

headline: Patents;   New Rods Said to Cut Danger of Lightning
abstract: LEAD: Two Florida inventors won patent approval this week on a class of lightning rods shaped like feather dusters. The advantage of the rods, they say, is that they dissipate far more of the ground's static electricity and sharply reduce the chances of being struck by lightning.

headline: Credit Cards Back National City Issue
abstract: LEAD: The National City Corporation, a Cleveland-based bank holding company, is selling $350 million in asset-backed securities through a newly formed National City Credit Card Trust 1990-A.

headline: Chiat Gets 'Rainmaker' From Lintas
abstract: LEAD: DON PEPPERS, whose brash personality and outrageous tactics made him one of the advertising industry's best-known scouts for new business, disclosed yesterday that he was leaving Lintas U.S.A. to become head of worldwide new business development at Chiat/ Day/Mojo.

headline: WORLD DRUG CROP UP SHARPLY IN 1989 DESPITE U.S. EFFORT
abstract: LEAD: The State Department reported today that global production of opium poppies, coca, marijuana and hashish soared in the last year. This occurred despite President Bush's highly publicized effort to curtail drug supply and demand.

headline: Business and Health;   A.T.&T.'s Plan To Slow Costs
abstract: LEAD: AT least a dozen major insurers and health-care chains are bidding to provide the American Telephone and Telegraph Company with an innovative insurance program that will be the nation's largest experiment in managed health care. Under the program, the telephone company and its unions will select networks of doctors and hospitals across the country to try to slow the telephone company's enormous medical spending.

headline: U.S. Sets Offer on Contra Aid
abstract: LEAD: The United States is prepared to provide up to $3 million to an international commission to begin planning the voluntary relocation of contras to Nicaragua provided that democratic conditions exist there, the State Department said today.

headline: U.S. Liftoff Delayed Again
abstract: LEAD: The launching of the space shuttle Atlantis and its secret military cargo was postponed again today until at least Saturday morning.

headline: 2 Tobacco Dealers Set Merger Accord
abstract: LEAD: Two of the nation's largest private tobacco dealers have agreed to merge. The Austin Company, based in Greeneville, and A. C. Monk & Company of Farmville, N.C., said they would form a holding company. No price was disclosed. A name for the new company has not yet been selected, said to Sam J. Calvert Jr.,

Change       1989   from '88        American Express Co.   $ 257,200,000    +11.3        Baker Hughes Inc.   25,400,000    +46.0        Baxter International Inc.   139,000,000    +14.9        Birmingham Steel Corp.   3,500,000    -66.0        Bristol-Myers Squibb Co.   (352,700,000)    -       Browning-Ferris Industries   66,500,000    +11.4        Cleveland-Cliffs Inc.

headline: Market Place;   Ship Companies 'Born to Die'
abstract: LEAD: IN the late 1970's, after spending much of his career in real estate, Michael S. Hudner turned his attention to shipping, an industry that had suffered several protracted downturns but that he believed was due for a recovery. In an attempt to persuade skeptical investors, he constructed a new investment vehicle, whose management would not be allowed to invest in new ships or other ventures once it had spent the original amount raised in a public offering.

headline: Fannie Mae Debentures
abstract: LEAD: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to price $1.4 billion in debentures today equally divided between four-year and 10-year maturities.

headline: Madrid Jolted by Influence-Peddling Charges
abstract: LEAD: Less than three months after winning a third successive term in office, Spain's Socialist Government has been shaken by accusations of influence-peddling by the brother of the Deputy Prime Minister.

headline: CAMPEAU INVOKES BANKRUPTCY CODE FOR ITS BIG STORES
abstract: LEAD: The American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation filed for court protection from creditors yesterday, saying they had debts of about $7.5 billion.

headline: Military Trials of Security Forces Begin
abstract: LEAD: The new Government announced today that special military courts had begun proceedings against members of the state security forces who were caught shooting at civilians after the fall of President Nicolae Ceausescu on Dec. 22.

headline: Bond Tables Are Incomplete
abstract: LEAD: Because of the failure of a computer system at The Associated Press yesterday, the tables listing trading in Government agency bonds could not be processed and do not appear today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          Companies

headline: Prison Term In Juice Case
abstract: LEAD: A former owner of a local fruit juice company was sentenced last week to two years in prison for selling orange juice adulterated with ingredients not listed on container labels.      United States District Judge

headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Diplomacy
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today became the first American Government official to testify before a committee of the Soviet Parliament. He told the legislators that he felt as though he was appearing ''before the Founding Fathers of a new Soviet Union.''

headline: Treasury Notes and Bonds Drop
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell again in fairly active trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities in the wake of a big drop in the dollar.

headline: Police in Kosovo Break Up Albanian Protest
abstract: LEAD: Riot policemen used tear gas and water cannon today to disperse about 40,000 ethnic Albanians demanding the lifting of emergency rule in Kosovo province, witnessess said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Lowe's U.S. Head
abstract: LEAD: The Lowe Group of Britain has appointed Adelaide Horton to the new position of chief operating officer of its American unit, Lowe Group USA. She was formerly a senior vice president at Chiat/Day/Mojo. The Lowe Group's roster of agencies includes Lowe Marschalk.

headline: FSX - Japan's Last Bad Deal
abstract: LEAD: JAPAN'S defense is keyed to America's security needs, not our own, which is an anomaly that reflects our subservient relationship. It is time for us to step out of Uncle Sam's shadow and build a military force suited to our own needs. The place to begin is the next-generation support fighter, code-named the FSX, short for fighter support experimental.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   At Conference, Soviet General Sees Changes in Warsaw Pact
abstract: LEAD: A senior Soviet military official said today that political change sweeping Eastern Europe would require a major reorganization of the Warsaw Pact, but he stressed that the military alliance would continue to exist.

headline: Israelis Accuse a P.L.O. Aide
abstract: LEAD: A military court today identified a leading West Bank Palestinian as a supporter and financial backer of the so-called Palestine Popular Army in an indictment of five alleged members of the group.

headline: As Other Deductions Vanish, Real Estate Endures
abstract: LEAD: There's little mystery to successful investing. No matter what the investments, the key, most financial advisers and accountants agree, is careful planning.

headline: BellSouth Net Up in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: The BellSouth Corporation, a regional Bell telephone company based in Atlanta, said yesterday that its profit in the fourth quarter of 1989 rose 11.9 percent and that its earnings for the year increased 4.2 percent on relatively flat revenues in both periods.

headline: Senate Votes Economic Sanctions Against China
abstract: LEAD: The Senate unanimously approved legislation today that included a series of economic sanctions against China.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Basic Shift In Japan Over Rates
abstract: LEAD: While the Government has intervened heavily in the last two weeks to stabilize the tumbling stock market and bolster the yen, economists and business leaders here say these short-term tactics cannot alter the fundamental economic shift behind the turmoil: the era of extraordinarily low Japanese interest rates is ending.

headline: Bond Wins Court Ruling
abstract: LEAD: The Bond Corporation, the embattled company headed by the flamboyant businessman Alan Bond, has won a key court battle to oust a creditor group that had control over some of its financial operations. Bond will revive negotiations to sell its Australian breweries.

headline: Protestant Militant Seeks a Way Through Ulster Deadlock
abstract: LEAD: Peter Robinson is a frustrated man, and all those who have long awaited a break in the political deadlock here are delighted.

headline: The Nicaraguan Vote: Break With the Past?
abstract: LEAD: As Nicaragua prepares for national elections that all sides hope will draw a clear line between the country's past and its future, Nicaraguans on all sides are counting on the elections to halt their country's long slide into civil strife and economic ruin. Article, page 14.

headline: Yugoslavia Catching East Europe's Political Fever
abstract: LEAD: For months, this nation of scrappy and independent burghers and farmers watched calmly as other East European nations swept away in anger the Communist systems that unlike the one here were imposed by Moscow.

headline: Careers;   Ever-Rising Demand for Paralegals
abstract: LEAD: THE Labor Department recently estimated that the need for paralegals would increase by 75.3 percent between 1988 and 2000, making paralegal work the nation's fastest-growing field. Its projection: the 83,000 paralegals employed nationwide in 1988 will increase to 145,000 by the turn of the century because of rapid growth of the legal services industry as well as widening use of paralegals in corporations and elsewhere.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: ALL ABOUT/Minivans;   Zippy Hybrids Win a Place in the Family Driveway
abstract: LEAD: For sheer inventiveness, there is little in the automotive world to rival theVoyager III, the Chrysler Corporation's vision of the ultimate minivan. As a whole, it resembles a bulbous, stretched-out van. It has two engines and four rear wheels. With the flip of a few switches and levers - voila! - the van separates into two parts: a three-seat urban commuter car and a rear module that can be parked until needed.

headline: For Liberia's Army, the Spoils Include the People's Hatred
abstract: LEAD: Sakou Saysay has had enough and wants to leave. The only obstacle now is finding a wagon big enough to take his 3 wives and 18 children.

headline: Meeting Sought On Nekoosa
abstract: LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that it had solicited enough approval by shareholders of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation to call a special meeting to consider replacing Nekoosa's board with nominees who support its takeover offer.

headline: Gold Falls As Mideast Sales Jump
abstract: LEAD: Gold prices plunged yesterday in New York in near-panic selling on reports of unexpectedly large sales by Middle Eastern interests. Statisticians at the Commodity Exchange in New York said the decline of more than $23 an ounce was the biggest one-day drop since Feb. 28, 1983, when bullion plunged by $42.50, to $400.50.

headline: The Anti-Dumping Laws Do Work
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Who's Z? A Former Student Points to a Berkeley History Professor
abstract: LEAD: A history professor at the University of California at Berkeley has been identified by other scholars as a likely author of a pseudonymous article asserting that Mikhail S. Gorbachev will bring neither democracy nor a market economy to the Soviet Union.

headline: Mortgage Delinquencies
abstract: LEAD: The delinquency rate for home mortgages held steady in the final three months of 1989 after jumping sharply in the previous quarter, a trade group said last week. The group, the Mortgage Bankers Association of America, said a seasonally adjusted 4.99 percent of mortgage payments on homes that house up to four families were late by 30 days or more.

headline: Careers;   Recruiting Trends for The Decade
abstract: LEAD: THE growing trend of companies' hiring outside managers is expected to be a leading trend of the 1990's, Richard M. Ferry of Korn Ferry International, the largest management recruiting firm, said recently.

headline: Japan Seen Extending Auto Quotas
abstract: LEAD: The Japanese Government is expected to announce soon that it will extend its ''voluntary'' quotas on automobile exports to the United States, but Japan's major manufacturers note that the action is now an annual political gesture that has no effect on the sales of Japanese cars.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Philippines Says U.S. Is Violating Bases Pact
abstract: LEAD: Manila accused the United States today of violating provisions in an agreement on two United States military bases in the Philippines and warned that the issue could affect negotiations on the bases' future.

headline: Managing;   Letting Employees In on the News
abstract: LEAD: Back in December, the Chrysler Corporation said it wanted to sell its Gulfstream Aerospace subsidiary. Less than 24 hours later, Allen E. Paulson, Gulfstream's founder and chief executive, went public with his plans to buy it.

headline: Article 372790 -- No Title
abstract: LEAD: Ford Holdings Inc. yesterday priced a two-part financing totaling $1 billion through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Philips Deal Is Stopped
abstract: LEAD: Philips Industries, a Dayton-based manufacturer, said Friday that a planned merger for $24 a share, or $672 million, with a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company would not go through as scheduled because of problems with financing.

headline: Eastern Air In Pact With Its Creditors
abstract: LEAD: After nearly a year of negotiations, Eastern Airlines reached an agreement in principle yesterday with its unsecured creditors on a plan to bring the carrier out of bankruptcy within several months.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Communist Luminaries Shot a Lot
abstract: LEAD: Leonid I. Brezhnev, Fidel Castro and other Communist luminaries would bag up to 2,000 hares and pheasants a day on luxury hunting estates in Czechoslovakia, the state press agency said today.

headline: Saar Vote Sets Stage For Challenge to Kohl
abstract: LEAD: Oskar Lafontaine, the brash, quick-witted Premier of Saarland state, scored an impressive victory in the state election today, virtually insuring that he will be named the Social Democratic challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in national elections next December.

headline: Joint Venture Expected For Display Screens
abstract: LEAD: Several electronics companies are discussing the formation of a venture to develop and produce display screens for use in laptop computers, military gear and television sets, an official involved in the venture said today.

headline: Stocks in Tokyo Decline Slightly
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices declined slightly today on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. The United States dollar opened higher against the Japanese yen.

headline: Patents;   University Sues Inventor Of Retin-A
abstract: LEAD: Retin-A , the acne medicine that has become much talked about in recent years as a possible ''anti-aging'' cream that smooths out facial wrinkles, is now the subject of a nasty patent battle.

headline: Binks Stake Sold
abstract: LEAD: Illinois Tool Works Inc., which on Feb. 20 made an unsolicited offer of $45 a share for the Binks Manufacturing Company, said its Ransburg Corporation subsidiary was selling some of its Binks holdings. Binks, based in Franklin Park, Ill., had rejected Illinois Tools' offer. Binks's stock closed today at $44.875, down 25 cents, on the American Stock Exchange.

headline: A.T.&T. Is Adding More Translators
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would greatly expand its translation services to provide businesses and consumers with telephone interpreters who can help with 143 languages and dialects, 24 hours a day.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Economic Goal;   Unsnarling a Tangled Trade Alliance
abstract: LEAD: As the current Comecon negotiations in Bulgaria make clear, both the Soviet Union and the nations of Eastern Europe are eager to untangle their economic embrace. The $10 billion question yet to be decided is how rapidly and on what terms.

headline: Sale of F-16's Set
abstract: LEAD: Portugal will buy 20 General Dynamics Corporation F-16 warplanes from the United States in the next three years for $450 million, a military spokesman said. A United States Embassy spokesman here said much of the cost would be met through grants under the Lajes Accord, which covers United States bases on Portugal's mid-Atlantic Azores Islands and military cooperation between the two NATO allies.

headline: India Acts to Extend Punjab Rule
abstract: LEAD: Facing a surge in violence and a deteriorating political climate in the Indian state of Punjab, the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh plans to renew its special powers to rule the state through an appointed governor.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Columbia Savings Gets Chairman
abstract: LEAD: Just a few weeks after Thomas Spiegel resigned as chairman of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association to help sort out problems with ''junk bond'' holdings, the savings institution has named his father, Abraham, to the post.

headline: Airlines' Big Gamble on Expansion
abstract: LEAD: The nation's biggest airlines, stung by higher fuel prices and a slowdown in traffic in recent months, are nevertheless gambling on a turnaround and for the most part proceeding with ambitious expansion plans. But with a record number of new planes set for delivery this year, the carriers could find themselves stretched to remain profitable if current conditions continue, analysts say.

headline: Gorbachev Is at Fault, Chess Champion Says
abstract: LEAD: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, said today that Soviet troops should withdraw from the Azerbaijani republic and that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev should take full responsibility for the ethnic violence there.

headline: A Strategist at American Express
abstract: LEAD: Harvey Golub, the chairman and chief executive of IDS Financial Services Inc., the American Express Company's highly successful financial-planning division, will be a key adviser to Howard L. Clark Jr., the newly appointed head of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

headline: Upheaval in ht e East: Bulgaria;   ACCORD IN SOFIA ON ETHNIC DISPUTE
abstract: LEAD: Government and opposition representatives reached an agreement today aimed at defusing ethnic tension between Bulgarians and Muslims.

headline: Crowds in Britain Fight Police Over a New Tax
abstract: LEAD: Angry crowds pelted police with cans, sticks and bottles today as demonstrations against Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's unpopular new ''poll tax'' erupted into violence.

headline: COMPUTER MAKERS HALT A CHALLENGE TO JAPANESE CHIPS
abstract: LEAD: A trail-blazing attempt at cooperation among American manufacturers in the face of a challenge from Japanese industry is being abandoned because it has failed to attract enough investors, people in the computer industry said today.

headline: Mayor Who Faulted Hirohito Is Shot
abstract: LEAD: The Mayor of Nagasaki, who broke one of the nation's most sensitive taboos by saying a year ago that Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot today, and the police arrested a 40-year-old ultranationalist.

headline: Coffee Exports Spurt
abstract: LEAD: World exports of coffee jumped by nearly 25 percent last year after international controls on sales were abolished in July, the International Coffee Organization said this week. Exports to all destinations in the last half of 1989 totaled 39.6 million bags, compared with 31.9 million in the comparable period of 1988, the organization reported.

headline: Lonely Days for Traders at Budapest Exchange
abstract: LEAD: With a dozen personal computers placed neatly around a square table in a stuffy, windowless room, Hungary's stock exchange seems more like a student pilot project than a functioning financial market.

headline: SALVADOR REBELS BACK PEACE TALKS
abstract: LEAD: Leftist rebels accepted a Government proposal today to ask the Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations to mediate peace talks, and proposed that negotiations start within 30 days.

headline: Two Resign At D.F. King
abstract: LEAD: Two senior executives of D. F. King & Company, a firm that solicits proxies from investors in takeovers and other corporate contests, resigned yesterday, the firm said.

headline: Inquiry Looks At Bush's Son
abstract: LEAD: Federal regulators are scheduled to meet on Thursday to determine whether Neil Bush, the President's son, violated Federal banking laws as a board member of a Colorado savings and loan institution that became insolvent.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Russians;   Cry of 'Won't Give My Son!' And Soviets End the Call-Up
abstract: LEAD: The Kremlin abandoned its emergency mobilization of army reserves today after an outpouring of protests from Russian parents unwilling to let their sons police the fighting in Azerbaijan.

headline: Citibank Seeking to Join Automated Teller Network
abstract: LEAD: Citibank, which has refrained from sharing its automated teller machines with other banks in the New York City area, is trying to join one of the two largest national networks on terms that would give Citibank's depositors access to other banks' machines but would limit other bank customers' access to

headline: Simmons Raises Lockheed Holding
abstract: LEAD: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas financier, has raised his stake in the Lockheed Corporation to 17.9 percent from 16.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons did not amend his previous statement that he has no immediate plans to take over the military contractor, which is based in Calabasas,

headline: Converting a Mill;   Condos in 19th-Century Structures
abstract: LEAD: In 1844, when Robert Beattie, an Irish immigrant, built a brownstone carpet mill on the banks of the Passaic River in Little Falls, N.J., he brought jobs, the railroad and residents to the tiny community. Now, a century and a half later, Mr. Beattie's mill is stimulating new growth for the town.

headline: Dow Off 10.82, A Comeback After Plunge
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 62 points in the first half-hour of trading yesterday, then climbed back during the balance of the day to close at 2,604.50, down 10.82.

headline: Challenge for Panamanians: A Canal in Transition
abstract: LEAD: Most first-time visitors to this famous vantage point on the Panama Canal, eight miles from the Pacific, come away dazzled by the majesty of the 51.2-mile waterway and the near-miraculous ingenuity and sacrifice that went into its construction more than 75 years ago.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   MOSCOW'S TROOPS CONSOLIDATE HOLD OVER AZERBAIJAN
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Army consolidated its occupation of Baku today as leaders of the Azerbaijan Popular Front made plans to stage a general protest strike throughout the strife-ridden Soviet republic.

headline: Paulson Group Won't Buy Learjet
abstract: LEAD: The group that is acquiring the Gulfstream Aerospace Corporation has let its $60 million agreement to buy the Learjet Corporation expire. Gulfstream said its chairman, Allen E. Paulson, had decided not to acquire Learjet out of concern that the Chapter 11 bankruptcy of the jet maker's parent, Integrated Resources

headline: Business and Health;   Medical Insurance And Job Mobility
abstract: LEAD: AMONG the many horror stories from people who have difficulty obtaining health insurance, that of Paul Tobias is a striking example. Mr. Tobias, an internationally known cellist who has appeared as a guest soloist with the New York Philharmonic, said several major insurers had rejected him and his wife, Elizabeth Moschetti, a concert pianist.

headline: Perrier Stock Off On Japanese Move
abstract: LEAD: The stock of Source Perrier fell sharply for a second straight day today after the Japanese distributor of the French water followed the lead of the United States and withdrew tens of thousands of bottles because of health concerns. Suntory Ltd. said in Tokyo that it had suspended sales temporarily and recalled 10,000 cases of

headline: Obstacles Remain In Path to Solvency
abstract: LEAD: Although Eastern Airlines is beginning to attract more passengers and is likely to get an infusion of cash soon from its parent, the Texas Air Corporation, it still faces large hurdles in its effort to emerge from bankruptcy protection as a profitable regional carrier.

headline: Pretoria Troops Sent to Ciskei Riots
abstract: LEAD: South African troops were ordered into Ciskei today to restore order after a wave of looting and destruction unleashed by a military coup Sunday in the nominally independent homeland.

headline: New Weapon in War on Insects: Hot Air
abstract: LEAD: rrSeeking to avoid the use of toxic chemicals in eliminating indoor insect infestations, two California scientists have developed a method that relies solely on hot air.

headline: SRI LANKA MUSLIMS THREATEN TO FIGHT
abstract: LEAD: Leaders of Sri Lanka's Muslim minority, fearful that their interests will be ignored in the granting of more autonomy to Tamil areas, are threatening to appeal to Islamic nations for support.

headline: Recycled Paper Spurs a New Debate: What Is It?
abstract: LEAD: The American paper industry has pledged to recycle 40 percent of its output by 1995 to reduce the amount of waste paper now being buried in landfills. But the president of a company specializing in selling recycled paper said much of what the industry calls recycled paper was mill scrap that had never been used by the public.

headline: 43.46 Decline Leaves Dow At 2,561.04
abstract: LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks plunged 43.46 points, to 2,561.04, yesterday, as upward pressure on interest rates and the flow of poor corporate profits kept many investors on the sidelines.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Czechoslovaks Pursue Diplomatic Initiatives
abstract: LEAD: Czechoslovakia's new coalition Government is energetically exploring new avenues in foreign relations in Eastern and Western Europe and farther afield.

headline: Brady Going To Group of 7 Talks in April
abstract: LEAD: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady said today that he will go to Paris next month to meet with financial leaders of the Group of Seven industrial nations to discuss recent economic developments around the world.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   51 Years After Hitler Marched In, Prague Welcomes a German Chief
abstract: LEAD: Fifty-one years to the day after Hitler arrived here at the head of an occupying army, President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia today greeted the President of West Germany with a speech that equated anti-German feeling with anti-Semitism, and an offer to build a Europe free of recriminations.

headline: 8 Die as South African Police Fire On Protesters in Black Township
abstract: LEAD: The South African police opened fire today on black anti-apartheid and hospital workers reported that eight people were killed and hundreds wounded.

headline: A.T.& T. Cutback
abstract: LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said its New River Valley electronics plant, with 1,000 employees, would phase out its operations within 15 months. Jay Walters, the plant's manufacturing director, said the shutdown resulted from excess capacity throughout A.T.& T.'s microelectronics business.

headline: India Tells of Foiling Uprising in Kashmir
abstract: LEAD: Officials in Srinagar, the Kashmiri capital, said today that separatists had planned to declare independence from India on Friday and send thousands of supporters into the streets in a show of force timed to coincide with India's independence day. The officials say the plan was foiled after a number of leading Kashmiri militants were captured by the security forces.

headline: Winner at Xtra Calls Proxy Fights Wearing
abstract: LEAD: Robert M. Gintel, who emerged the winner last week in the Xtra Corporation proxy fight, said he was not eager to get involved in another anytime soon.

headline: U.S. Says Arafat Sticks to Word On Renouncing Terrorism in Israel
abstract: LEAD: The State Department, in a report sent to Congress, credits Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, with adhering to his commitment renouncing terrorism.

headline: Collor Receptive to Criticism Of Brazil's Policy in Amazon
abstract: LEAD: Facing foreign criticism of Brazil's treatment of the Amazon region and the Indians living in its rain forest, Brazil's President-elect has been surprisingly conciliatory.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Gorbachev Discusses Crisis With Thatcher
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev discussed the crisis in Lithuania with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain today, British officials and the official press agency Tass reported.

headline: Thinking Machines Seen in Japan Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Thinking Machines Corporation, a maker of parallel supercomputers, will announce this week that it has sold its first machine in Japan. The Japanese organization, Auditory and Visual Perception Research Laboratories, is associated with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company. The group said it was buying the supercomputer, known as a CM-2 Connection

headline: Control Data Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Control Data Corporation said today that it expects its fiscal year 1989 restructuring costs to climb to more than $650 million with the addition of a fourth-quarter charge of $210 million. With the restructuring charges, the computer maker said it would incur a loss in the fourth quarter and for the year.

headline: Rate Moves: No Firm Global Link
abstract: LEAD: When interest rates go up in one major industrial country, must they also do so in others? The recent rise of West German, Japanese and American rates, in tandem, has given that impression. But plenty of room still exists for the United States to control its own interest rates, even going against the trend in other countries.

headline: Merrill Lynch Deal to Sell Canada Unit
abstract: LEAD: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Canadian retail securities brokerage business to Wood Gundy Inc., a leading Canadian investment firm.

headline: Rumania Seeks Trade Status
abstract: LEAD: The new Government said today that it would seek most-favored-nation trading status with the United States. Nicolae Ceausescu, the executed dictator, renounced the American trade agreement in February 1988, when it appeared that Congress would not renew it because of rights abuses under Mr. Ceausescu.

headline: Carl Jr. Expands
abstract: LEAD: Carl Karcher Enterprises Inc. signed a licensing agreement to establish its Carl's Jr. fast-food restaurant chain in nine Pacific Rim countries. The agreement is with the MBF Group, a financial services firm based in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, which already operates Grandy's fast-food restaurants in the Pacific.

headline: Your Money;   States Increase Tax Vigilance
abstract: LEAD: Many taxpayers will find state tax collectors newly vigilant this year. States are hungry for revenues, and with ever-improving computer and investigatory skills they are making aggressive efforts to step up tax collections.

headline: Maged & Behar
abstract: LEAD: Murdoch Magazines has selected Maged & Behar as the advertising agency for the Salon Network, a video magazine program for beauty salons that will make its debut in June. The commercially sponsored program will include features derived from the Murdoch magazines Mirabella, New Woman, Seventeen and European Travel & Life.

headline: Birmingham Deal Loses Financing
abstract: LEAD: A deal for the acquisition of the Birmingham Steel Corporation foundered when the buyer indicated it would not be able to obtain financing for the deal. In a letter to Birmingham, Duffy Holdings Inc. said its financial adviser, Bear, Stearns, did not believe an acquisition of Birmingham could be financed because of deteriorating financial results at

headline: A.T.&T.-Tandem Computer Venture
abstract: LEAD: Tandem Computers Inc. and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said they would jointly develop and market computer systems combining Tandem's ''fault tolerant'' designs and A.T.& T.'s Unix operating system software.

headline: Car Sales Off 20.2% at End Of December
abstract: LEAD: Despite a late surge in light-truck sales, American auto makers ended December and last year with total sales badly depressed and little confidence that the current salesroom incentives are enough to solve the problem.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Bonn Again Sidesteps Warsaw's Growing Demand for Guarantees on Its Borders
abstract: LEAD: A spokesman for Chancellor Helmut Kohl today again dodged Poland's growing demand that West Germany affirm the permanence of the two countries' border. But pressures mounted on Mr. Kohl both at home and abroad to issue the unequivocal guarantee that the Poles are seeking.

headline: Lockheed Board's 'Greenmail' Stance
abstract: LEAD: The Lockheed Corporation, defending itself against a planned proxy fight by the Dallas financier Harold C. Simmons, said its board had passed a resolution affirming its opposition to the payment of ''greenmail.'' A proposal made on Monday by Mr. Simmons, who owns 18.9 percent of Lockheed, would ban such payments on stock held less than two years.

headline: Management Realigned At Young & Rubicam
abstract: LEAD: Young & Rubicam Inc. announced a nearly complete management realignment yesterday. Peter A. Georgescu, who had been president of Young & Rubicam Advertising, was named president of Young & Rubicam Inc., a title formerly held by the chairman and chief executive, Alexander Kroll. Joseph E. DeDeo, formerly president of Young & Rubicam Europe, was named president and chief executive of Y.&R.

headline: New Xerox Copier
abstract: LEAD: The Xerox Corporation introduced a new copier that can ''phone home'' for help when it senses a problem developing. The Xerox 5065, a mid-volume copier that produces 62 copies a minute, is the first Xerox copier to offer a built-in ''remote interactive communications'' system, which continuously checks the copier's performance and alerts a central computer when it notices a potential problem, a Xerox spokesman said.

headline: Dow Slips 5.85, to 2,553.38, in Light Trading
abstract: LEAD: Stock prices dropped again yesterday in sharply slower trading.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       Many health insurers have quietly blacklisted dozens of types of small businesses and professions. While some insurance companies have been accused of denying coverage to people in cities and occupations where the insurers contend the AIDS virus is most prevalent, the exclusions extend well beyond these groups.

headline: Prague Is Showing Off an Empty Secret Police Headquarters
abstract: LEAD: The Government showed the Czechoslovak public one of its proudest achievements today. It was a massive building that takes up most of a city block, and it was totally deserted.

headline: COMPANY NEWSB.P. to Reduce Staff by 1,150
abstract: LEAD: The British Petroleum Company said today that it was cutting 1,150 jobs, or nearly half the staff, at its London headquarters in a reorganization intended to lower costs and make the oil giant more flexible.

headline: 'Fax Poll' Paying Off
abstract: LEAD: At Business Month, they resist the term ''repositioning'' to describe the new look and tone of the magazine's March issue.

headline: Gallipoli Journal;   Echo of Long-Ago Battles Stirs Sleeping Peninsula
abstract: LEAD: The problem with today's youngsters, Feridun Kanten said, echoing a lament that probably began when Adam and Eve were having trouble with their kids, is that they want everything easy.

headline: McCaw Loses $58.4 Million
abstract: LEAD: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had lost $58.4 million in the fourth quarter.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Aldus Corp., Seattle, a provider of computer programming and other software services, said it would acquire Silicon Beach Software, San Diego, a software publisher, through a merger in which shares of Aldus common stock would be exchanged for all of the outstanding shares of Silicon Beach.

headline: A Gallimard Sets Deadline
abstract: LEAD: The feuding Gallimards, owners of a publishing house whose authors include Marcel Proust and Jean-Paul Sartre, have until mid-February to bid for 12.5 percent of company and end a fight for control.

headline: Message for Nicaragua's Victors: Things Must Get Better, and Fast
abstract: LEAD: With the store shelves largely bare and one-third of the work force without a job, Nicaraguans are serving notice that they expect the newly elected government to bring about rapid improvement or face political consequences.

headline: Starts of Housing at Lowest Level Since '82
abstract: LEAD: Housing construction slumped in 1989 to its lowest level since the 1982 recession, the Government said today, but many analysts said further decreases in mortgage rates should improve the situation slightly in 1990.

headline: Charges Seen For Developer
abstract: LEAD: The General Development Corporation, a real estate developer based in Miami, disclosed today that the company, its mortgage banking subsidiary and members of its senior management are facing possible criminal indictments.

headline: Profits Scoreboard
abstract: LEAD:      $      Net Income   Percent        Oct.-Dec.   Change        1989    From '88        Allied-Signal Inc.   $ 115,000,000    +10.6        A.T.&T. Co.   705,000,000     *-       Cooper Industries   89,900,000    +20.3        Data General Corp.   (20,500,000)    -       R.R. Donnelley & Sons   68,100,000    +5.6        Dow Corning Corp.

headline: Cuba Fights New Telecast From U.S.
abstract: LEAD: Days from the start of direct television broadcasts from the United States to Cuba, Cuban officials are calling them illegal and considering ways to stop them.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Jefferson Smurfit In Recycling Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Jefferson Smurfit Group P.L.C. agreed to buy a Southern California newsprint recycling mill from the Giant Group Ltd. for $95 million plus $25 million later if Jefferson Smurfit decides to expand the mill within several years. The mill, the Golden State Newsprint Company in Pomona, Calif., also operates 10 recycling centers.

headline: Precious Metals Are Down While Crude Oil Prices Rise
abstract: LEAD: Precious metal prices continued to fall yesterday, largely on the firmness of the dollar and the belief that the Federal Reserve will not reduce interest rates because of recent signs of economic improvement.

headline: G.M. Plans To Merge Engine Units
abstract: LEAD: In a move that analysts say may cut costs and improve efficiency, the General Motors Corporation disclosed plans today to consolidate its two engine operations into a single division.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Washington;   Tough Choice for the U.S.: Baltic States or Gorbachev
abstract: LEAD: The drive for independence in Lithuania and the other Baltic states has presented the United States with a diplomatic quandary, Administration officials said today.

headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Yugoslavia;   A Sign of Bad Times in Yugoslavia: Trade War Between Two Republics
abstract: LEAD: Shoppers in the ''Beograd Woman'' department store will find that the mention of certain brand names can make the staff snap as though a curse had just been directed at them.

headline: Issues of 'Junk Bonds' Off Sharply in Quarter
abstract: LEAD: Underwritings of ''junk bonds'' shrank dramatically in the first quarter, reflecting the disarray in the market for these high-yield, high-risk securities and the downfall of Drexel Burnham Lambert.

headline: Genentech Seeks Approval for Drug
abstract: LEAD: Genentech filed an application with the Food and Drug Administration seeking approval to sell gamma interferon to treat patients with chronic granulomatous disease. If approved, it would be the third drug created by genetic engineering to be sold by the biotechnology company, based in South San Francisco, Calif.

headline: Korea Accepts Du Pont Plant
abstract: LEAD: After a four-year delay, South Korea has authorized E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's application to build a $97 million titanium dioxide plant with a local company, the Finance Ministry said Friday.

headline: New Options Rule Cleared
abstract: LEAD: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he had decided not to delay a new rule that would allow an option to be listed on more than one exchange in the United States.

headline: Gillette In Accord on Antitrust Suit
abstract: LEAD: The Gillette Company and the Justice Department announced an agreement yesterday to settle an antitrust lawsuit in which the department had challenged Gillette's purchase of a significant portion of Wilkinson Sword Inc.

headline: 2 Nuns, One From U.S., Are Slain By Gunmen in Nicaragua Ambush
abstract: LEAD: Two Roman Catholic nuns, one of them American, were killed Monday night when their pickup truck was attacked on an isolated highway in this remote Atlantic Coast region by armed men who Government and church officials said were American-backed contras.

headline: Sun-Times to Sell Building
abstract: LEAD: The Chicago Sun-Times Company announced today that it would sell its newspaper building and build a new printing plant to replace its outdated presses.

headline: Talking Deals;   A Team Approach For Orbital Plane
abstract: LEAD: FOR the last five years some of the nation's largest aerospace companies have been competing to design and build an aircraft that could take off from a runway and fly at 25 times the speed of sound directly into orbit. But this week, faced with daunting technological challenges and the prospect of Federal budget cuts, the companies said they wanted to stop competing and start cooperating.

headline: New Executive Team At Wickes Lumber
abstract: LEAD: The Wickes Lumber Company, a major supplier of building materials, yesterday announced the appointment of a new management team: William A. Hensler, from inside the company, and Philip M. Chrusz, from outside.

headline: Iraq Executes British-Based Journalist Convicted of Spying
abstract: LEAD: Iraq said today it had executed a British-based journalist who was convicted last week of spying by an Iraqi revolutionary court.

headline: Stocks Drop in Tokyo
abstract: LEAD: Share prices fell on the Tokyo Stock Exchange this morning as the United States dollar recovered slightly from its lows. Stocks fell almost across the board, and the 225-issue Nikkei average lost 535.01 points, or 1.43 percent, to end the morning at 36,843.01. The index had gained 121.01 points on Tuesday.

headline: East Germany Is Still Spying On the West, Magazine Says
abstract: LEAD: East Germany has bugged telephone conversations of West German Government officials for years, and evidence indicates it continues to do so, a news magazine reported today.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Lucinda Holmes has been named president of Lowe International.

headline: Gorbachev Picks a New Cabinet: Old Allies and a Few Hard-Liners
abstract: LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has named his first Cabinet, balancing the choice of some of his closest partners in change with two figures who have been openly hostile to aspects of his program, the official press agency Tass reported today.

headline: Pontiac Sees Gain in '90
abstract: LEAD: The Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation said today that it expected its domestic market share to rise in 1990 to as much as 7.5 percent from 7.2 percent last year. Pontiac's general manager, John Middlebrook, said an array of new vehicles should help spur sales.

headline: Aeroflot Buys First Airliners From West
abstract: LEAD: In its first order for Western aircraft, Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, bought five A310 airliners from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium said yesterday.

headline: U.S. Won't Join Hughes Lawsuit
abstract: LEAD: The Justice Department said it would not join in a whistle-blower lawsuit that charged the Hughes Aircraft Company with selling $3.2 billion in potentially flawed computer chips to the Navy. A spokesman said the department would ''not join the suit at this time.'' Richard Dore, a Hughes spokesman, said, ''Obviously, we're very satisfied with the Government's decision.

headline: Approval of Extra Money For Savings Rescue Is Near
abstract: LEAD: The agency that oversees the bailout of the savings and loan industry is close to approving a plan that will permit the additional borrowing of more than $40 billion from the Treasury Department this year. The new money is needed to cover the interim costs of taking over and selling off insolvent institutions.

headline: Pennsylvania to Toughen Bill to Thwart Takeovers
abstract: LEAD: In a move that could severely hinder proxy fights in Pennsylvania, the state's Legislature moved on Monday to make what is already the nation's toughest state anti-takeover statute even tougher.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   KREMLIN BYPASSED IN MEDIATION OFFER
abstract: LEAD: A new sort of political initiative has emerged beyond the Kremlin's orbit with the resourceful Baltic separatist movements persuading their counterparts in the feuding southern republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan to hold peace talks in the Latvian republic.

headline: Freedom in a Locked Ward in Vilnius
abstract: LEAD: At midnight the scene at the city psychiatric hospital seemed a microcosm of the state of Lithuanian independence.

abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   11.00        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   6.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.18   8.12   9.35        3-MO. headline: S.E.C. Looks At Interstate
abstract: LEAD: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun an ''informal inquiry'' into First Interstate Bancorp's $400 million write-down during the fourth period to cover possible losses at the company's troubled Texas operations.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   With 3 Dead, Soldiers Break Up Romanian and Hungarian Mobs
abstract: LEAD: Army tanks and troops separated rival, taunting crowds of Romanians and ethnic Hungarians today in a Transylvania city where three people were killed and 300 hurt in fighting on Tuesday night between mobs wielding iron bars, scythes and pitchforks, witnesses said.

headline: Hiring a Preparers Can Ease the Pain
abstract: LEAD: THE 50 million Americans who will pay someone to prepare their income tax returns this year face an important choice: what kind of service to use.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Harper's Is Proud of Its Circulation THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Campbell-Mithun Buys Drossman Lehmann
abstract: LEAD: EVERY month, in a feature entitled ''Annotation,'' Harper's Magazine calls on an expert to decode a document in his or her field, telling readers the real meaning behind the abbreviations and arcana that constitute the expert's written world. A screenwriter might explain a screenplay, or a doctor might interpret a hospital bill.

headline: Company News;   I.B.M. Introduction May Come Earlier
abstract: LEAD: A computer industry analyst said he expected the International Business Machines Corporation to introduce the next generation of its most powerful mainframe computer earlier than had generally been expected. The analyst, Rick Martin of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., told Reuters yesterday that he expected I.B.M.

headline: Teheran Denies Direct Discussions With U.S. on Hostages in Beirut;   Hostage Demands Pressed
abstract: LEAD: A clandestine pro-Iranian group believed to be holding three of the eight Americans missing in Lebanon said today that it would not free the hostages before its demands are met.

headline: Party's Agenda: Liberty and Justice
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Communist Party adopted a platform last week endorsing the abolition of the party's constitutional monopoly on political power and other changes. The text of the platform was distributed on Monday night by the official press agency Tass. Here are excerpts from the platform, as translated by Tass.

headline: A Firm Step, a Smile: Mandela Floods the Screen
abstract: LEAD: The moment was worth the wait. Along the road leading out of Victor Verster prison he appeared, hand in hand with his wife as though strolling to Sunday church, and everything we had been hearing of the man's dignity and strength was there on the screen.

headline: Serbia's President Threatens to Colonize Kosovo
abstract: LEAD: The president of the Serbian republic threatened today to send hundreds of thousands of Serbs to take over the province of Kosovo, the scene of a fierce ethnic feud.

headline: Mortgage Rates Are Up
abstract: LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 10.34 percent, up from 10.29 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.55 percent this week, up from 8.5 percent the week before.

headline: Court Backs Right of Boards to Deny Takeover Offers
abstract: LEAD: In a decision that will help many of the nation's biggest companies fend off hostile takeovers, a three-judge panel of the Delaware Supreme Court ruled yesterday that corporations have a right to decide their own future rather than sell to the highest bidder.

headline: Australian Airbus Order
abstract: LEAD: Ansett Airlines has ordered 10 Airbus Industrie A321 aircraft for delivery between 1995 and 1999, the General Electric Company said Wednesday. G.E. said in a statement that CFM International, which it owns jointly with Snecma of France, had won the order to supply engines for the planes.

headline: Insider Case Is Settled
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday approved a settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and a typesetting supervisor accused of illegally trading on confidential information from advance copies of Business Week magazine.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 20, 1990
abstract: LEAD:    Companies

headline: Tokyo Journal;   Emperor Stops for Traffic Lights; Is It a Portent?
abstract: LEAD: A year to the day after Emperor Hirohito died, Japan today completed the ceremony of burying him, and perhaps with him some of the memories of Japan's militaristic past that shadowed the Japanese royal family through Hirohito's life.

headline: FORUM;  Salvaging the Junk Market
abstract: LEAD: If the collapse of Drexel Burnham Lambert has taught us anything, it is that when life hands you a lemon, make lemonade.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   SOVIETS APPROVE THE RIGHT TO OWN SMALL BUSINESSES
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Parliament approved a property law today that gives private citizens the right to own small-scale factories and other businesses for the first time since the 1920's.

headline: U.S. Bond Auction Goes Poorly
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Government's first auction of 40-year bonds since the mid-1950's went poorly yesterday, as investors demanded higher-than-expected interest rates on $5 billion worth of bonds issued by the Resolution Funding Corporation that will be used to finance the bailout of insolvent savings institutions.

headline: Snapple Drink Account Has Moved Once Again
abstract: LEAD: The fast-moving Snapple Natural Beverage Company account has landed with Buckley/DeCerchio. Last at Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company, since 1986 the account has also been held by Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss and Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, as well as by a defunct media buying service.

headline: Will Federated's Chief Have Time?
abstract: LEAD: At the helm of Bullock's five years ago, Allen I. Questrom ordered the West Coast department store chain to pull out of a data exchange through which competing chains tracked short-term shifts in market share. He warned his merchandisers and buyers to think of the long term because short-term gains mean little in the life of any business.

headline: Carter Applauds Nicaraguans On Election-Monitoring Plan
abstract: LEAD: Strongly praising Government preparations for the Feb. 25 national elections, former President Jimmy Carter left Managua on Sunday night after mediating between Sandinista and opposition leaders on concerns ranging from reported police intimidation to restrictions on campaign funds.

headline: Retail Group President
abstract: LEAD: As expected, John J. Schultz has been named president of the National Retail Federation's retail services division in New York, effective Sunday. He succeeds James R. Williams, who is resigning to become a consultant. Mr. Schultz was most recently president and chief executive of the B. Altman & Company chain of department stores.

headline: Election Means Little in Contra Camp
abstract: LEAD: While this country prepares for elections, rebels in the steamy forests here are getting ready for war.

headline: Eurotunnel Dispute on Costs Ended
abstract: LEAD: The latest dispute to threaten completion of a tunnel under the English Channel was settled today after the owners and builders of the venture agreed to name an American executive to head the project management team.

headline: Salvadoran President Announces Arrests of 8 in Killing of 6 Jesuits
abstract: LEAD: President Alfredo Cristiani today announced the arrest of a colonel, two lieutenants and five lower-ranking soldiers in the slaying of six Jesuit priests in November. He said another soldier was being sought in the killings.

headline: Banks' Profits Fell 35% in '89
abstract: LEAD: Profits at American banks fell 35 percent in 1989, to $16.3 billion, largely because bad loans sharply eroded earnings in the second half of the year, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today.

headline: U.S. Concern on Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: Washington said an increase in Moscow's political pressure against Lithuania's independence movement was ''cause for concern.'' Page A18.

headline: Poland's Foreign Lenders Accept Unusual Extension of Payments
abstract: LEAD: The United States, West Germany and other major Polish creditors showed support for the Solidarity-led Government today by extending the payment deadlines for $9.4 billion of Poland's hard-currency debt on unusually lenient terms.

headline: A Sense of Wonder Among the Mere Bystanders
abstract: LEAD: Some people were thunderstruck. Others were numb, unable to absorb one more remarkable blow to Communism. Many were wary, waiting to see if Mikhail S. Gorbachev could ''stay one step ahead of the sheriff,'' as the conservative columnist Robert Novak put it.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Marriott Corp., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, for its Fairfield Inn division, with a budget of $4 million.

headline: In Magazines, It's a Man's World Once Again
abstract: LEAD: Ever on the lookout for what is truly hot, the magazine industry has come up with a sizzler. It has discovered men.

headline: Diplomats See Barriers to a Trial of Salvador Military
abstract: LEAD: Despite President Alfredo Cristiani's announcement that an investigation has revealed Army involvement in the killing of eight people, including six outspoken Jesuit priests, there are major obstacles to a successful prosecution, diplomats and lawyers here said today.

headline: Court Backs Broad Definition for Securities
abstract: LEAD: Endorsing a broad interpretation of Federal securities law, the Supreme Court ruled today that many unsecured promissory notes, sold privately and not traded on any stock exchange, were subject to Federal regulation as securities.

headline: New Report Shows Loss At Shawmut
abstract: LEAD: The Shawmut National Corporation said yesterday that after an examination by Federal banking regulators it had revised its 1989 earnings to show a loss of $128.9 million. In January it had reported a profit of $201.7 million.

headline: Pressure On the Fed Increasing
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Reserve Board's Open Market Committee is probably not going to approve a change in monetary policy when it meets tomorrow in Washington. But a growing number of analysts say the central bank may now be leaning toward its first tightening of policy in nearly a year.

headline: Bankers Trust Debt Ratings Are Downgraded by S.&P.
abstract: LEAD: The debt ratings for about $2.9 billion in securities issued by the Bankers Trust New York Corporation have been downgraded, the Standard & Poor's Corporation announced yesterday.

headline: Italy Prepares, in Its Way, for the World Cup
abstract: LEAD: In the high-wire act that most people call Italy, where Government disaster is often only a misstep away, doomsday scenarios are in full bloom for the World Cup soccer finals that will be held here in June.

headline: Two Renegade Officers Arrested in Philippines
abstract: LEAD: Soldiers seized two renegade officers linked to coup attempts today, and a rebellious provincial Governor agreed to step down and end his 12-day defiance of President Corazon C. Aquino.

headline: Co-Founder Leaves Next
abstract: LEAD: The vice president of sales at Next Inc. has left the company to become vice president of sales and marketing at the Go Corporation, a start-up computer company that is developing a portable that users can control with handwriting.

headline: Teachers to Go to Poland
abstract: LEAD: The Peace Corps announced today that it would send its first contingent to Poland, 60 volunteers who will train English teachers there.

headline: Managing;   When the Boss Wears a Hula Skirt
abstract: LEAD: Dave Holmes realized that the meeting was turning into a disaster. After three uplifting days, the top worldwide managers in Du Pont's wire and cable unit had suddenly become defeatist and morose.

headline: Aoun's Troops Rout Christian Rivals
abstract: LEAD: Army troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun routed rival militiamen in a strategic coastal town north of here today, as fierce artillery and rocket fighting also raged in Christian East Beirut.

headline: Orange Losses Are Put at 29%
abstract: LEAD: Florida's orange harvest will plunge by some 29 percent this year because of damage from the Christmas weekend freeze, the Department of Agriculture estimated today.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Yugoslavs to Study Kosovo Police Controls
abstract: LEAD: A commission has been established to investigate complaints against security forces that put down the violent ethnic unrest in Kosovo province, the police chief said today.

headline: Unfair Swipe at Anti-Dumping
abstract: LEAD: To the Editor:

headline: French Agree to Buy Rorer for $3.14 Billion
abstract: LEAD: The Rorer Group Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a preliminary agreement with Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the chemical company owned by the French Government, to merge with Rhone-Poulenc's pharmaceutical operations. Rorer said the deal valued its stock at $73 a share, or $3.14 billion.

headline: In a War Over Taxis, 27 Die In a South African Township
abstract: LEAD: A war between rival taxi companies has turned this quiet black township a dozen miles southeast of Johannesburg into a battleground.

headline: Century 21 Is Putting Its Account in Review
abstract: LEAD: The Century 21 Real Estate Corporation said yesterday that it was putting its approximately $20 million advertising account up for review. The company said the competition would include the incumbent agency, McCann-Erickson in Los Angeles. It did not say who else would compete. McCann-Erickson won the account from Wells, Rich,

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD: The Economy

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Havel Traces Passage 'From Jail to the Castle'
abstract: LEAD: President Vaclav Havel's third-floor office in the Prague Castle these days has the urgent chaos of a theater stage the day after opening night. Mail is piled on the floor. Young secretaries and assistants rush in and out. Unwanted paintings stand around against the wall like discarded scenery. Telephones ring and ring and often go unanswered.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
abstract: LEAD: * Lois Geller has been named president of AC&R Direct, a division of AC&R Advertising.

headline: A New Bullock's
abstract: LEAD: R. H. Macy & Company said it would open a 240,000-square-foot Bullock's department store in the Regional Shopping Center complex in Burbank, Calif. The new Bullock's, the first in Burbank, will open in the fall of 1992. Macy's said that the new store was part of a commitment to expand the Bullock's chain in Southern California and that it was among seven new stores Macy's plans to open in the next four years.

headline: OPPOSITION GAINING A BIT IN NICARAGUA
abstract: LEAD: In the heated election battle between the Government and its opponents, it is perhaps no surprise that an opposition rally on Sunday ended in a shoving match. What was notable was that the fight involved only one side: bickering leaders of the main anti-Government coalition.

headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Bulgaria;   Baker Asks Bulgaria for Fair Election
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of Bulgarians, chanting ''No money for Commies'' and ''Democracy U.S.A.'' in English, greeted Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on his arrival today. He stopped for 12 hours to press the new Government to conduct free and fair elections.

headline: ISRAEL TO CENSOR NEWS ON EMIGRES
abstract: LEAD: The Israeli military authorities issued a highly unusual order today requiring news organizations to submit all reports on Soviet Jewish immigration to military censors.

headline: New President of Macy Unit
abstract: LEAD: Mark S. Sellers, the executive vice president and chief financial officer of the Marshalls Inc. unit of the Melville Corporation, has been named president and chief operating officer of the Macy's South/Bullocks division of R. H. Macy & Company in Atlanta.

headline: At Least 37 Die in Central Asia Rioting
abstract: LEAD: Defying an emergency decree and a ban on demonstrations, thousands of people rallied Tuesday in the capital of Soviet Tadzhikistan, Soviet television reported early today, saying that as many as 37 people had died since rioting began there late Sunday night.

headline: North Korea Agrees to a Joint Tunnel Inquiry
abstract: LEAD: A North Korean military delegation surprised its American and South Korean counterparts today by agreeing in principle to jointly investigate a tunnel dug underneath the heavily militarized border.

headline: Noriega's Surrender;   Guerrillas in Colombia Kill 6 Policemen and 3 Civilians
abstract: LEAD: In their first major attacks of the year, leftist guerrillas ambushed and killed six policemen on patrol and burned a city bus, killing three passengers and wounding 20, the police said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    INTERNATIONAL       Seeking to bolster East Germany's collapsing economy, Helmut Kohl of West Germany called for talks on creating a single German currency. [Page A1.]  The crucial question is at what rate the East German mark could be exchanged. [A15.]      Moody's Investors Service lowered debt ratings of three large Japanese banks because of their real estate problems.

headline: Upheaval in the East: The Pentagon;   Discount Soviet Peril to Iran, Cheney Tells His Strategists
abstract: LEAD: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has issued a new guide for military planning that instructs the services to drop the mission of defending Iran in the event of a Soviet attack and calls on the United States' Asian allies to take on more of the burden for their own defense, Pentagon officals said today.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    The       Markets

headline: Andersen Breaks the Auditing Mold
abstract: LEAD: From the outside, the Microseal Corporation looks like any other small factory on the fringe of Chicago. But inside, there is an experiment under way that could well change the nature of the accounting profession.

headline: Volkswagen Campaign
abstract: LEAD: Rolling Stone magazine has lent its ''Perception/Reality'' advertising campaign to Volkswagen. In this execution, which appears in the March 8 issue of Rolling Stone, perception is the humble Beetle, and reality is Volkswagen's current line. The One Club recently named the campaign, which was devised by Fallon McElligott, as the third-best campaign of the 1980's.

headline: Business and Health;   Insurers Testing Basic Coverage
abstract: LEAD: WITHOUT waiting for Congress, which seems reluctant to act on important health insurance issues in an election year, insurers in a number of states are testing new types of coverage for at least some of the 31 million Americans who lack health insurance.

headline: OPEC's Output at 1989 High
abstract: LEAD: Oil output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reached a 1989 high of 23.6 million barrels a day throughout December and will probably remain strong in early 1990 despite a new production-cutting accord, oil industry, government and shipping sources said last week.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;  People
abstract: LEAD: * Frank Blaney, Kevin Brown, Thomas Deska, Mark Liska, Thomas Luke and Henry Smith have been named senior vice presidents at Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising.

headline: Boeing Plans Worker Cuts At Factories
abstract: LEAD: Despite an $80 billion backlog of orders for commercial airliners, the Boeing Company said yesterday that its factory work force had grown too large and would be reduced this year by 5,000 workers.

headline: The Party Is Haunted By a Trail of Scandals
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party's latest round of humiliation began on New Year's Eve, when a drunken chauffeur in the Ukrainian city of Chernigov swerved his Government car into a lamppost.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Baker Offers Prague Economic Aid
abstract: LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today offered Czechoslovakia a package of economic assistance similar to that provided by Washington to Poland and Hungary to help the new leaders in Prague consolidate their revolution and establish a free-market democracy.

headline: Leftist Candidate Assassinated at Bogota Airport
abstract: LEAD: A leading left-wing politician was assassinated at the Bogota airport today, and troops used tear gas and gunfire to disperse hundreds of demonstrators accusing the Government of complicity in the killing.

headline: South African Exiles Fear to Return
abstract: LEAD: While many South African exiles concede the importance of the changes in their country in recent weeks, few of them are prepared to test the extent and permanence of the new climate by returning home.

headline: Wall Street;   End of the 'Event-Risk' Nightmare?
abstract: LEAD: Top-quality corporate bonds were among the first casualties of the takeover craze that defined the Drexel era on Wall Street. With each new debt-laden deal, another set of corporate investors awoke to find that their bonds, blue-chip assets the night before, were suddenly on their way to the junk heap.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Showcase for Bucharest's Dissenters
abstract: LEAD: From poet to peasant, Rumanians who want to vent disappointment with the way things are going these days are turning increasingly to Romania Libera, the only major newspaper to take an adversarial role against the ruling Council of National Salvation.

headline: Your Own Account;  The Lure of the Lump Sum
abstract: LEAD: The man is 62 years old, earning about $100,000 a year and thinking of retirement. But when he starts doing his pension numbers, he hits an increasingly common dilemma. Should he take the money in a lump sum - in this hypothetical case, $380,000 - and invest it himself? Or should be accept his company's guarantee of $40,000 a year for the rest of his life?

headline: McCaw-Lin Link
abstract: LEAD: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said it had won bank financing for its $3.4 billion merger with the Lin Broadcasting Corporation, bringing it a step closer to creating the nation's biggest cellular telephone company. The $3 billion bank loan agreement was arranged by a syndicate of 43 commercial banks.

headline: Resignation Is Expected At Apple
abstract: LEAD: In a continuation of the management shake-up at Apple Computer Inc., Jean-Louis Gassee, the company's chief of product development, is expected to resign, computer industry officials said today.

headline: MTV Rolling Out Comedy Network
abstract: LEAD: MTV Networks jumps into the race to establish an all-comedy cable channel on Sunday with the introduction of HA! the TV Comedy Network.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   A Casualty of Amnesty: A Plant Using Convicts
abstract: LEAD: When President Vaclav Havel declared an amnesty for 20,000 prisoners on New Year's Day, he obviously was not thinking about what the effect would be on the country's biggest automobile factory.
