headline: Mr. Donut Ruling
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge has lifted a restraining order that blocked the sale of the Mr. Donut chain to its biggest competitor, Dunkin' Donuts. United States District Judge Franklin S. Van Antwerpen ruled on Wednesday that Mr. Donut franchise owners could pursue their lawsuit to block the sale on antitrust allegations, but he said the franchise owners had failed to prove they would suffer irreparable harm while they pursued their lawsuit.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   Warsaw Wins Showdown With Miners, but Signs of Unrest Remain
abstract: LEAD: The Government won its first major showdown over its crash economic plan today when coal miners agreed to return to work at four of the five mines that have been shut down over demands for higher pay.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Fondness for Germany Endures in Polish Silesia
abstract: LEAD: For Silesians like Henryk Kroll, memories of the time Germany owned this corner of what is now Poland, which ended with the Nazi defeat in 1945, can be summed up succinctly:

headline: Famine Threatens as Fighting Flares in the Sudan
abstract: LEAD: The civil war in the Sudan has flared anew in the last six weeks, and Western aid officials say the fighting and Government obstruction of relief efforts make another large-scale famine appear likely.

headline: Treasury Prices Rise on Rumors
abstract: LEAD: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved higher again yesterday, as traders were buffeted by rumors throughout the session.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Yugoslav Communists Vote To End Party's Monopoly
abstract: LEAD: The Yugoslav Communist Party voted today to give up its 45-year monopoly on power and to permit a new political system in which other parties may compete.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Atlantic Supplement
abstract: LEAD: The Atlantic magazine, combining a desire to report the rise in corporate philanthropy over the last decade and to increase advertising revenues, will publish an annual supplement called ''Private Profit Public Gain,'' which will be distributed with its September issue. The Atlantic said it would donate a tenth of the supplement's net revenues to charity.

headline: A Darwinian Creation of Software
abstract: LEAD: A fledgling science that creates software whose behavior mimics that of living creatures is beginning to provide scientists with a new class of software tools with significant commercial potential.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Okidata, a marketer of computer peripherals, to Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, with a budget of $5 million.

headline: To the Brink and Back in Real Estate
abstract: LEAD: Back in the late 1960's, most people saw nothing more than cattle and horses rambling over the rolling prairie northwest of Dallas. Ben Carpenter saw the community of the future. So, in 1969, he set about building it.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Bonn's Politicians Invade East Germany
abstract: LEAD: The question here is no longer which power the Communists will surrender next or which hurdle the opposition might clear. The question is which West German party will win the East German election next month.

headline: Asahi Breweries Plans U.S. Plant
abstract: LEAD: Asahi Breweries Ltd., the third-largest beer producer in Japan, said it plans to build a plant in the United States and produce its Super Dry beer, one of the company's largest exports. Asahi is planning to invest about 10 billion yen, or about $70 million at today's exchange rate, to build a plant near Denver in

headline: Ortega Says He Won't Arm Rebels In El Salvador if He Is Re-elected
abstract: LEAD: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that if he was re-elected, his Government would not provide leftist guerrillas in El Salvador with arms to fight a Salvadoran Government that he called ''legitimate.''

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Agency Acquires Big Software Account
abstract: LEAD: Schell/Mullaney Advertising, a tiny new agency founded in part by alumni of the J. Walter Thompson Company, has lured the account of the big computer software company Computer Associates International away from Thompson.

headline: Disney Outlines Plans for Florida
abstract: LEAD: The Walt Disney Company's chief executive, Michael Eisner, announced plans to expand Disney's three Florida theme parks and said a fourth would be added during the 1990's. Mr. Eisner declined to provide details about the new park.

headline: Disney Bans Commercials At Showings of Its Films
abstract: LEAD: The Walt Disney Company is giving theatergoers a bonus - no commercials with its movies. That may please some moviegoers, but cinema advertising executives and theater owners are unhappy.

headline: Foxmoor Files For Protection
abstract: LEAD: Dylex Ltd. said today that its subsidiary the Foxmoor Speciality Stores Corporation had filed in New York for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

headline: Company News;   First Pacific Pact
abstract: LEAD: First Pacific Networks, a private company based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it had received a contract worth $150 million over five years to supply telecommunications equipment for Costa Rica's telephone system. First Pacific's equipment allows telephone conversations and computer data, as well as television signals, to be transmitted over a cable television system or optical fiber.

headline: Marijuana Dealer Doomed
abstract: LEAD: A Malaysian court today sentenced a man to hang for trafficking in marijuana but acquitted his wife, saying that she did not know about the 21 ounces of marijuana that the authorities found in their home. The condemned man, Abdullah Zawawi Yusoff, 41 years old, became the 248th person sentenced to death for drug trafficking since 1975.

headline: Patents;   A Nicotine Drug Patch to End Smoking
abstract: LEAD: Transdermal drug patches, which dispense medication into the blood stream through the skin, may have a new use: helping cigarette smokers to quit.

headline: Bonwit Stores To Be Sold
abstract: LEAD: The L. J. Hooker Corporation announced yesterday that it would sell 5 of the 16 Bonwit Teller stores, including the flagship store in Trump Tower in Manhattan, to the Pyramid Companies, a real estate development and investment company based in Syracuse, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: P.L.O. Says a New State Could Link With Jordan
abstract: LEAD: The No. 2 official in the Palestine Liberation Organization says in an article to be published on Sunday that Palestinians welcome the idea of a confederation with Jordan but only after the establishment of an independent Palestinian homeland.

headline: Italy's Communists Agree to a Metamorphosis
abstract: LEAD: Ending four days of soul-searching, Italy's troubled Communist Party, the largest in the West, agreed at a meeting here today to transform itself into a new political grouping known for now only as The Thing.

headline: Fed Expects Slow Growth This Year
abstract: LEAD: The nation's economy is expected to grow slowly in 1990, with improvements in some regions later in the year, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Advanced Telecommunications Corp., Atlanta, which provides long-distance telephone services, said Metromedia Co., Secaucus, N.J., would buy more than 1.9 million common shares for $13 each, or $25.4 million.

headline: Forging a Global Empire in a Sluggish Market
abstract: LEAD: These are not the easiest of days for the Marriott Corporation, the largest hotel company in the world. The company's chairman, J. W. Marriott Jr., is recuperating from open-heart surgery. The Marriott hotel in Panama endured a harrowing seige during the United States invasion last month. Business at some of the company's lodging properties has been so sluggish that the company last month announced a $150 million write-down.

headline: Azerbaijan and the Kremlin
abstract: LEAD: Circumstantial evidence suggests that the explosion of ethnic violence in Azerbaijan was not as spontaneous as it seemed. Page A8.

headline: Beijing to Limit More Posts In Hong Kong to the Chinese
abstract: LEAD: China, which has said it will bar holders of foreign passports from top government jobs in Hong Kong after Beijing resumes sovereignty in 1997, will extend the ban to more posts, a Chinese official said today.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Soviets Said to Seal Uzbek City After Clashes
abstract: LEAD: Security forces reportedly sealed off a city near Tashkent, the Uzbek capital, today after clashes with demonstrators. Officials said at least one soldier had been killed, but a protester reported many dead.

headline: Israelis Speculate on Attack's Plotters
abstract: LEAD: Israeli military officials speculated this evening that the attackers of an Israeli tourist bus near Cairo were members of a guerrilla organization that sent assassins across the Egyptian border into Israel in December.

headline: Control Data Reports Losses
abstract: LEAD: The Control Data Corporation today reported a 1989 loss of $680.4 million on revenues of $2.9 billion. The results, which were in line with expectations, included a fourth-quarter loss of $196.4 million on revenues of $524 million.

headline: A New Upjohn Strategy To Compete Globally
abstract: LEAD: In a move intended to bring products to market faster, the Upjohn Company is forming a unit, Upjohn Laboratories, that will integrate research and medical-affairs divisions into a single global operation. Dr. Jerry R. Mitchell will be its president.

headline: Cable Broker Selling Stake
abstract: LEAD: The cable television entrepreneur Bill Daniels plans to sell 49 percent of his cable brokerage firm, Daniels & Associates, to nine of the company's executives. Mr. Daniels, who is 69 years old, will keep 51 percent, the company's senior vice president of marketing, Bob Russo, said on Tuesday.

headline: Channel 5 Phone Ads
abstract: LEAD: WNYW, Channel 5 in New York, said yesterday that it would restrict commercials for 900-number telephone services, which offer callers either recorded messages or live conversation. The station said it will run the commercials only between midnight and 6 A.M. and will not run any spots with sexual themes.

headline: All About/Machine Tools;   Fissures in the Industrial Bedrock
abstract: LEAD: Machine tool makers are part of the nation's industrial bedrock. Manufacturers rely on them for equipment to forge, cut, grind, drill, bend, trim and stamp the blocks and sheets of metal that become cars, airplanes and appliances.

headline: Ethnic Albanian Protesters Battle With Yugoslav Police
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of ethnic Albanians fought with the police today in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo in demonstrations demanding that the Communist authorities lift a state of emergency and allow free elections. A man was reported killed and four injured.

headline: Massachusetts Drexel Accord
abstract: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. agreed to pay Massachusetts $1 million in a settlement announced today, the latest settlement arising from the Wall Street firm's guilty plea to securities fraud charges.

headline: Korea, U.S. In Beef Pact
abstract: LEAD: South Korea has resolved a dispute with the United States over beef imports, averting possible trade sanctions, trade ministry officials said today.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Webster and Cheney at Odds Over Soviet Military Threat
abstract: LEAD: The Director of Central Intelligence and the Secretary of Defense are at odds over whether the Soviet Union will continue to pose a serious military threat to the United States and the West.

headline: Soviets Pull Out Advisers at Ethiopia Fronts
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union has withdrawn all its military advisers from the battle zones in Ethiopia's civil wars, the Soviet Ambassador to the Sudan said today.

headline: The U.N. Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       MEETING OF PARTIES TO THE CONVENTION ON THE ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.       COMMISSION ON TRADE LAW: WORKING GROUP ON THE NEW INTERNATIONAL ECONOMIC ORDER - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.       Economic and Social Council       ECONOMIC AND SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

headline: People
abstract: LEAD: * Ralph McGill has joined the McDonald Group, Atlanta, as senior vice president and a creative partner.

headline: All the Names Will Be New on the Nigerian Ballot
abstract: LEAD: Two years from now, if all goes as scheduled, Nigeria will have a new national legislature, 21 new state governors and a new democratically elected President. What it does not have now are candidates for any of those jobs.

headline: When the Furnace Tilts and Ponds Disappear
abstract: LEAD: Longwall mining looks worse from the surface.

headline: 20 Quit at The Jerusalem Post
abstract: LEAD: The new publisher of The Jerusalem Post accepted the resignations today of 20 senior editors and longtime reporters who objected to what they called the publisher's moves to turn the liberal daily into a platform for right-wing views.

headline: 69 Hurt as Protesters Clash With Police at Ball in Vienna
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of demonstrators clashed with the police outside the Vienna State Opera on Thursday night as socialites waltzed inside, and the authorities said today that at least 69 people were wounded.

headline: First Chicago Profit Outlook
abstract: LEAD: The First Chicago Corporation, parent of the First National Bank of Chicago, said today that troubled real estate loans will cause a drop of about 50 percent in first-quarter earnings compared with the 1989 period. In last year's first quarter, First Chicago earned $120 million, or $1.72 a share.

headline: U.N. Drug Plan Puts Stress on Reducing Demand
abstract: LEAD: he United Nations today approved a new anti-narcotics plan that stresses the need to reduce demand in the industrialized consuming countries and to compensate poor drug-producing countries for losses suffered by curbing the trade.

headline: Hicks, Muse Buys 7 Insurers
abstract: LEAD: Hicks, Muse & Company, a private investment group specializing in leveraged acquisitions, said today that it had completed the previously announced acquisition of seven insurance companies from the I.C.H. Corporation for $530 million.

headline: Lukewarm Ending for Auctions
abstract: LEAD: Investors gave the final portion of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions a tepid welcome yesterday, but even that was enough to push prices of notes and bonds higher.

headline: Radio Deal in Honolulu
abstract: LEAD: The Bedford Broadcasting Company announced Friday that it had agreed to buy the Honolulu radio stations KSSK-AM and KSSK-FM from the Heftel Broadcasting Company of Hawaii. Terms of the sale, which must be approved by the Federal Communications Commission, were not disclosed. Bedford also owns four newspapers in Southern California and a company in San Francisco that publishes books on the arts.

headline: CORRECTION
abstract: LEAD: The ''All About'' column on Feb. 25, discussing modems, misidentified a company listed among those dominant in that market. It is Multi-Tech Systems Inc. of Mounds View, Minn., not the Acer America Corporation. The article also referred incorrectly to the Telebit Corporation. It was one of the first makers of cellular telephone modems, not the first.

headline: Kashmir Dispute Is Souring India-Pakistan Ties
abstract: LEAD: Tensions over the disputed state of Jammu and Kashmir have brought relations between India and Pakistan to their worst since 1971, when the two nations last fought a war.

headline: TURKEY SENSITIVE ABOUT ITS IDENTITY
abstract: LEAD: Enveloped in smog and, for Turks, in familiarity, too, the slogan that spreads across the highway here on a kind of ceremonial arch proclaims: ''What joy to say I am a Turk.''

headline: BankAmerica Names Successor to Clausen
abstract: LEAD: Richard M. Rosenberg, whose aggressive marketing tactics fueled the BankAmerica Corporation's resurgence in California banking, yesterday was named the next chairman and chief executive of the nation's third-largest banking company.

headline: Japonica's Plan To Buy Allegheny
abstract: LEAD: Japonica Partners, a New York investment firm, filed a proposal in Federal Bankruptcy Court under which it would buy Allegheny International Inc. for $650 million. Japonica said its plan provided ''substantially greater value'' than a competing plan filed by the company, which Japonica has valued at $570 million.

headline: American Visas for Scientists From the East Are Said to Be Lagging
abstract: LEAD: Despite the crumbling of cold war barriers, the granting of American visas to Soviet and East European scientists remains mired in red tape, depriving the nation of sorely needed talent, American scientists contend.

headline: Trade Gap Widened in November
abstract: LEAD: The nation's trade deficit grew in November to $10.5 billion, the biggest monthly gap of 1989, the Commerce Department reported today.

headline: All About/Computers Talking to Computers;   Fast Modems: All Dressed Up, With Only a Slow Way to Go
abstract: LEAD: Ever since personal computers became common in the late 1970's, users have wanted their computers to communicate. Modems answered their needs by allowing computers to exchange data over the telephone. During the 1980's, modems opened up a world of information, including electronic mail, computer data bases and services ranging from airline reservations to stock trading.

headline: U.S. Gives Details of Charges In Nuclear-Arms Parts Case
abstract: LEAD: Five people and two companies have been charged with conspiring to smuggle electronic devices used to detonate nuclear bombs to Iraq, according to an indictment by a Federal grand jury in San Diego that was unsealed today.

headline: The Noriega Case: Panama City;   Papal Envoy Asserts Psychology, Not Ultimatum, Swayed Noriega
abstract: LEAD: The papal envoy to Panama, the pivotal figure in 10 days of tense negotiations that ended in Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's surrender, insisted today that the general's departure from the Vatican mission resulted not from an ultimatum but from a precisely calibrated psychological campaign.

headline: New York Life Names Successors to Leader
abstract: LEAD: The New York Life Insurance Company, one of the nation's largest life insurers, yesterday named a new management lineup to take charge on Aug. 1.

headline: Market Place;   Hopes Run High For South Africa
abstract: LEAD: INTERNATIONAL investors poured cash into South African stocks yesterday, continuing the trend of assuming that signs of political change in the world will work out for the best.

headline: Chip Report Shows Gain
abstract: LEAD: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator continued to rebound in February as United States semiconductor orders declined slightly but shipments increased, a trade group reported today.

headline: Real Estate;   Construction Without Loan Or Tenants
abstract: LEAD: AS a cadre of dignitaries looked on, ground was broken on Monday for a new 28-story office tower in Fort Lee, N.J.

headline: Sandinistas Warn They Want Control of Military
abstract: LEAD: After a wave of conciliatory gestures following their election defeat last week, Sandinista leaders have begun to issue defiant warnings that the government-elect must not tamper with Sandinista control of the military or the Ministry of the Interior, which controls the secret police.

headline: Sallie Mae Prices $200 Million Issue
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced $200 million in notes due in 1995 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

headline: The U.N Today
abstract: LEAD:    General Assembly       COMMITTEE ON THE ELIMINATION OF DISCRIMINATION AGAINST WOMEN - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.       Economic and Social Council       INTERGOVERNMENTAL OCEANOGRAPHIC COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

headline: For Citibank Official, An End and a Beginning
abstract: LEAD: For William R. Rhodes of Citibank, yesterday was an end and a beginning. At the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan yesterday, he joined officials from Mexico to sign an agreement to lower Mexico's $48.5 billion in debt with the more than 460 banks involved, winding up almost a year of tough negotiations that he led as co-chairman of the commerical bank advisory committee.

headline: Talks End, Wait Begins
abstract: LEAD: In an era in which the cold war is ending, the Germanys are moving toward reunification and the South African Government has legalized the major black opposition, is it possible to resolve trade disputes with Japan?

headline: New Retrieval Software By On Technology Inc.
abstract: LEAD: Three years after resigning as chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, Mitchell D. Kapor is to introduce today the first software product developed by his new company, On Technology Inc.

headline: Israel Hopes to Join Bank
abstract: LEAD: Israel will apply to join the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the proposed bank to help Eastern Europe, Bank of Israel sources said Sunday. France is the driving force in the plan to establish the new bank, which will serve the private sector in Eastern Europe. The 12 European Community countries, 14 other developed nations and 8 East European states are involved.

headline: Sallie Mae Prices $400 Million Notes
abstract: LEAD: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced a $400 million issue of notes due in 1993 through Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: Azerbaijani Strife Expected to Lift Oil Prices Throughout the World
abstract: LEAD: Western experts say the ethnic strife in Azerbaijan has begun to disrupt production of oil in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer by far and a large exporter. The resulting drop, which comes on top of a decline that began in mid-1987, is expected to contribute to tighter supplies and higher prices for oil around the world at a time when production is also falling in other regions.

headline: Soviets and Hungary Agree on Troop Pullout
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union and Hungary signed an agreement today calling for all Soviet troops to be withdrawn from Hungarian territory by the middle of next year, Hungarian radio reported.

headline: Drexel Creditors Prepare Legal Strategies
abstract: LEAD: Creditors of the Drexel Burnham Lambert Group held a final conference yesterday about legal strategies as they prepared for the first volley of litigation stemming from its bankruptcy filing nearly two weeks ago.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Albania Opens Phone Links With Some Western Nations
abstract: LEAD: Albania has opened direct telephone service with the West, lifting some of the restrictions that have made it one of the world's most isolated countries.

headline: Israeli Who Met Arafat Is Freed;He Vows to Press His Peace Effort
abstract: LEAD: Unrepentant, the Israeli peace campaigner Abie Nathan was released from prison today. He vowed to continue the activities for which he was jailed four months ago.

headline: Investor Suggests Lockheed Concentrate on the Military
abstract: LEAD: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor who is seeking control of the Lockheed Corporation, outlined his strategy for the company today, saying Lockheed needs to refocus on its core military and space businesses.

headline: Currency;   Taking Mr. Greenspan in Stride
abstract: LEAD: The yen lost its punch this week, falling back to its level of 145 against the dollar. As for the West German mark, it continued strong, but the dollar only moved down a little against it. Suggestions from Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, that there was less chance of a recession seemed to have little impact.

headline: Commercials Become News, And the Air Time Is Free
abstract: LEAD: Advertisers are increasingly using their commercials not for the tried-and-true purposes of showcasing products or appealing to consumers' emotions, but to generate controversy that they hope will translate into free air time and press clippings.

headline: Noriega's Surrender: Change of Command;   PANAMANIAN QUITS AFTER TWO WEEKS
abstract: LEAD: The newly appointed commander of Panama's security force resigned today, less than two weeks after the country's new civilian Government appointed him to head the remnants of the Panamanian Defense Forces.

headline: Foreign Investing in U.S. Helps, Greenspan Says
abstract: LEAD: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that foreign investment in the United States spurred competition and new technology. He characterized as overblown concerns about a surge of foreign money invested in the United States.

headline: Long Swiss Exile for a Wartime King of Rumania
abstract: LEAD: King Michael of Rumania, who has been living in exile for 42 years, wants his throne back.

headline: Perrier Widens Recall After New Finding
abstract: LEAD: Source Perrier announced today that it was withdrawing every bottle of its sparkling mineral water throughout the world after traces of benzene, a toxic chemical, were reported in bottles tested in Denmark and the Netherlands.

headline: Yields Post Slight Rise
abstract: LEAD: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were slightly higher for the week that ended yesterday.

headline: TRW, Motorola Develop New Chip
abstract: LEAD: TRW Inc., of Cleveland, and Motorola Inc., of Schaumburg, Ill., have built a microprocessor chip with four million transistors as part of a Defense Department program to create very-high-speed semiconductors. It is intended for high-speed mathematical applications and can also repair itself.

headline: Accounts
abstract: LEAD: * Twin Med Inc., Santa Monica, Calif., to Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley, San Francisco, for its Epi Products subsidiary's home health-care products with billings of $2 million. The agency also won the account of New Zealand Fruit Co., Seattle, whose billings previously were $600,000.

headline: Study Says Ford Leads In Efficiency
abstract: LEAD: A study of North American auto plants has concluded that the Ford Motor Company has better manufacturing efficiency than its Big Three rivals, giving it the best competitive position for the 1990's.

headline: Havel Says His Predecessors Sent Libya Explosives
abstract: LEAD: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia said today that the ousted Communist Government in Prague had shipped 1,000 tons of lethal Semtex explosives to Libya, which had passed it on to terrorist organizations.

headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: East Germany;   Berlin Hospital Weathers a Drain of Doctors
abstract: LEAD: Friedrichshain Municipal Hospital, a 1,280-bed institution not far from the center of the capital, suffered like the rest of the East German health system from the loss of qualified people when the mass exodus from this country began last summer.

headline: LEBANON GENERAL MAY OPEN ATTACK
abstract: LEAD: With his ammunition dumps resupplied, Gen. Michel Aoun, commander of the Christian part of the Lebanese Army, is ready to open a new offensive to suppress his militia rivals in the Christian enclave north of here, Lebanese military officials said today.

headline: Oilfield Opens in Iraq
abstract: LEAD: Iraq's Oil Ministry has begun production at its southern Suba oilfield with an initial output of 20,000 barrels a day, the official Iraqi News Agency said today. Developing the Suba oilfield is part of a significant expansion program begun last year to develop Iraq's oil and gas reserves after the August 1988 cease-fire in the eight-year war with Iran.

headline: Ex-Exile Emerges at Core of Chamorro Alliance
abstract: LEAD: When the Nicaraguan opposition held an enormous rally here before the election on Sunday, huge vertical banners waved with the names of the presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, and her running mate. But a smaller set of signs advertised a third name: Alfredo Cesar Aguirre, the opposition's man behind the throne.

headline: BUSINESS PEOPLE;  Time Warner Lawyer Is Nominated to S.E.C.
abstract: LEAD: President Bush yesterday nominated Philip R. Lochner Jr., Time Warner Inc.'s deputy general counsel, to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Tass Reports Arrests of 31 At Moscow Demonstration
abstract: LEAD: The police arrested 31 people today at an unauthorized demonstration in which protesters shouted anti-Communist slogans, the official news agency Tass reported.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Spain;   Challenge to Madrid's Success Story
abstract: LEAD: Having flourished as Western Europe's economic success story of the late 1980's, Spain is now worried that it may lose out as wealthier members of the European Community turn their attention to Eastern Europe.

headline: Skepticism in the Street And No Excited Crowd
abstract: LEAD: On the day the Communist Party's leaders voted with near unanimity to forswear the political monopoly their party has held for more than 70 years, Red Square was void of anxious, interested citizens waiting for a sign of democracy to rise from behind the towering brick walls of the Kremlin.

headline: Stocks Drop on Rate Fears; Dow Off 38.74
abstract: LEAD: Stocks fell across a broad front yesterday as traders worried about rising interest rates here, as well as in West Germany and Japan.

headline: Baker Hughes Profit Up
abstract: LEAD: Baker Hughes Inc., an oil tool maker, posted a 45.9 percent gain in quarterly profits, despite a worldwide decrease in drilling activity, the company announced today. Earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31, the company's first quarter, were $25.4 million, or 20 cents a share, on revenue of $578.9 million, compared with earnings of $17.4 million, or 13 cents a share, on revenue of $566.3 million a year earlier.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Agency Review At Parker Bros.
abstract: LEAD: Parker Brothers, the division of the Tonka Corporation that makes such board games as Monopoly, Sorry and Clue, said yesterday that it had put its $20 million advertising account up for review.      The account had been at

headline: India Paves Way for Kashmir Elections
abstract: LEAD: The Governor of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, which is troubled by anti-India agitation, dissolved the state legislature today, paving the way for possible elections this year.

headline: Want a Seat? They're Going For a Song
abstract: LEAD: Anybody want to buy a house? Or a seat? With share prices weakening last week as interest rates rose and housing starts hit a six-year low, the most depressing news at the New York Stock Exchange may have been the year's first sale of a seat in that august body. The price: $390,000, the lowest tab since 1985.

headline: Savings Agency Ordered to Sell Real Estate Fast
abstract: LEAD: The new agency created to manage the huge savings and loan bailout was instructed today to sell the real estate it inherited from hundreds of insolvent institutions as quickly as possible. The directive from the Bush Administration raised concerns among bankers that the properties could be ''dumped'' in an already weakened real estate market.

headline: Patents;   States Held Immune on Infringement
abstract: LEAD: In a decision viewed by some experts as a blow to inventors, the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington has ruled that state governments are immune from charges of patent infringement.

headline: Chinese Press Is Silent on Gorbachev Plans to End Party Monopoly
abstract: LEAD: Chinese readers discovered today that a Soviet organization had awarded a medal to a famous Chinese writer for fostering cultural relations, but they did not learn a word about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plan to abolish the Communist Party's monopoly on power in the Soviet Union.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.50   1050   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   6.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.50   8.00   9.40        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.64   7.59   8.13        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.52   7.60   8.28        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   7.96   7.96   9.28        30-YR.

headline: Generic Drugs Recalled After Questions on Data
abstract: LEAD: The Bolar Pharmaceutical Company, a generic drug maker, announced today that it was recalling its version of a drug widely used to treat high blood pressure. The company had been resisting the action for months.

headline: Avondale Layoffs
abstract: LEAD: Avondale Industries, a Louisiana shipbuilder, laid off about 300 workers, and a company spokesman said another 615 workers might be released to cut costs. The company, one of the nation's most active shipbuilders, has about 8,500 employees. It has a $2 billion backlog of work, but much of it will not begin before later this year, the spokesman said.

headline: Committee Criticizes Eastern Air
abstract: LEAD: The committee representing the preferred stockholders at Eastern Air Lines said yesterday that it had lost faith in the airline's management and called for dramatic steps to salvage any value that was left in the airline.

headline: Ortega Spurned in an Old Stronghold
abstract: LEAD: For the last decade, this town has been known throughout Nicaragua as ''the cradle of the insurrection,'' in honor of the singular role that it played in helping the Sandinista Front overthrow Anastasio Somoza Debayle. But when Masaya residents voted last Sunday, they cast aside their reputation as Sandinista loyalists and voted for Violeta Barrios de

headline: Paramount Quits Agency
abstract: LEAD: The Paramount Pictures Corporation has withdrawn its $60 million advertising account from D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, the agency said yesterday.

headline: Rohr Gets Jet Job
abstract: LEAD: Rohr Industries received a contract valued at about $1 billion from International Aero Engines to design and manufacture the nacelles - the aerodynamic structures that surround jet engines - for International Aero's V2500 engine for the MD-90 airliner built by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation. McDonnell Douglas has orders for 95 of the MD-90 jets and has received options for another 155.

headline: Business and Health;   Cutting the Cost Of Medicaid Drugs
abstract: LEAD: THE pharmaceutical industry is fighting growing pressure to reduce the prices of prescription drugs used by low-income Americans in the financially pressed Federal-state Medicaid programs. Medicaid officials said spending on prescription drugs rose last year by 12 percent, to $3.87 billion, from $3.45 billion in 1988.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Japanese Aid;  $1 Billion Plan for Poland and Hungary
abstract: LEAD: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan announced a $1 billion economic aid package for Poland and Hungary today, and said Japan should play a political as well as economic role in Eastern Europe.

headline: Turner in a Four-Year Deal To Televise N.F.L. Games
abstract: LEAD: In a deal believed to significantly raise the stakes in the bidding war for National Football League games, Turner Broadcasting System Inc. last night announced an agreement to televise 47 prime-time games over four years, beginning next season.

headline: Economic Scene;   The Americans Are Coming
abstract: LEAD: TO Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the case for discouraging European imports of American television programming is self-evident. ''Have we the right to exist, to perpetuate our traditions?'' he asked broadcasters meeting in Paris in October. They approved guidelines for 1992 limiting

headline: Blue Chips Lead Rebound; Dow Up 23.25
abstract: LEAD: Blue-chip stocks rose strongly yesterday on sharply higher volume, as the stock market bounced back from two losing sessions.

headline: Indian Leaders Visit Kashmir In Hope of Defusing Tension
abstract: LEAD: Prominent Indian political leaders, including Deputy Prime Minister Devi Lal and former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi, traveled today to Srinagar, the capital of Jammu and Kashmir state, to begin a political drive aimed at defusing an anti-Indian mood there.

headline: Consumer Debt Rises At 7.2% Rate
abstract: LEAD: Americans took out $4.24 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in November, the largest increase in outstanding debt in nine months, the Federal Reserve reported today.

headline: Hoare Govett Plan
abstract: LEAD: The securities house Hoare Govett Ltd. plans to offer its employees a 51 percent stake in the company when its owner, the Security Pacific Bancorporation, cuts its holding to 49 percent starting in mid-1990, a Hoare Govett spokeswoman said.

headline: Pope Urges Just Solution To Dispute on Lithuania
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II appealed today for ''sincere dialogue'' and for a ''just and peaceful solution'' to the crisis in Lithuania.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE ECONOMY       The Bush Administration has refined its new savings plan and other programs that it hopes will address the lagging rate of savings and investment. The centerpiece is an account that it hopes will increase Americans' savings by granting tax-free interest on money left on deposit for at least seven years.

headline: MOSCOW REJECTS U.S. PLEA TO ALLOW FLIGHTS TO ISRAEL
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union, under heavy pressure from Arab countries, has rejected an appeal from the Bush Administration to allow direct flights for Soviet Jews from Moscow to Israel, Administration officials said today.

headline: Waterford Labor Protests Halted
abstract: LEAD: Waterford's 2,300 glass crystal workers have called off protest stoppages and agreed to court arbitration in a dispute over management cost-cutting proposals for the heavily indebted company. The workers, who agreed six months ago to a three-year wage freeze, called their first two-hour stoppage on

headline: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   Communist Cabinet for Bulgaria
abstract: LEAD: Bulgaria's Communist Prime Minister formed an all-Communist Cabinet today after failing to persuade his party's old allies and new opposition groups to join a broadly based government.

headline: New Brazil Chief Vows Economic Revolution
abstract: LEAD: Vowing to work a free-market revolution in Brazil, Fernando Collor de Mello was inaugurated here today, becoming the youngest President of Brazil ever and the first to be popularly elected in 29 years.

headline: Calling All Bankruptcy Lawyers . . .
abstract: LEAD: This morning at 8:30 sharp, a swarm of lawyers and journalists descended on the Federal Bankruptcy Court here to get the first public look at the mounds of documents in the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of the Campeau Corporation's American retailing operations.

headline: Du Pont to Build Complex in Spain
abstract: LEAD: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company and the Spanish Government signed an agreement to invest $1 billion in the next 12 years to build a high-technology industrial complex in the northern region of Asturias. Spain has agreed to put up $300 million for the complex, which is to employ 1,000 people in the hard-pressed region by 2001.

headline: Bad Times, Bold Plans for Brazil
abstract: LEAD: Fernando Collor de Mello, Brazil's 40-year-old President-elect, has some ambitious plans for his troubled nation.

headline: Greeks Feel the Pinch as Two U.S. Bases Close
abstract: LEAD: A popular Greek cartoon shows American G.I.'s, a look of indifference on their faces, carrying out crates of personal belongings as they abandon their military bases in Greece. Taken away with the belongings is a Greek protester clutching a ''Yankee go home'' sign, a look of bewilderment betraying his confusion at being left without a cause.

headline: Head of Retail Group Plans To Resign to Do Consulting
abstract: LEAD: After 19 years as president of the National Retail Merchants Association, the nation's largest retail trade group, James R. Williams is stepping down to form his own consulting business, to lecture and to write. Mr. Williams will remain a consultant to the association after he officially leaves the staff position on

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Upheaval in the East: Siberia;   Miner Guards Flame of a Rustic Past
abstract: LEAD: Over the hard Siberian horizon beyond the frozen river, legions of families must wait in the city 10 years or more on a Government list simply to move from their one-room apartments to a two-room existence in the soulless tenement towers of Communism.

headline: East Germans Deny a Report That Ex-Spymaster Has Fled
abstract: LEAD: East German officials today disputed a report that the country's former spymaster, Markus Wolf, fled East Germany for the Soviet Union, saying he was only on vacation and was not under investigation for illegal arms deals.

headline: Main Foes of Apartheid Appear Split
abstract: LEAD: Leading figures in South Africa's black nationalist movement began a meeting here today amid signs that they are divided over ways to respond to the increased flexibility of the Pretoria Government under President F. W. de Klerk.

headline: ALL ABOUT/DISK DRIVES
abstract: LEAD: Naming this area Silicon Valley, some say, was a mistake. It should be called Ferrite Valley, after the magnetic materials used in disk drives even before the emergence of silicon-based semiconductors. Dozens of disk-drive start-ups blossomed, much like the semiconductor companies, in the area of San Jose.

headline: Federated Considers Taking Bloomingdale's Off the Block
abstract: LEAD: For the first time since it put Bloomingdale's up for sale in September, Federated Stores Inc. said yesterday that it might not sell the 17-store chain.

headline: Limousine 'Dumping'
abstract: LEAD: The Commerce Department issued a final ruling today that imported stretch limousines from Canada were being sold at less than fair value on the American market. The ruling paved the way for possible anti-dumping duties on the cars. If the United States International Trade Commission finds that the cars have injured American producers, duties of about 5 percent would be imposed to compensate.

headline: Apple Promotes European Unit Chief in Big Realignment
abstract: LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. confirmed today that it was bringing one of its stars back from Europe to take charge of most of its somewhat listless operations in the United States.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Kohl's Foes Want NATO Recast If a Reunified Germany Is to Join
abstract: LEAD: A committee of the opposition Social Democrats led by the party's standard-bearer said today that a united Germany might remain in NATO until the establishment of a new European security order, but only if the alliance abandoned much of its current strategy.

headline: POPE URGES CHAD TO PURSUE PEACE
abstract: LEAD: Pope John Paul II preached reconciliation today in Chad, which has lived with border fighting and intermittent civil war for 25 years.

headline: Talks on a Joint Korean Team for Games Fail
abstract: LEAD: Talks between North and South Korean sports officials aimed at fielding a joint team for the 1990 Asian Games collapsed today, with South Korea reportedly fearing a trap that would prevent it from using the Beijing Games to improve relations with China.

headline: California Paroles Man Who Set Son Afire
abstract: LEAD: A former Brooklyn man who severely disfigured his 6-year-old son seven years ago when he tried to burn the boy to death as a result of a custody dispute, was freed on parole today with $200 in his pocket and an ''electronic leash'' strapped to his body.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   11.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   7.00        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.25   8.37   9.94        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.91   7.96   9.04        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.84   7.92   9.01        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.59   8.65   9.52        30-YR.

headline: Dow Slides 7.21 Points on Light Volume
abstract: LEAD: Stocks moved narrowly yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 7.21, to 2,669.59, in light volume, as traders marked time until tomorrow's key employment figures for February. The numbers are expected to show continued weakness in the economy.

headline: Palestinian Leader Is Opposing Arafat On Talks With Israel
abstract: LEAD: Coming out in open opposition to what he said was Yasir Arafat's policy of compromise, a Palestinian guerrilla leader called today for ''mobilizing all our energies'' to foil proposed Palestinian-Israeli talks under United States and Egyptian sponsorship.

headline: 150 May Be Dead in Crash Of Trains in South Pakistan
abstract: LEAD: More than 150 people were feared killed in southern Pakistan early today when a passenger train rammed into a freight train in what the railroad police said could be the worst such accident in the country.

headline: Clashes and Unrest Grow Fiercer in Ivory Coast
abstract: LEAD: Hundreds of students demanding the resignation of President Felix Houphouet-Boigny clashed with riot policemen today in the worst outbreak of violence since anti-Government demonstrations began in this West African nation two weeks ago.

headline: Northrop Reports Loss
abstract: LEAD: The Northrop Corporation said today that it had a loss of $16.6 million in the fourth quarter after setting aside $28 million to cover losses on fixed-price research and development programs. In the comparable period in 1988, the company had a loss of $86.1 million.

headline: Bond Wins a Round In Fight Over Holdings
abstract: LEAD: Alan Bond's flagship company, Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., successfully withstood an attempt today to liquidate the Australian's brewing and media holdings, but it now faces new demands from United States creditors to repay $510 million immediately.

headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: The Baltics;   Baltics Say the Kremlin Blocks Economic Shifts
abstract: LEAD: One month after a new law took effect promising economic independence to the three Baltic republics, officials in the region say they are encountering bitter resistance from Moscow as they try to introduce experiments in free-market economics.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Retirement Plan
abstract: LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would offer an enhanced early retirement program to about 2,400 longtime employees in the United States in a program to reduce its work force and slow the growth of expenses.

headline: Insurgents in Ethiopia Begin Anti-Government Offensive
abstract: LEAD: The main rebel group fighting the Ethiopian Government began a long-expected military offensive on Thursday apparently aimed at forcing the Government out of the last piece of Eritrea that it still occupies.

headline: Japan Business Leaders Ambivalent on Election
abstract: LEAD: Japan's worried business community expressed relief but little joy after the election victory Sunday of the pro-business Liberal Democratic Party. Some executives expressed concern over the economic problems that a divided Parliament faces in coming months.

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD:    Debt

headline: Cuban Heads U.N. Council
abstract: LEAD: Cuba's delegate to the United Nations, Ricardo Alarcon de Quesada, took over the presidency of the Security Council today, the first time a Cuban has held the post since 1957. Cuba was elected by the General Assembly late last year to a two-year Council term that began on Jan. 1, the first time it has obtained a seat on the 15-nation body since before Fidel Castro came to power in 1959.

headline: Pan Am Debt Pact
abstract: LEAD: The Pan Am Corporation said that its airline unit had negotiated the extension of $64 million in obligations and interest payments to manufactures, lessors and other creditors, giving the troubled carrier at least until Feb. 28 to pay its bills. Pan Am said in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing that the negotiations were completed last month.

headline: Looking Ahead
abstract: LEAD:    MONDAY: The National Association of Business Economists releases its quarterly survey.    A Detroit jury is scheduled to determine damages for the inventor who claimed Ford stole his windshield-wiper idea.       TUESDAY: The Commerce Department reports durable-goods orders for January.       WEDNESDAY: Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan testifies before the House Budget Committee.

headline: Careers;   Job Turmoil Takes a Toll On Loyalty
abstract: LEAD: ONE business commodity in short supply, and growing shorter, is corporate loyalty, both the loyalty of employees to the company and the loyalty of the company to its workers.

headline: British Rules on Stocks
abstract: LEAD: The Department of Trade and Industry today announced tougher requirements for the disclosure of stock purchases, making it more difficult for buyers to build up secret stakes in publicly held companies. Starting in June, stock buyers will have to disclose to the companies the purchases of stakes of 3 percent or more, compared with the previous 5 percent or more.

headline: Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Is Seeking A Safe Path Through a Time of Change: LEONID ABALKIN, Soviet Adviser
abstract: LEAD: In the rapidly changing world of perestroika, Leonid Abalkin is not the only economist of influence. But he is apparently highly valued for his political flexibility and grace under pressure.

headline: Philippine Army Destroys a Guerrilla Camp
abstract: LEAD: Philippine Government troops destroyed a heavily fortified Communist rebel training camp after two days of fierce fighting that left 59 insurgents and a soldier dead, the military reported today.

headline: Rise in Health Insurance Rates Levels Off
abstract: LEAD: After several years of climbing steeply, increases in health insurance rates are leveling off in many parts of the country, according to executives of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, the nation's largest health insurer.

headline: Threat of Oil Shortage by '93 Seen
abstract: LEAD: The deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company predicted today that oil supply shortages could occur as early as 1993 or 1994 because of OPEC's inability to expand production. A possible increase in demand for oil from Eastern Europe could add to the strain on supplies, he added.

headline: British Inflation at 7.7%
abstract: LEAD: Britain's inflation rate was unchanged in January at an annual 7.7 percent for the third consecutive month. Financial markets had been expecting a lower figure after economists had predicted that the pace of rises in the retail price index, Britain's main measure of inflation, would fall to 7.5 percent.

headline: 3 Men Accused of Violating Computer and Phone Systems
abstract: LEAD: The Federal Government today charged three men in California with engaging in a widespread pattern of breaking into Government and telephone company computers and obtaining classified information from a military computer.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Shevardnadze Comments
abstract: LEAD: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that Moscow had no desire to use force to deal with the Lithuanian drive for independence, or any intention of doing so, but the Soviet official was careful not to categorically rule out a military option.

headline: Frederik Willem de Klerk
abstract: LEAD: There is little in the personal and political history of F. W. de Klerk to suggest that he would be the South African leader to make the bold gestures that have set his country on a course of uncertainty and hope.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Business Week Venture
abstract: LEAD: Business Week magazine and Hirlapkiado Vallalat, a Budapest publishing company, have agreed to publish Business Week Hungary beginning in May, with articles culled from Business Week and Business Week International.

headline: Audit Says New York Telephone Overpaid
abstract: LEAD: A preliminary audit by the New York Public Service Commission found that the New York Telephone Company had overpaid the purchasing division of its parent company, the Nynex Corporation, by as much as $28 million to remove old telephone equipment, according to court documents and people familiar with the audit.

headline: NORIEGA ARRAIGNED IN MIAMI IN A DRUG-TRAFFICKING CASE; HE REFUSES TO ENTER A PLEA
abstract: LEAD: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the fallen Panamanian leader who had vowed never to surrender to the United States, was arraigned on drug trafficking charges here today after giving himself up to American forces in Panama.

headline: Japanese Moon Flight Is Delayed by Problem
abstract: LEAD: Space officials postponed Japan's first mission to the Moon just 18 seconds before liftoff today, but they said they would try again Wednesday if they could correct a technical problem.

headline: KEY RATES
abstract: LEAD:               Previous   Year     In percent   Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   10.00   10.00   10.50        DISCOUNT RATE   7.00   7.00   6.50        FEDERAL FUNDS   8.18   8.18   9.09        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.80   7.76   8.48        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   7.75   7.71   8.52        7-YR. TREAS. NOTES   8.45   8.37   9.04        30-YR.

headline: Market Place;   Shearson Changes Are Hinted
abstract: LEAD: The marriage of American Express and Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. is a permanent one, and the two will be integrated now to a far greater extent than ever before, James D. Robinson 3d, the chairman of American Express, said yesterday.

headline: Celebrity Twist to Savings Failure
abstract: LEAD: In the current savings industry crisis, the collapse of Colorado's Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association would stand out even if one of its former directors were not Neil M. Bush, a son of the President.

headline: Bush and Baker Press the Israelis To End Deadlock on Peace Plan
abstract: LEAD: President Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d suggested today that it was time for the Israeli Government to stop hesitating about putting its own peace plan into effect, and to make the necessary compromises to open negotiations with the Egyptians and Palestinians.

headline: U.S. Sues Northrop Corp.
abstract: LEAD: The Northrop Corporation, which last month pleaded guilty to criminal fraud charges, was sued today by the Justice Department for more than $5 million in related civil damages involving false test results on jet parts.

headline: Productivity Gain Stands
abstract: LEAD: The Government left unchanged today its earlier estimates of gains in productivity of two-tenths of 1 percent for the fourth quarter of last year and of nine-tenths of 1 percent for the year.

headline: U.N. Agency to Provide Aid To Ethiopia Drought Victims
abstract: LEAD: The World Food Program said today that it will provide almost $8 million in emergency food aid for drought victims and refugees in Ethiopia.

headline: Triumphant Opening For New Paris Opera
abstract: LEAD: The new opera house, built on the site of the Bastille prison, had its grand opening today. The crowd roared with approval at the first Paris performance of ''Les Troyens,'' a seldom-performed work by Berlioz.

headline: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
abstract: LEAD: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday, as tax-exempt funds dipped slightly and taxable funds were virtually unchanged.

headline: Chinese at the U.N. Seeking to Keep Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The union of United Nations civil servants has asked Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to extend the contracts of several Chinese workers at the Secretariat who the union says have been asked to leave their jobs under ''pressure from the Chinese Government.''

headline: U.S. Intelligence Aides Say Libya Is Again Making Chemical Arms
abstract: LEAD: Government intelligence experts have concluded that Libya has renewed production of small quantities of chemical weapons and has stepped up its efforts to put a chemical arms plant into full-scale production, Bush Administration officials said today.

headline: Georgia-Pacific In Nekoosa Move
abstract: LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation asked a Federal judge to cut the number of votes needed to dismiss directors of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation in the proxy battle between the rival paper companies. Great Northern has resisted Georgia-Pacific's unsolicited $3.8 billion tender offer on antitrust grounds.

headline: Firm Has 20.76% Of Gulf Resources
abstract: LEAD: D. S. Kennedy & Company, a San Francisco-based brokerage, said it controls a 20.76 percent stake in the Gulf Resources and Chemical Corporation and added that it might seek control of the Boston-based coal and petroleum concern ''absent a substantial change in direction by the company.'' In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Kennedy said it had purchased its two-million-plus Gulf

headline: Upheaval in the East;   BONN WILL CUT AID TO EAST GERMANS WHO MOVE TO WEST
abstract: LEAD: Moving to stem the migration of East Germans to West Germany, the Bonn Government decided today to put an end to special reception centers and most benefits for East German resettlers on July 1.

headline: Mandela Urges Blacks of Natal to End Deadly Rivalry
abstract: LEAD: Nelson Mandela urged his followers today to bring an immediate halt to the factional warfare that has swept Natal's black townships and taken more than 2,500 lives in the last five years.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   BULGARIAN PARTY LOSES DOMINANCE
abstract: LEAD: This country today became the last of the Soviet Union's East European allies to strip the Communist Party of its dominant role, following the others in a halting transition to multiparty democracy.

headline: CBS Plans New Round of Staff Cuts
abstract: LEAD: CBS Inc. plans to cut dozens of employees from its staff, executives at the network said yesterday, either through a strict review of all job openings or dismissals spaced out slowly.

headline: CHINA IS WATCHING WATCHERS CLOSELY
abstract: LEAD: Despite the lifting of martial law in the capital last month, the Chinese authorities appear to have intensified their efforts to keep foreign journalists under surveillance and limit their unofficial contacts with Chinese, Beijing-based correspondents and some Chinese say.

headline: Argentine Stocks Fall 53%; Inflation Soars
abstract: LEAD: Prices on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange plunged an average of 53 percent in value today when the market reopened for the first time since Dec. 28.

headline: Time Warner Posts Losses From Merger
abstract: LEAD: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had lost $222 million in the fourth quarter, compared with a profit of $56 million, or 97 cents a share, in the corresponding period of 1988.

headline: Bush Calls for Peace Talks in Mozambique
abstract: LEAD: President Bush called today for negotiations to end Mozambique's 10-year civil war. He issued the plea after talks with Joaquim A. Chissano, the President of the formerly Marxist country.

headline: British Trade Gap Grows
abstract: LEAD: Britain said today that the country's foreign trade deficit more than doubled in January from December. The deficit was $:1.88 billion, or $3.16 billion, compared with the revised $:817 million, or $1.37 billion, gap for December. The Central Statistical Office attributed the size of the January gap, which was larger than had been expected, to a deficit in several items that were expected to show a small surplus.

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: LEAD: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 14, 1990:       MONDAY       Central & Sth West Corp    Russ Togs Inc    Southern Co.       TUESDAY       Citicorp    DuPont E I Demours & Co    Hartmarx Corp    Hawaiian Elec Inds Inc    Honeywell Inc    Teco Energy Inc    K Mart Corp    Lehman Corp    Loews Corp    Southrn Ind Gas & Elec Co

headline: Policemen in Seoul Break Up Protest Against a New Party
abstract: LEAD: The South Korean police crushed a peaceful protest against a new governing party today, kicking and punching demonstrators and detaining more than 400 in one of the most violent actions this year, witnesses said.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Hot Town Of the 80's Loses Allure
abstract: LEAD: ADVERTISING creative people may leave their hearts in San Francisco, but many seem to be taking their resumes and portfolios out of town.

headline: Murdoch Hires Outsider To Run British Papers
abstract: LEAD: To hear Rupert Murdoch tell it, the British portion of his publishing and television empire is consuming too much of his time, and Andrew Knight is just the man to do something about it.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Reagan Is Invited to Berlin
abstract: LEAD: The East German press agency said today that former President Ronald Reagan would make a campaign appearance for the liberal Alliance of Free Democrats.

headline: WARSAW ALLIANCE SPLIT ON GERMANY
abstract: LEAD: The Foreign Ministers of the Warsaw Pact, meeting here under new, democratic conditions, failed to agree today on whether a united Germany should be neutral or aligned with the West. The Soviet Union was left alone in its rigid opposition to Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

headline: Bush Faces Criticism On Bailout
abstract: LEAD: The savings and loan bailout legislation's smooth trip through Congress last year was a clear Republican victory. The newly elected President, George Bush, had introduced the plan three weeks after assuming office, and it passed essentially untouched by a Democratic-controlled legislature.

headline: Bass Selects Chairman For Holiday Inn Chain
abstract: LEAD: The Holiday Inn, a distinctive American institution, is now owned by the British, and the new man in charge is Bryan D. Langton, an affable European hotel man who will run the chain out of Atlanta.

headline: New Fund to Help Unions Buy Ailing Factories
abstract: LEAD: In an effort to prevent plant closings and resulting layoffs, union leaders and a new investment firm said today that they are forming a fund to help workers buy factories.

headline: BRIEFS
abstract: LEAD: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, sued Massachusetts, challenging the state's 7.9 percent limit on automobile insurance premium increases for 1990.

headline: Economic Scene;   U.S. Memories: Who Is the Loser?
abstract: LEAD: U.S. MEMORIES, R.I.P.: The joint venture formed last year to rescue the American computer industry from the clutches of a Japanese chip cartel died of financial anemia last week. The giant companies it was intended to protect just could not bring themselves to sign checks amounting to a few days' worth of the industry's annual investment budget.

headline: BUSH DRAWS FIRE OVER TROOP CUTS
abstract: LEAD: The chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee and the Air Force chief of staff expressed concern today that the recent agreement to cut American and Soviet forces in Europe would hamper the Pentagon's ability to deploy forces there.

headline: Business People;  Columbia Hospital Plans To Go Public After Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Columbia Hospital Corporation, a three-year-old private hospital company, will be taken public this spring after acquiring Smith Laboratories Inc. in San Diego, which makes medical equipment used in orthopedic rehabilitation.

headline: Kenya Stressing Tea
abstract: LEAD: Kenya said Tuesday that it would increase payments to its tea producers in an apparent bid to increase output of the commodity. President Daniel arap Moi announced that the Government would raise its initial payment to tea farmers some time this month to 3 shillings (14 cents) a kilogram (2.2 pounds) from 1.9 shillings (9 cents).

headline: Further Rises in Rates Expected
abstract: LEAD: Upward pressure on interest rates in Japan and West Germany is expected to continue to influence the domestic credit rate structure this week and in the near future.

headline: Kep Journal;   Listen! A Ghostly Riviera Tells Cambodia's Story
abstract: LEAD: This seafront resort, where Cambodia's elite bathed, yachted and gambled in the days before Pol Pot's battalions spun the entire society through all the circles of Khmer Rouge hell, is now a Riviera for cows.

headline: Business and the Law;   Panel Urges End Of Diversity Rule
abstract: LEAD: A 200-YEAR-OLD rule that has provided the basis for Federal court jurisdiction in many commercial disputes is coming under attack again.

headline: Texaco Tree Plan
abstract: LEAD: Texaco Inc., one of the nation's oil giants, announced a $1 million program to plant trees this spring to start private-sector involvement in President Bush's ''America the Beautiful'' program. James W. Kinnear, Texaco's president, said the money would be shared by Denver, Houston and New Orleans, where the company has extensive operations.

headline: School Reform: Business Moves In
abstract: LEAD: When it comes to reforming the nation's schools, these days the leading radicals are likely to be wearing pin-striped suits and come from oak-paneled board rooms rather than the ivy-covered walls of academia.

headline: Soviet Legislators Urge A Tight Grip on Rallies
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Parliament urged a crackdown today on illegal demonstrations scheduled for Sunday and said the authorities should tightly control legal rallies, the Tass press agency said.

headline: Drug Bosses Give Up Laboratories On Eve of Bush Visit to Colombia
abstract: LEAD: With world attention focused on Colombia for President Bush's summit conference on drugs, the country's most prominent cocaine traffickers made a grab for the spotlight today by turning over to the authorities an enormous complex of cocaine-processing laboratories.

headline: Brasilia Journal;   Brazil Gets the Picture: A Dynamo Is Taking Over
abstract: LEAD: In Japan, he limbered up with karate kicks. In Italy, he bounced a soccer ball on his forehead. And here in Brazil's capital he donned a T-shirt and set out for a well-documented jog.

headline: For Many On Wall St., A Post-80's Hangover
abstract: LEAD: For years Wall Street has been a beacon of wealth and glamour for talented young people willing to work punishing hours for mind-boggling pay. Today, as Wall Street shrinks back to life-size proportions, the game has shifted to making a living, not a killing.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addendum
abstract: LEAD: * Metropolitan Outdoor, an outdoor advertising company, has acquired eight-sheet operations of Transportation Displays Inc., which was formerly called AMNI America, in New York and Los Angeles for $30 million.

headline: S.E.C. Said to Review Trading by Simmons
abstract: LEAD: Harold C. Simmons, the Texas billionaire, said today that the Securities and Exchange Commission had begun an investigation into his trading in the stocks of the Lockheed Corporation and the Georgia Gulf Corporation.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:          The Economy

headline: Bush and Japan's Leader to Meet Next Month
abstract: LEAD: President Bush and Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan announced today that they would meet early next month amid signs that critical trade discussions between Japan and the United States are at a serious impasse.

headline: Europe's Ski Industry Is in Difficulty
abstract: LEAD: After a warm and erratic winter, the European ski industry is troubled.

headline: For Some Publishers, Profit Goes With Quality
abstract: LEAD: For nine years, Cornelia and Michael Bessie have published books that have earned them and their imprint a reputation as publishers of quality. Their authors have included Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn, Theodore H. White, Doris Lessing, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Anwar Sadat and the Nobel laureate Peter Medawar.

headline: Company News;   Mediplex Group To Be Sold by Avon
abstract: LEAD: Avon Products Inc. reached an agreement to sell its Mediplex Group health-care unit to the Diamond Healthcare Acquisition Corporation, a company formed by officers of Meditrust, a health care real estate investment trust, for $100 million.

headline: As Their Visit Ends, Kirkland Pledges Aid to Soviet Miners
abstract: LEAD: The president of the AFL-CIO, Lane Kirkland, has noted the end of a monthlong visit and union training session for nine Soviets miners by pledging to assist the free trade union movement in the Soviet Union.

headline: Noriega's Surrender: The President;   Text of Bush Announcement On the General's Surrender
abstract: LEAD: Following is the text of President bush's statement last night on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

headline: Bloomingdale's Chief Sought Payment Delays
abstract: LEAD: In a last-ditch effort to help the American retail units of the Campeau Corporation avert a possible bankruptcy, Marvin S. Traub, the chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's, the centerpiece of Campeau's operations, asked key fashion manufacturers this week to allow the store to postpone payments on

headline: Bush Says Bill Ignores His Powers
abstract: LEAD: Signing a bill today to allocate $9.8 billion in funds for the State Department next year, President Bush said he did not consider several of its provisions binding, including language that would require him to inform Congress of any sensitive diplomatic missions.

headline: 'Perking Pot' Theme Back at Maxwell House
abstract: LEAD: Joining a long list of American advertisers who are waxing nostalgic, Maxwell House coffee is reintroducing the ''Perking Pot'' theme song that it all but abandoned in 1975.

headline: Corruption Debate, on the Air
abstract: LEAD: Soviet television broadcast a parliamentary debate in which a leading opposition member accused the Prime Minister, Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, of corruption. Page A10.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   A Leader Ousted in Siberia
abstract: LEAD: The Communist Party leader in the Siberian city of Sverdlovsk has resigned in a growing wave of discontent over regional and local party practices, the newspaper Trud reported today. The resignation of the official, Leonid F. Bobykin, was announced on Monday at a regional meeting of party activists, the newspaper said.

headline: Rights Group Assails Iraq for 'Ruthless' Repression
abstract: LEAD: A new human-rights monitoring group, Middle East Watch, assailed the Government of Iraq today for what the group termed ruthless suppression of dissent, apparently seeking to counter Baghdad's assertions that it has entered a period of liberalization in the aftermath of the Iran-Iraq war.

headline: Citicorp Auction
abstract: LEAD: Interest rates were up modestly at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday. It marked the third consecutive week that rates rose. The bank holding company sold $50 million of 91-day paper at an average rate of 8.1805 percent, up from 8.137 percent last week. Citicorp said it also sold $50 million of 182-day paper at an average rate of 8.12 percent, up from 8.043 percent.

headline: Mongolian Communists Rally Against Foes
abstract: LEAD: Thousands of Mongolian Communists staged their first rally today in Ulan Bator, criticizing new opposition movements as undemocratic and calling two of their leaders traitors.

headline: U.S. Deficit Up in Month
abstract: LEAD: The Federal budget deficit increased $14.64 billion in December, bringing the deficit total so far this fiscal year to more than two-thirds the amount permitted for the entire year, the Treasury Department said Tuesday.

headline: CARTER SAYS SYRIA AIDS ON HOSTAGES
abstract: LEAD: Former President Jimmy Carter said in Damascus today that President Hafez al-Assad of Syria promised to help win freedom for hostages held in Lebanon.

headline: Stocks Advance a Third Day; Dow Up 10.13
abstract: LEAD: Stocks rose for the third session in a row yesterday on moderately higher volume, and the Dow Jones Industrial average, which was up more than 28 points in the early afternoon, finished 10.13 points higher at 2,627.25.

headline: Avrett Finds Way to Offer Global Link
abstract: LEAD: ''WE'RE more like the old-fashioned agencies that have grown with their clients,'' said Jack Avrett. But even though his agency, Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, has resisted the acquisition offers that flow to small, successful package-goods agencies like congratulatory telegrams to newlyweds, Mr. Avrett and his colleagues have found another way to grow: Concord International.

headline: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Romania;   ROMANIAN LEADERS COURTING MILITARY
abstract: LEAD: The provisional Government's abrupt dismissal of Defense Minister Nicolae Militaru on Friday after days of protests by army officers is the latest step in its troubled quest for post-revolutionary credibility.

headline: Stocks Drop Broadly, With Dow Off 22.83
abstract: LEAD: Stocks retreated broadly yesterday in continued moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.83 points, to 2,773.25.

headline: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   COMMUNIST SESSION IN BELGRADE SPLIT
abstract: LEAD: In a tense atmosphere of a crew fighting for control of a sinking ship, Yugoslavia's ruling Communists today insulted, challenged and prodded each other on nationwide television, displaying a split in their ranks on the second day of the party's national congress.

headline: Nicaragua Victor Plans to Return Some Land Seized by Sandinistas
abstract: LEAD: The government of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro will move promptly to return or make compensation for most land confiscated by the Sandinista Government, and will sell many state enterprises, aides to Mrs. Chamorro say.

headline: D.&B. Accord Set on Lawsuits
abstract: LEAD: A Federal judge in Cincinnati yesterday approved an $18 million settlement of lawsuits against the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation by customers who said they had been overcharged for credit reports.

headline: OPEC Output at High
abstract: LEAD: Oil production by the OPEC nations rose to an average of 23.7 million barrels a day in the last quarter of 1989, the highest level since early 1981, the International Energy Agency said on Tuesday.

headline: American Drug Chief Resigns
abstract: LEAD: Richard A. Scott, chairman and chief executive officer of the American Drug Stores unit of the American Stores Company, has resigned, the company said last week.

headline: Hong Kong Calls China Talks Useful but Sees No Progress
abstract: LEAD: The Governor of Hong Kong said today that his three days of talks with Chinese officials had been useful, but neither side reported major progress in easing tensions between Hong Kong and Beijing.

headline: Japanese Halt Underwriting
abstract: LEAD: Japanese securities firms are halting equity-linked financing of Japanese companies at home and abroad until the falling Tokyo Stock Exchange recovers, officials said today.

headline: Moscow Accepts U.S. Advantage Of 30,000 Soldiers Across Europe
abstract: LEAD: The Soviet Union abandoned its demand for equal American and Soviet troop levels in Europe today and accepted President Bush's proposal that the United States be allowed to maintain a 30,000-soldier advantage.

headline: Air France Strike Set
abstract: LEAD: Air France's pilots' union today called on its members to strike for 48 hours next weekend to protest deteriorating working conditions and a continuing loss in purchasing power, a union statement said. The statement came as a two-day strike by flight navigators and mechanics at France's three main airlines - Air France, Air Inter and UTA - was drawing to a close.

headline: 2-Part Fannie Mae Offering Of Debentures Priced at Par
abstract: LEAD: A two-part financing by the Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, totaling $1.4 billion and consisting of an equal amount of five-year and 10-year debentures, was priced at par yesterday through various securities dealers.

headline: Muslim Militants Are Seized In Egyptian Religious Strife
abstract: LEAD: The police today arrested 11 Muslim militants accused of fanning sectarian violence, and their leader was reportedly electrocuted when he jumped out a window onto power lines while fleeing the authorities, an official said.

headline: Likud's Civil War: Insults, Then Apologies
abstract: LEAD: Even by the none-too-decorous standards of Israeli political discourse, the mudslinging leading into the Likud party showdown on Monday between Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and three antagonists led by Ariel Sharon seems to be reaching for new lows.

headline: U.S.-Peruvian Teams Renew Drive on Coca
abstract: LEAD: After a yearlong break to strengthen security, a joint Peruvian-American force has resumed eradication of coca plants in the Upper Huallaga Valley, a guerrilla stronghold in northern Peru that is the source of half of the world's cocaine crop.
