headline: GE Aerospace To Cut 5,600 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The General Electric Company's aerospace division said it would eliminate 5,600 jobs in the Eastern United States by 1991, citing tighter Pentagon budgets and mounting competition. The cuts amount to nearly 14 percent of the work force at GE Aerospace, the nation's third-largest military contractor.

headline: Upheaval in the East;   Last of the Old Guard Quits as Czech Premier
abstract: LEAD: Deputy Prime Minister Frantisek Pitra, the last of the old guard Communist leaders left in power after Czechoslovakia's peaceful revolution, resigned today as leader of the Czech republic, the official press agency said.

headline: Mexico Toasts, and Jeers, the Spanish Monarchs
abstract: LEAD: The arrival here of King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain for a state visit has reawakened all the ambivalent and contradictory feelings Mexico harbors for its mother country, with the Spanish couple getting a reception oscillating between warmth and hostility.

headline: A Scholarly Mystery: ''Z'' Writes Darkly of Communism, but Who Is ''Z''?
abstract: LEAD: Who is ''Z''?

headline: Merchant Pacific Buys Barry Stake
abstract: LEAD: The Merchant Pacific Corporation, a private investment firm in Los Angeles, has acquired 8.4 percent of the R. G. Barry Corporation. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Merchant Pacific said it had bought 313,000 shares on the open market for an average of $9.25 each. Barry's shares rose 12.5 cents each today, to $7.625, in trading on the American Stock Exchange, giving the company a current value of $28.2 million.

headline: Your Own Account
abstract: LEAD: The idea behind the Tax Reform Act of 1986 was to simplify taxes. Whether that has worked is debatable, but there are now far fewer ways to cut taxes. Still, taxpayers have dozens of questions on what is allowable under the Internal Revenue Service code. The following are some that accountants hear regularly.

headline: No Shortage, but Costlier Coffee
abstract: LEAD: No matter what economic changes are made next in Brazil, the world's largest exporter of coffee and the largest supplier to the United States, American coffee drinkers will almost certainly be paying more next month at the supermarkets.

headline: Soccer Fans Riot in Belfast; 63 Injured in the Violence
abstract: LEAD: Rival Protestant and Roman Catholic soccer fans rioted at a match today, and the police said they fired plastic bullets into the stands to stop the disturbance.

headline: France Offers Troops to Stop Fighting in Lebanon
abstract: LEAD: France has offered to send troops to Lebanon's Christian enclave in an attempt to avert intervention by the Syrian army and stop fighting that has killed 450 people, Arab diplomats said today.

headline: Profits at Pfizer Are Down 5.9%
abstract: LEAD: Pfizer Inc., the New York-based pharmaceutical company, reported yesterday that its net income fell 5.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 as a stronger dollar hurt sales overseas.

headline: Sutton May Raise Its Bid for DeSoto
abstract: LEAD: The Sutton Holding Corporation, the New York concern that has been pursuing DeSoto Inc. since November, said it might be willing to raise its $50 bid for the Des Plains, Ill., paint and chemical maker to ''at least $55 per share in cash'' if it was given permission to discuss its plans with third parties.

headline: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East German Party Purges Ex-Leaders
abstract: LEAD: Faced with growing rebellion and defections in its ranks over the slowness of internal change, leaders of East Germany's Communist Party decided after an emergency session that ended early today to purge several more former leaders, but rejected calls that it dissolve altogether.

headline: Poland to Get U.S. Corn
abstract: LEAD: Poland will get United States corn instead of butter as initially announced under President Bush's $100 million food-aid package, the Agriculture Department said today. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager of the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said 173,225 metric tons of surplus corn would be donated to Poland instead of the 10,000 tons of butter originally specified.

headline: Release Opposition's Funds, Carter Warns Nicaraguans
abstract: LEAD: Concerned over reports of intimidation of opposition candidates, former President Jimmy Carter warned today of a ''great uproar'' in the United States unless official delays in releasing United States funds to the opposition were stopped.

headline: 2 Die in Attacks by Rival Groups in Ulster
abstract: LEAD: A truck driver was killed today in a machine-gun attack that the Irish Republican Army took responsibility for, and a Protestant paramilitary group said it killed an I.R.A. backer the day before.

headline: Europe's Military Chiefs Meet In a Step to Reduce Tensions
abstract: LEAD: The military chiefs of 35 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, sat down together at the same table for the first time today at an extraordinary seminar intended to reduce tensions in Europe.

headline: Duke Power Bonds To Yield 9.715%
abstract: LEAD: The Duke Power Company, Charlotte, N.C., yesterday priced through competitive bidding $200 million in first- and refunding-mortgage bonds due in 2020.

headline: Walter F. Loeb Retires To Publish Newsletter
abstract: LEAD: After 16 years as the senior retail analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, Walter F. Loeb, an often-quoted commentator on Wall Street, is retiring to become a consultant and newsletter publisher.

headline: At Electronics Show, Phones of the Future
abstract: LEAD: The public got its first glimpse of what home telephones of the future will look like at the winter Consumer Electronics Show, which opened here this week.

headline: Shiite Leader Said to Back Moves to Free Hostages
abstract: LEAD: A key Lebanese Shiite Muslim leader said in remarks published today that he was ''encouraging elements'' that may lead to the release of Westerners taken hostage in Lebanon.

headline: TDK Account to HDM
abstract: LEAD: After a creative shootout, TDK Electronics has awarded the $6 million account for its audio, video and computer recording products to HDM in New York. The other contenders included Della Femina, McNamee WCRS in New York; Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver, and Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer.

headline: Top Spy Flees to Soviets
abstract: LEAD: Markus Wolf, the retired chief of East German intelligence, has taken refuge in the Soviet Union to avoid possible arrest at home in an arms export scandal, a West German newspaper reported today.

headline: Time to Acquire Sunset Magazine
abstract: LEAD: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to buy the Lane Publishing Company, the publisher of Sunset magazine and Sunset Books, in a deal valued at $225 million.

headline: Real Estate;   Seven-Year Face Lift Is Completed
abstract: LEAD: THE enormous building at 120 Broadway that provoked protests 80 years ago and led to enactment of the first zoning laws in New York City - and indeed the nation - has been given a face lift that required seven years of intensive work. Among the tasks in the just-completed renovation were the cleaning of the 50,000-square-foot facade of the 40-story structure and the replacement of many of its eroded terra cotta details.

headline: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;   U.S. Backing West German's Unity Idea
abstract: LEAD: The United States is backing a proposal by the West German Foreign Minister that a reunified Germany be part of NATO but that no NATO troops be based on the territory of East Germany, a senior Administration official said today.

headline: Chevron Cut May Total 1,000 Jobs
abstract: LEAD: The Chevron Corporation said today that it would trim up to 1,000 jobs this year, or 12 percent of the payroll of its domestic exploration and production unit. The oil giant also said it would sell more than $700 million worth of its domestic properties in the next two years.

headline: Venezuela Plane Crash
abstract: LEAD: A military transport plane crashed into a hillside near the Venezuelan capital early today, killing all 24 people aboard, rescue officials said. The cause of the crash was under investigation. National guardsmen on the scene said fog was suspected as the cause.

headline: Security Pacific In Purchase Deal
abstract: LEAD: The Security Pacific Corporation said it had signed a letter of intent to acquire Santa Clarita National Bank for $52.5 million worth of Security Pacific common stock.

headline: Carbon Paper 1, Technology 0
abstract: LEAD: Fat forms - invoices, purchase orders, bills of lading and other multipart documents that require a number of copies - are the bane of most small-business computer printers. The cries of anguish seem to peak at this time of the year when companies start trying to print W-2 forms. Each Federal, state and local agency wants its own copy of the wage statement that employers are required to provide to employees.

headline: No-Frills Bankruptcy Planned for Integrated
abstract: LEAD: For a company that once spent freely, Integrated Resources Inc. is in the midst of a no-frills bankruptcy under the direction of Stephen D. Weinroth.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: LEAD:    THE CAMPEAU FILING       Campeau's American retailing operations filed for bankruptcy protection, saying they had debts of about $7.5 billion. The filing will enable Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores to keep their 260 department stores open while plans are made to stock merchandise, reschedule debt payments and reorganize the company, perhaps selling some divisions.

headline: New India Budget Stresses Farming and Export Push
abstract: LEAD: India's 14-week-old centrist Government today made its first substantial economic statement with the presentation of a budget that is pro-agriculture and pro-export.

headline: Driverless Car Bomb Misses Commodore Hotel in Beirut
abstract: LEAD: A driverless car filled with explosives rolled toward a hotel early today where Syrian soldiers are based, but it careened off course into sandbags and the bomb was defused safely, the police said.

headline: 'Jack of All Trades' Named To Chairman's Job at Boots
abstract: LEAD: The Boots Company, the British retail and pharmaceuticals group, has appointed Sir Christopher Benson chairman. He will succeed Robert Gunn, who had the post for the last five years and will retire in July at age 65.

headline: The Lincoln Touch
abstract: LEAD: The Rev. Jesse Jackson compared President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa to Abraham Lincoln today on the 181st anniversary of the American President's birth.

headline: Dreams of Pitching Machines
abstract: LEAD: In rented quarters here in a nondescript office park on the northern outskirts of Atlanta, Mickey A. Hall is busy living out his own version of ''Field of Dreams,'' the movie about a farmer who builds a baseball stadium in his cornfields in response to an inner voice.

headline: President-Elect of Brazil Pushing Free-Market Ideas
abstract: LEAD: Beginning a nine-nation tour to put a ''new face'' on Brazil, the country's president-elect, Fernando Collor de Mello, vowed in New York yesterday to restore growth to Latin America's largest economy through privatization, fiscal discipline and debt relief.

headline: The Freeze In Florida Aids Brazil
abstract: LEAD: The icicles dripping off frozen Florida oranges on Christmas weekend warmed hearts in Brazil, the world's largest producer of frozen orange juice.

headline: A Vale of Tears, and Anger: Anti-Indian Militancy Is on the Rise in Kashmir
abstract: LEAD: The relatives and friends of Mustaq Ahmed Khan, a 22-year-old man killed this week in a skirmish between the police and Muslim militants, were filled with anger.

headline: PROTESTS IN NEPAL LEAVE FOUR DEAD
abstract: LEAD: The police battled with thousands of students and political militants demonstrating for democracy in central Katmandu today, and at least four people were killed in clashes in the Nepalese countryside.

headline: NICARAGUA EXPERT TURNS THE TABLES
abstract: LEAD: When Francisco Mayorga Balladares boarded a plane for the United States on Friday to represent Nicaragua's government-elect in vital economic talks, he was well prepared. For make the trip.
